description:
What a treat! I love the details in all that they do. The ambiance is stellar and takes you away from San Francisco. The decor is wonderful, even the hallway where the restrooms were and leading up to the kitchen was gorgeous. Seats are low like sofas and you can lounge on the pillows. Best seats are the ones facing the middle of the room, as you can see the whole restaurant and have the perfect view of the belly dancing show. I love that the dancer encourages participation. The waiter was kind and courteous. Food is unique and tasty. The seafood special entree was so yummy, although a bit smaller portion than other dishes. The lamb chicken entree was great. The tea they offer toward the end if so delicious, slightly sweet and feels comfortably warm. Every bit of this night was a fun experience.
Cost comes out to ~$65 per person including tax/tip for prefix (appetizer, entree, dessert) and one beer/wine.
Do expect that dinner for a group may be about 2.5 hours, as there is time in between each course.
author: Veranna N.

description:
This is my first restaurant review. We had such a strange experience at this restaurant the other night that I felt compelled to tell the story as I found it humorous.
We arrived, my family and I for my mom's 80th birthday.  She wanted Moroccan food so we thought we'd give El Mansour a try. When we entered It was a little odd at first as we were the only customers in the entire restaurant, so that had kind of a strange feeling to it. However, the gentleman who greeted us and served us was fantastic. The food was wonderful!  
But here's where things got weird. We sat down and were served appetizers and they were great. Then the main course came. Just as the food was put on the table, very loud music started to play and a woman dressed as a belly dancer came out from the back and began to dance. Now I've been to Moroccan restaurants plenty of times and I'm quite familiar with belly dancing and it can be a pleasant art form. That being said, this woman was definitely NOT a belly dancer. Just some lady shaking it around in a costume like a belly dancer and pushing up on us trying to get us to put dollars in her outfit. She danced and didn't seem to acknowledge the fact that none of us were interested in her at all because, as I mentioned before, she was not a belly dancer.  Oh yeah, and to make it really even more creepy, the only other person in the restaurant, apparently, was her father who she brought along to watch the show.  He sat opposite us, the only other person in the restaurant, staring at this whole fiasco with a big grin on his face. Creepy creepy creepy. The woman finally left after five terrifyingly frightening songs and dances.  And remember, this is all going on at the exact time they serve us our hot food and she literally said oh "well now I'm going to have to compete with the food for your attention".
I don't understand if we are supposed to eat while watching her or leave the food on the table to get cold while we watch her or are we supposed to ignore her and eat? Also, they make a big show of everyone washing hands prior to eating as you eat with your hands.  Money is very dirty.  So are we supposed to be stuffing bills into the sweaty clothing with one hand and eat with the other?  None of that is made clear.
My conclusion to this whole thing is that the food is wonderful and would be great for takeout. Or perhaps on a busier day when the real belly dancers are working.  I feel very sorry for the kind gentleman who was the proprietor that evening as he was phenomenal. I am a bit confused why he allowed this "show" to go on but at least we have a very funny story to tell for years to come. Remember that awful belly dancer.... And we'll laugh.
author: Josh W.

description:
This really is as good as it gets...take me to Morocco! 

Tonight... I was blessed to eat here for the first time, on a first date, with someone very special. It was absolutely perfect. The atmosphere is sensual, festive, enchanting, cozy and beautiful. We felt welcomed, like family; like they wanted us to stay. And dine and party with them and the belly dancer all night. 

It felt like I was dining at the royal palace. Food is beautifully presented with love and oh so flavorful! Since they bring each morsel separately it just keeps getting better and better and you always have something to look forward to! 

The hand washing rituals with flower aroma made me feel like a queen.
The mint tea was like drinking a glass of warm joy. 
The Bastela du Chef chicken pastilla with powdered sugar, cinnamon and almonds was an exotically-delicious delight!

Thank you El Mansour for treating your guests like royalty! You are the true royalty on San Francisco. I hope you get treated as special outside of work as you treat your guests. 

You stole our hearts and we will be back.

Worth every penny and I would tip the 20% and higher if I can. They deserve it.
author: Tangerine T.

description:
This place is great. I was looking for such a place close to Pacifica and found it via google. As soon as I walked in I clearly knew that I'm was going to host my husbands surprise party  there. I booked it right away and asked them all of the details. They said not to worry all will be done. We were able to bring our own wine (corkage fee) and our cake and candles. The party was a success, we had a prefix menu and everyone choose their preference.  The belly dancer was entertaining as well. 
We will come back for dinner for sure.
author: Konstancia M.

description:
I was not sure what this experience would be like but it was amazing. 

The service was awesome. 

Every item from salad, appetizer, entree, and dessert was  awesome.   

The lamb kabob was excellent, the Tagine sea bass was very good. 

I love the hand washing before and after the meal and the mint tea was great 

It is truly an amazing experience.
author: Nancy C.

description:
We had a great night, everything just gorgeous. 
I loved the food,the show and the atmosphere.
author: Rawan 1.

description:
Great family experience! My 10 year old son
had a great time!! He's very particular about trying different foods but he loved every dish they served which is their Specialty menu ( 5 course meal) we ordered the seafood dish and grilled chicken kabobs. Everything was fresh! 
The spices were just right! We loved it! Thank you El Mansour for making our first visit a perfect one!!
author: Lillia T.

description: I had the best time here celebrating during my recent birthday trip to San Francisco. I loved the hand washing prior to the meal and again before dessert. Each course was delicious. The belly dancing was also really entertaining. It's a great experience everyone should have while visiting the Bay.
author: Deisha L.

description: Such a fun and interactive experience! The restaurant is so nicely decorated. The dancer is really excited about her dancing and was able to get the whole restaurant up and dancing with her while each party still felt very intimate. Staff is super friendly and the food is delicious. Highly recommend to everyone! An experience everyone would remember!!
author: Natashia S.

description:
Love this place, I've been coming for over 25 yrs and I've never been disappointed. I a.ways bring my out of town guest here, the experience is unique and the food is tasty.
I love the amount of food you get for the price and there's also a belly dancer to entertain.
author: IRMA C.

description: Best of the best! I have nothing bad to say about this place! It met all of my expectations, ambiance, great food, you can't go wrong going for date night or with a large group of friends!
author: Scott D.

description:
Very nice place , good ambiance and VERY VERY good service !! Definitely going back. 
And good price for good food .
Thanks Sofiane
author: Juliàn É Melanie D.

description:
Love this place 
Great food
Great service
Great atmosphere
Great entertainment 
A must visit place in San Francisco
author: Cj W.

description: Perfect! We arrived without reservations (gasp!) on a Friday night, and the place was packed. But we got lucky and got seated. The atmosphere is fabulous; the decor, music, dancing, hand washing service, and seating -- it all made for a unique experience, I loved it all. Service was great, as soon as you're seated, the bread and water arrive, and we made our entree selections for our 5-course meal. The soup was lovely, I adored the salad plate, and the bastilla was great (note: they will create a vegetarian one if you ask.) Our entrees - chicken with the lemon and olives, and couscous with vegetables -- were delicious. Dessert was nice, but we were too full to finish it. If I had to nitpick one detail it would be the knafeh. I'm used to the Lebanese version of this dessert and what we got was more of a napoleon. Not sure if this is how Moroccans make this dessert, but I was just thrown off a bit by it. The mint tea was the perfect way to end the meal. I'm already looking forward to our next visit.
author: Liz I.

description:
Have been several times over the years, and am always glad to return -- great place for a group. Unbelievable value for a multi-course meal (the bastilla is to die for, as is the lamb w/honey & almonds). Love the gracious service (including hand washing from a beautiful urn), beautiful room and the belly dancer -- lots of fun, and no pressure. Only minor problem: when the belly dancer is performing (twice during dinner), it is LOUD, and impossible to talk.
LOVE THIS PLACE.
author: Delene W.

description:
Be hungry!  Prix fixe with many courses... all delicious.  So much fun to sit at the low table surrounded by cushions.  Joyous, festive evening....Definitely going back.

Choices:

Couscous:
 with Lamb & Veges
 with Chicken & Veges
 with Brochette & Veges
 with Vegetables
Chicken:
 with Lemons
 with Almonds
 with Lemons & Olives
 with Vegetables
 with Honey & Prunes
 with Onions
 with Onions & Raisins
 with Onions & Olives
Lamb:
 with Honey & Almonds
 with Almonds
 with Lemons
 with Olives
 with Lemons & Olives
 with Eggplants
 with Prunes
 with Onions & Olives
 with Vegetables

All selections include:
All include Harira Soup(Spicy Lentil Bean Soup), Salade Mohammed V (Combination of Tomatoes, eggplant, carrots & cucumbers), Bastela du Chef (Pastry filled with chicken, almonds, and assortment of spices),King Hassan (Banana Fritter), Keneffa (Sweet Bastela with Cream and Almonds), The A La Menthe (Mint Tea)
Price: $38.50
author: Bleep S.

description: The food is... fine, not bad, nothing to write home about. However, the ambiance and the show are absolutely worth going for. We had a great time and WILL be back!
author: Michael S.

description: Delicious and unique experience! Belly dancer was amazing and encourages interaction. Lots of fun!
author: Monika K.

description:
Call first if possible to time your dining with the presence of their entertainment (belly dancer). The dining room with its low lighted and the draped fabric ceiling is reminiscent of being inside a tent. As eating with your hands is encouraged (forks are also provided) a server brings the hand washing experience to your table before and after dining.

At $38.50 we are fans of the five course Complete Dinner. 
First served is the Harira Soup/Lentil Bean Soup. 
Then, the Salade Mohammed V, a combination of tomatoes, eggplant, carrots and cucumbers.
Following that, the Bastela du Chef which is a pastry filled with seasoned chicken and almonds.
Following that comes the main Entrée, which had seven to nine preparation options.
For our chicken we choose with almonds and for our Lamb choice we choose to have it with prunes. Both were wonderful. 
Dinner concluded with desserts of banana fritters, something like a donut ball and a soothing mint tea.

If you are dining while the belly dancer performs, she will encourage patrons to join her in a little dancing fun. This is not just dinner it is an all our Moroccan style experience.
author: Caesar A.

description: Amazing ambiance, food, and music!  our dancer tonight was beautiful and so fun! Thank El Mansour! Thank you for my first  Moroccan experience :)
author: Cynthia C.

description:
bad bad bad experience in this place ..... very expensive menu compared to the dishes that this restaurant served i went with my wife and some friends we ordered couscous with lamb. Honestly the side was so small and when i called the server and we wanted it more couscous he was very mad and talked bad to us ..... i'm moroccan but i never never comeback .....
I'll cal this place EL CATASTROPHIC not EL MANSOUR :)
author: Medi M.

description:
Love this place! Always go with a group ,
Whether it be couples or just
A girls night out love this staff and food here! Always consistent and delicious!! Entertainment is always a good time. Sometimes the dancers are a little odd for this place but then other times they are spot on.  Always a good time here and never disappointed
author: Kelly K.

description: Didn't know it existed.. was looking for other places near by. could not find parking. tread into this place by accident a couple of Sunday's back. loved the tent like interior. Food and Service are good  unfortunately, the day we visited there was no belly dancing. would have loved it more with that experience. my favorite is "Bastella"
author: St F.

description:
We came here on a Saturday evening for, of course, a birthday celebration! (That seems to be the case, there were about 6 different parties doing the same thing.)

Like most reviewers mention, ordering individually will provide you with more food than their "group" option. We had 3 tables for 13 guests. On our table we had 5 people and opted to order 3 plates. Our waiter required the extra 2 people to order the soup, salad and starter for $20 a head. (not sure if this is a thing every night or if it's because we had a big party). Anyway, the 3 plates were more than enough for the 5 of us to become stuffed! 

Something I wanted to mention is that the "starter" we got was the same size for the 5 of us as it was for the 3 people we were sitting next to even though we had 2 people paying extra money for it. =/ Food was great regardless.

The belly dancer was entertaining. She tried to engage the party but it felt a bit forced on the participants side. 

I would recommend trying this place once at least.
author: Mai W.

description:
This place is so fun! Definitely a great place for celebrations. Not to mention the food here is so great.  My favorite dishes that I have gotten here is the Lamb with honey and almonds and chicken with almonds! They have this savory, sweet pastry which is to die for! It has either lamb or chicken or both, I honestly cannot remember, but either way it's delicious.   
Definitely recommend! I always bring my family here during special days, I have even had my birthday here a couple times.  Anytime anyone asks me for recommendation in the city, I always point them to this place!
author: Ashley O.

description: Brought some friends here and they thoroughly enjoyed the entire experience! I haven't been here myself for quite some time but once I walked in, I remembered the decor and the feeling was still the same. Very beautiful and exotic. I ordered the rabbit tagine. I think the meat could've been a little more tender but the base/broth was delicious, though. The couscous was quite bland...nothing special added. Don't get me wrong, I still finished everything on my plate. lol. The soup and salad was delicious. Overall the food was decent but I felt it was slightly overpriced for some other dishes that were ordered but hey, we had an awesome time! Great service and everyone was so polite. The belly dancer was gorgeous and put on a great show. She was really engaging with the audience and got a lot of us to dance with her.
author: B. M. C.

description: Gotta be honest. The location scared us off a bit but pleasantly surprised by the end of the night. The early crowd (6:30-7:30) was full of families. We were out on a bachelorette party so that was sorta weird.  Once they left and we were eating ( well seasoned by the way) the fun started. All in all- it was entertaining and the wait staff was great. The belly dancer was good and made the night feel special!
author: Audrey B.

description: Good food (salad and soup) and the show. Couscous was bit tasteless. Would def recommend this place for those trying the cuisine for the first time especially with family and friends.
author: Noni P.

description: This place is amazing!  Had an awesome date night out with my husband here.  There was a very mixed crowd and everyone was made to feel comfortable and welcome (a small group of friends, a big group of family with teenagers, a young 20-something couple on a date, and us).  Everyone was having a great time and the food was amazing!!  Best Moroccan good I've had since I was actually in Morocco!  The wait staff was also super friendly and helpful and I thought the belly dancing would be awkward but instead it was super fun!
author: Laura S.

description: It was love at first site. The beautiful artistic blue door that opens into a fantastical world. From trickling water to hanging lamps all wrapped in a huge silk tent. Pillow seating and the wafting scent of delicious food that greets you. The service is excellent- taking care of your every need. The food is true perfection - from spicy lental soup, to puff pastry stuffed with chicken and nuts topped with powdered sugar, roasted lamb and chicken in a wonderful olive lemon sauce. Morrocan food knows no bounds when it comes to flavors and textures. This place executes it perfectly. And if this isn't ienough they have belly dancers. A truly memorable experience. It hits every high point from service, food to entertainment. Can not wait to come back!
author: Allie P.

description:
I love this place! Great food, unusual decor, great service.... and you eat with your hands!! Belly dancers at 8pm every night and the honey lamb is a foodgasm! Not an everyday restaurant, but a perfect place to travel with your palate. 

Note: parking sucks... do yourself a favor a save time by parking two blocks up in the golf course
author: Ryanbradley N.

description: El Mansour is a perfect stop for me and friends after a day of viewing art and botanicals in Golden Gate Park. The restaurant is a work of art in itself with beautiful tiles but the presentation of the food and the food itself is some amazing stuff. I reclined and produced a single tear after this delicious meal.
author: Hannah Z.

description: We went and we were the only people there. The dancer was amazing. The food and service were top notch! We went with five adults and two children. The children tried everything. We were soooooo incredibly full! I should have stopped eating but everything was delicious.
author: j m.

description: Totally worth the drive out to this part of the city. Very chill atmosphere and excellent Moroccan food. Gets super fun when the belly dancing starts--and super awkward when customers join along. It's like going to a luau and the goofy patrons try to hula. Hard pass for me on the dancing but definitely yes on the food!
author: Carina R.

description: One of the top Moroccan restaurants. I threw a bachelor party dinner for my best friend here. The staff and dancers were friendly. Food was ok, but atmosphere was great. Must try
author: Rajesh D.

description: The atmosphere was absolutely beautiful and I enjoyed the belly dancer, but the food wasn't that great to be honest.
author: Charlotta C.

description: The atmosphere was absolutely beautiful and I enjoyed the belly dancer, but the food wasn't that great to be honest. i Love it.
author: Golbahar K.

description: This place is a lot of fun. The belly dancers were cool and interactive but the Food was incredible. They had multiple veggie and vegan options. The soups and stews will definitely bring me back again! Thumbs way up.
author: Phil S.

description:
All in all, I'd say this is a 3 1/2-star spot - but it's just so fun that I had to bump them up to 4.

I was here for the first time last Saturday.  El Mansour is really off-the-beaten-path for me.  A  far-far-and-away place that I wouldn't  have known about it had it not been for my friend's birthday.  Shout out to my girl!

When I arrived, I thought, "ok, the Moroccan theme is in full effect."  It is a bit corny, but all in all, they've done a good job with the ambiance - dimly lit, beautiful colors, mosaic lighting effects.  All of the seating is the round-table comfort-style, so get prepared to take a chill pill.  

After I took in the Moroccan theme, 'twas time to chow down.  My friends ordered the 5-course meal, and I gotta give them mad props for even mentioning that I'm a vegetarian.  Seriously - when it comes to family-style meals, I'm easy.  Just go with the flow even if that means I'm eating bread and rice. It's all good.

The party started with lentil soup.  100% vegetarian and definitely worth a second bowl if you're hungry.  And next up was a hodgepodge plate - there was a bunch of meaty stuff on this plate but the only thing I can remember I could eat was the eggplant - SO GOOD!  

**THE NEXT DISH, YOU CANNOT MISS** I don't remember the name, but it's a sweet and savory pastry dish (they'll know when you tell them). It's a sweet pastry stuffed with savory, spicy, delectable vegetables and meat.  El Mansour was so nice, they made a special vegetarian version for lil old me.  That just made my night.  By the way, it all comes with bread, bread, and more bread.  Nothing special or artisan - in fact, I think the bread is just regular old white buns. But you'll definitely want one or two to soak up all that spicy goodness.

And finally, desserts.  Honestly, I don't think desserts here are memorable - especially since I can't remember what we had!   It's all topped off by mint dessert tea and that's a fun one to bust out the iPhone video :)

All in all, the food, belly dancing, ambiance and desserts make a fun package for a group of friends to just hang out, be chill, and get some good bites.

FINAL NOTE:  Don't worry about getting gussied up to come here. Dress is SUPER casual.
author: Angella S.

description:
I went with my friends ! We really enjoyed belly dance , food & drinks but at the last , we were so disappointed by the staff "old guy" asked us to leave even though he saw us we were still eating ! He said you guys need to leave bcuz of time limitation . Staff took our food platter & gave us dessert & check ????? I was like WTF so disrespect of customers. Because of that staff "Old guy" I will never visit again . 

Those people want to go there in future please keep in your mind they stupid time limitation. They won't ask you they just take your food platter away even though you eating !

I really want this comment to read by restaurant management & review with him ! Thank you
author: Abishek M.

description:
Absolutely loved this place. Took my boyfriend around 7pm to start dinner. Multi course meal with efficient, friendly staff. The food just does not stop coming, so pace yourself. Sweet, juicy lamb with honey and almonds, came in a very large portion. Particularly, the Bastela was to die for.

Spent almost 3 hours here, eating, talking, watching the entertainment, and enjoying the ambiance. Would recommend it to any friend.
author: Angie R.

description: It was exactly what I was looking for: a small, out-of-the-ordinary restaurant, where you can eat with your hands and get entertained with dancers. It doesn't feel like you're in SF at all. The food was good, but the only reasons why I gave 4/5 is because the service was really slow, and the amount of food didn't seem fair for the price we paid. We were a group of four, and the food seemed like it was for two.
author: Bruna D.

description:
El Mansour was great, as everyone has commented.  We celebrated a graduation here.  If you want a festive, fun dinner, this is the place to go.
  The food was wonderful.  I loved their shrimp and scallop dish.  Yum!  The belly dancer was excellent and people from most of the tables danced with her.  Sunday night was a great night to come, not crowded.
author: Nancy S.

description:
I did not enjoy my experience here whatsoever. They took four hours to bring our dinner out. The food is extraordinarily underwhelming compared to other Mediterranean restaurants. They knowingly served us kanefeh that had salt instead of sugar.  It wasn't even real kanafeh anyways (it was composed of puff pastry). The belly dancers aren't great so if you're looking for professional belly dancing you're better off anywhere else. Definitely the worst restaurant I've ever been to in my entire life. Don't waste your money or time. This place shames middle eastern hospitality and cuisine.

Side Note: Each individual in your group MUST order a FULL meal. A girl in our group of 10 was not that hungry and wanted to opt for something light but our waiter told us that it was not possible. So just keep in mind that every member of your party must order an appetizer, entree, and dessert or they won't let that individual stay in the restaurant.
author: Hanna E.

description: Took my friends here after years since I've been here on my 1st time. The food never disappoints me including the belly dancing that entertains you as your enjoying the food with greats friends. Words can't describe what I'm experiencing unless you come here to judge for yourself.
author: Randy A.

description:
TL;DR: Good food, long wait, unnecessarily high price point.

We tried El Mansour for a spontaneous birthday gathering. It's a nice space and the staff was courteous. Our party was delayed due to heavy traffic so everyone arrived in intervals. We told them that some of us had to depart early, but our food still came very late, the final course arriving when it was departure time for us. Although the food is fairly good, the prices are way too high for Moroccan fare. I have been to several other Moroccan restaurants that are setup exactly the same way and don't charge exorbitant prices - the price of dining in SF I suppose. I'd recommend trying it out if you're in the mood for something different or if it's a special occasion, but not for an average weeknight visit.
author: Naveen H.

description: This was the coolest restaurant I've ever been too! I can't wait to come back. The food was amazing, I was a little nervous though cuz I've never had Moroccan food. We loved everything we were served. We had 4 courses served. For 5 people it came out to like $40 each. And we were full and took leftovers home. There was a belly dancer that performed. The service was great and super friendly and helpful. The whole thing was a great experience! You really felt like you were somewhere else.
author: Maegen E.

description: Fun spot. Pretty good food, but really you are coming here for the experience. Belly dancers are a good time.
author: J A.

description: Had an amazing experience here. The 4 course meal is really good. Smaller portions on the actual entree but definitely nice. The belly dancer was an added plus. Try the Moroccan wine. . The neighborhood on the other hand not good. Gotten broken into. That's the only reason for 4 stars. Price is decent and service is excellent
author: Arlind M.

description:
We went here on a Saturday for a date night, and stepping into this restaurant sent me on a fairy tale vacation to Morocco.  The interior is gorgeous, with fabric hanging from the ceilings, and decorative pillows and tables.  Before you start your course, they bring over towels and a fancy water spout to pour water over your hands to wash them.  They top it off with an orange scented oil to make your hands smell extra good.  Eating here is such an experience.

It's a fixed course menu, so not the cheapest, but reasonable for the amount of food you get.  You start off with this delicious soft bread and a tasty lentil soup.  We had this unique sweet and savory meat pancake dish, the Bastela du Chef next.  As our entrees, my boyfriend and I got two different lamb dishes- the honey and almond lamb and the lamb tangine.  I would highly highly recommend the honey and almond lamb.  I absolutely adored the amount of sweet and savory combinations going on.  The dessert was equally amazing, with the fresh fried bananas.

Halfway through our course, the bellydancer came out, only adding to the experience.  They poured us this amazing mint tea at the end, at about 3 ft above the actual cups- watching this was entertaining within itself.  Though this place is quite a long haul away, it's definitely worth it, both for the food and the Moroccan getaway.  I will definitely be coming back.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Neighborhood places are often forgotten. 
We often take them for granted since access is so easy.  
The friends who introduced this restaurant to me have a special place in their heart here.  You see, their original location two doors up from here was the site of two life changing experiences for them:  their proposal and wedding!
As you walk in, you'll notice the setup is similar.  The tables have either bench seating or cushioned stools.  We were seated near the kitchen entrance.  After receiving our menus, my friends noticed it was different from before.  There are meal options as well as ala carte selections available.  We were a party of six and two diners were new to Moroccan food so we asked our waiter to  put together a family style tasting menu.  Here's what we had:

First course
Soup and bread (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=ulZYvIO4qYPB_MSW1-9DWQ) - Smooth and slightly warm bean or lentil soup with fresh baked warm bread.  

Second course
Pickled veggies and hummus/dips (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=gb_etxW14Mi16ODrgXDo9g) - Good munching while conversing course. Nothing really stood out.

Third course
Chicken pie (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=xCX2Mi79mfF8EggQhe09fQ) - Favorite dish of the meal, but wish it was warmer.  Friend joked that he would prefer a double order of this over entrees.

Fourth course
Mixed entrees (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=GSrcoR-KhUuf0D_GKKi0jQ) - This plate featured a little from each of the dinner entrée options of seafood, kebabs, lamb, and chicken.  The seafood comprised of scallops, shrimp, and some squid, I believe.  The quartered chicken was well seasoned but a bit difficult to share as bones were an obstacle.  The kebab was okay and didn't stand out.

The dancer started her performance when we received our second course.  By this time, the dining room was 70% full.  The sword dance and audience participation were the highlights.  Given the large gap between dining trips here, it is difficult to detail the changes; generally, I remember there was more protein, the old place was cozier, and the feel was a bit warmer and brighter.  The meals here are around $40.00 per person pretax and tip.  Food rates three stars plus half star for attentive service and entertainment.  Decent change of pace neighborhood spot.
author: Mike C.

description: This place is an experience. The entrance alone has you feeling like you are walking into a different world. The restaurant is designed in traditional Moroccan style with low tables and comfy couches. The staff is very friendly and inviting. They had moroccan wines by the bottle and glass. Their meals are basically a fixed price 4 course meal for around 40 dollars. The black bean soup is rich and warm and perfect for a cool night. The salad was a variety of mezze including eggplant, cucumber and carrot cold appetizers. The lamb entree was fantastic. The lamb kebab was also really good. The chicken kebab was average. The vegetable couscous was my favorite! Fried dough and bananas were served for dessert. It was hard to finish all the delicious food. The food and service was great. My one complaint was that there was a table of really loud male customers who were being disruptive by harassing the belly dancer and yelling when other tables got birthday singing and going into the womens bathroom and then laughing about it when I had to wait for them. The staff was obviously in a difficult position and I was disappointed they didn't ask these guests to calm down. It did make the whole experience change quite a bit.
author: Anne S.

description:
We were a party of 6.
Prefixed meals. Endless bread. 
Start with bread and half bowl of barley soup.
Next was the salad, comprised of small piles of pickled cucumbers and carrots, some mushy eggplant, seasoned diced tomatoes similar to salsa.
One bottle of wine.
Next two Bastela du chef, approximately 8 inches in diameter, 1 inch tall. 
Next, main "dishes". They place a little of everything on one platter about 12" in diameter. The portions didn't seem right for 6 people, more appropriately for 2-3 people.
Dessert was about 4 balls of fried banana, two small custard like filled pastry the size of a ravioli, and two beignets. Again, not enough for 6 people.
Sweetened mint tea to finish.
Total bill - $345, tax and tip included.
Dinner was around 9pm and we were the only party at this time. 
Belly dancing ensued around 9:15pm.

The food was good. I think the vibe, decor, and service was amazing, but guessing it's one of those places you only go once and never return. If the prices we lower and portions were more reasonable, I'd go back.
author: Susan C.

description:
The Chicken entree w/ Honey and Prunes is honestly one of the worst chicken dishes I've ever had. It's inedible; imagine piles of fake/condensed prune syrup spread over chicken. It's more artificial tasting than candy. 

The appetizers were significantly better and were actually pretty good and interesting. The service was great and the belly dancers are a nice touch. 

Still, I would never go here again because the price is absurdly high (dinner for two is easily ~$100) and the food is mediocre overall and the Chicken entree was actually atrocious (I'm not exaggerating).
author: Jared G.

description: The food was great! We ordered takeout but the staff was very friendly and helpful while I waited. The decor is really cool too.
author: Kenneth C.

description:
Very different, Cozy, friendly staffs. 
However food comes out a bit slow so if you are hungry, I suggest going some where else. 
Great for family, friends, couples. 
Food was decent. Wish they had more options. 
Service was great! 
Belly dancer came and performed around 8:30ish. It was fun to see! 
Dancer was too close to our table I feel bad eating front of her so our table waited until she was done with her dance. Didn't want to be disrespectful. 
I would come here again!! 

Tip* make sure you tip the dancer. She will ask you dance with you so prepare!!
author: Stella K.

description:
Truly amazing service great food in this place!!!
Me and my friends had an early dinner and we were very happy for the decision to come out here, best service in the bay every body here super nice.
Thank you guys for the good time
author: Roy G.

description: Entertaining and lively atmosphere. The server was quite attentive to our needs despite the place being really busy. Our food was satisfactory as well. Certainly, I would recommend this place to others. Next time I'm in San Francisco, I will be sure to visit this establishment again!
author: Robert S.

description: I am very disappointed with the quality of service! we came especially to eat good couscous they did not even respect on the quantity we paid very expensive to give us a little ball of couscous! we remarked to the waiter he replied to us by saying "you are not in Morocco here you are in the united states" disrespectful
author: Jasmine B.

description: Came here for my birthday tonight and it was an incredible experience and delicious meal! We left feeling stuffed and in awe of the talented dancer. My only disappointment was that the fish tagine had just sold out, but now it's more of a reason to come back. I had the shrimp and scallops which were cooked and seasoned to perfection. My boyfriend said the lamb melted right in his mouth.
author: ashley d.

description:
We were staying in San Francisco for the night and I Googled fun placed to eat.  Came across El Mansour.  Wasn't sure what to think when we pulled up outside and saw it nestled between other businesses.  We had trouble finding parking in the crowded residential neighborhood but once we went through the doors, it was like being transported.  It is definitely a hidden gem.  The atmosphere was authentic Moroccan.  Service was very attentive.  I had the chicken kebobs and they were the most flavorful chicken I've ever had.   My husband had the chicken and lamb kebobs and said the lamb was equally good.  All the other courses were delicious as well. 

Part way through our meal, the music turned up and the belly dancer came out.  She put on a long show, interacting with the guests and encouraging them to get up and try to learn some moves.  It felt like she was on the floor for close to 30 minutes.  Very fun.  Service continued uninterrupted during her show.  

I would definitely recommend this as a must for all visitors to SF.  Great place for a celebration also.
author: Susan B.

description:
I was so excited to come here for my birthday, which I made reservations for 5 days prior, but I was better off going to the Burmese restaurant up the street. As soon as we walked in there it was aesthetically pleasurable, however, we were approached by the intimidating owner. I explained to him how I had made reservations several days ago, and he kept denying that I made the reservation because he simply didn't know my name off the top of his head and didn't bother to check. He finally sat us down in a very uncomfortable spot in the corner of another table just to squeeze us in. My friend got the courage to ask if we could possibly move, and he "jokingly" questioned why we wanted to move so bad. Fortunately, he was not waiting on us, and the actual waiters were very kind and understanding people. Also, the belly dancer was phenomenal. She was very interactive with the crowd, and really knew what she was doing! However, the food was pretty mediocre and very overpriced, but the portions were pretty decent. Unfortunately, I wasn't a fan of their food except for the chicken pastilla which was delicious! 

El Mansour seemed like such an exotic, fun place, but coming here will just be a one time thing for experience. This place definitely had its ups, but unfortunately, the bad outweighs the good.
author: Talia Z.

description: Fabulous setting and wonderful Moroccan food. A bit expensive, but well worth it. I could do without the belly dance. I will definitely return over and over and bring friends
author: Sandy R.

description:
Wow! What an experience! I think, somehow, my girlfriend, our neighbor and myself were accidentally transported out of San Francisco last night and wound up in Morocco. This was a dining adventure unlike any other I can remember. I mean that sincerely, and I don't understand the yelp reviewers that spoke so nastily of this place.

The atmosphere was quite and relaxing. No, you didn't sit on the floor like other such establishments, but the seating was far more comfortable than the typical booth at any other given restaurant. I could have stretched out and fallen asleep right there if good manners hadn't prevented me from doing so.

Moroccan cuisine is new to me, or was up until last night. Everything from the bread, lentil soup on up through the tea at the end was delicious and satisfying.

Back to the atmosphere. I have very eclectic musical tastes and what I heard last night was a big part of what left me feeling I had been transported. Sure, it was contemporary (from what sounded like Moroccan hip hop to an extended remix of Stings "Desert Rose), but that only served to make me feel like I was visiting the Morocco of today, and not time traveling.

One more hint on the food. If You read the menu and the sugar and cinnamon on the Bastilla sounds off-putting, please, don't let it stop you. It is a blend of sweet and savory that works so well, it's practically magic!

My only regret? Missing the belly dancer. But that, and the food is just another reason to go back again.

So, if you want to visit Morocco without a long flight or having your passport in order, don't miss this place!
author: Alan W.

description:
This place is my treat. I've eaten here at least 6 times. The soup, bread, salad, entree are all good.  I love the Bastilla, mint tea and the orange scented hand washing experience.  I will return again and again. 

If I were to remove a star it would only be because it's a long drive to the restaurant.
author: Lorraine G.

description: Absolutely phenomenal experience. From the belly dancers ( no joke), to the warm water to wash your hands at the table, to the eucalyptus tea, etc. I would 100% go back. The meats are high quality, well seasoned, and the service is above par. It's NOT a cheap experience though, so get ready to splurge. And come hungry, because the courses are never ending.
author: Candace S.

description:
Game to experience different cuisines, our friends made dinner reservations for an exotic Moroccan dinner at a neighborhood restaurant.  After entering the restaurant doorway that is lined with Moorish tiles, you've entered a large dining room that's resembles a Moroccan tent.  Walls are covered with green and red tapestry with low pillowed bench sofas and floor cushion stools and lacquered dining tables.  The dining room was semi divided into two and we were seated in the back half this evening. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-mansour-san-francisco?select=OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg#OFGmDeYqPD-uy5qRnu5D8g)( http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-mansour-san-francisco?select=OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg#OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg)

After checking out the menu, we opted for the specialty selections for the six of us. The meal starts off with a hand washing, where the waiters brings a silver basin to the table and pours warm water on your hands to wash them.  Why?  Because you eat with your fingers.  No utensils here.  Ok, they will give you a fork if you insist.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-mansour-san-francisco?select=OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg#R0B9NoJPGSPXc_5YLZew2w)

To start the meal, the waiter brings a large platter of sliced Moroccan flatbread for you to put on your plate.  He does come by several time during the course of the dinner to offer more bread.

Harira Soup - a bowl of warm spicy lentil soup that you can dip your bread into it. Though described as spicy, didn't think it was spicy. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-mansour-san-francisco?select=OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg#Ufb3Uk7ecB17mDZg52Gwrw)

Salade Mohammed V - a combination platter of tomatoes, eggplant, carrots and cucumbers. Each platter served three of us.  This is where the bread came in handy. Used it dip/grab the tomatoes and eggplant items.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-mansour-san-francisco?select=OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg#M5JdxW_Mnr8xxFrlvuCWug)

Entertainment. Yes, this is when belly dancer started performing.  After her solo performance, it was audience participation time. First three women, then three men.  Let's say, I got a dance lesson with my dinner. Ha!  She then finished with a sword dance. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-mansour-san-francisco?select=OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg#JaLK7hwycpp2UIGzW9HyHg)

Bastela du Chef - chicken pastilla with almond and spices.  Each of powdered sugar topped pastilla served three of us.  The warm filling is not creamy, but rather a dry filling.  This Moroccan chicken pie was tasty. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-mansour-san-francisco?select=OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg#HAHxPRwJnSXLbC779D60sA)

Specialties plate -this was a good sampler plate. It consisted of Moroccan seafood (shrimp and scallops), lamb and chicken kabob, lamb and chicken with almonds and vegetables.  It was good way to get a sampling of the various Moroccan dishes.  The chicken and lamb were not deboned and hence, at times it was a little difficult to manage with just your fingers.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-mansour-san-francisco?select=OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg#pfOL6hR0iX5Rpua2NqOVIw)

Again, it was time for another hand washing before our dessert course.  Mint tea was then artistically poured from three feet above the cup. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-mansour-san-francisco?select=OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg#xh0OPtXQxjWcjwQbQTG6SA)

King Hassan (banana fritter) and Keneffa (sweet bastela with cream and almonds) - good, but expected something more exotic. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-mansour-san-francisco?select=OajpZ0UqqwJ3WJWi4Payrg#wfptEcbIdi3kBKWxN730Uw)

Overall, it was a nice experiencing the foods and culture of Morocco at a neighborhood restaurant in the Richmond District.  Service was friendly and attentive.  This being my first foray into Moroccan cuisine, it was nice being able to taste a wide variety of foods during this meal.  Some dishes were tastier and more unique that others. Now I can say I've dined Moroccan.
author: Al L.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday, and was so excited. The belly dancer was gorgeous and I loved how interactive she was. The servers were very friendly and polite. 

HOWEVER, this "new owner" (this was only my first time being there, but I'm pretty sure he's the owner that all these reviews are written about) was not welcoming whatsoever and made me second guess if I should even spend my money there. He didn't have a space reserved for us already, in which we called more than a week ahead for, and decided to place us in any space he could squeeze four people in. I had to ask him to move us, and he really had to question me about it, which to me was very rude. The only reason why I gave them a star is for the wonderful staff.  

You would think that the owner would be the most inviting and genuine person.
author: Taylor V.

description: I enjoy finding a new place in the City each year to take my husband for his birthday.  He LOVES good and interesting food and, since he's a great cook himself, he knows it when he tastes it.  My choice of El Mansour for this year's birthday was a winner.  The food was delicious!  (And generally quite authentic Moroccan, with a few concessions to the fact that we are in the US.)  The service was great -- attentive but not at all overbearing.  (A nice touch:  when my husband went to the restroom, the waiter came over to ask if we were there for an occasion and I told him about the birthday.  He later presented my husband with a lovely little birthday dessert.  So nice.) The belly dancing was fun and interesting.  (The dancer is one hard-working artist!  The crowd was light, since it was a Tuesday night, but she put on a great show and did her best to involve the customers.  She even got my husband to dance a little!)  One caveat -- the seating is traditional low tables and pillow-topped benches -- maybe not the most comfortable seating for people (like me) with back issues, but that is a minor cavil given the enjoyable evening we experienced.  This place is also a good value.  Our $40 prix fixe dinners included delicious soup, salads, bread, dessert, and mint tea, and our entrees were so generous that we both had leftover for the next day.
author: Gail J.

description:
This place is great for a group outing or special birthday dinner

Came to this place about 7 years ago but never Yelped it. Hmmm....
You walk in and you're taken to another land with colored lanterns, ornate and comfy seating, and subtle traditional musis. Menu items are fixed meaning you choose your entree (chicken, lamb, vegetarian) and is accompanied with a soup, salad, dessert and complimentary tea. The food is delicious starting with lentil soup, and sharing dishes such as chicken kebab with preserved lemons and lamb with prunes...of course, we all had the giggles as to who would have the first affects of eating prunes. Immaturity aside, the dishes were delicious and our group had fun all night without any potential-prune-induced issues.  Probably a good thing they served mint tea....My favorite dish of the evening was the Bastila - sweet, savory, cinnamony, powdered-sugary filo wrapped shredded chicken with almonds. Sounds odd but so delicious!

The belly dancer was wonderful and engaged customers in joining her. She had that side-hip action going ala Shakira and were all wowed.
author: Cheryl M.

description: This restaurant was a must for me to check out since I had seen it in a travel guide for San Francisco and I was not disappointed! The ambience, food, and customer service was great! I had the lamb with honey and almonds. We were seated at 6:30 pm and were told the belly dancing show would start at 7. Boy was that further from the truth. It started more around 8 pm, but good thing we weren't in a rush! The belly dancing show was a lot of fun and participation was required by some of the guests (no one objected, of course! All in good fun no matter how embarrassed you felt). We had plenty of leftovers after our meal and left in a great mood. I would highly recommend coming on a night when you don't have any other plans. Just sit back, relax, and eat!
author: Jamie M.

description: It actually pains me to say this because I'm a pretty big fan of Moroccan food, but I was honestly was not impressed by this place at all. That's what happens when a dinner turns into a three-hour affair that pretty much blows up your entire Saturday night plans. Not just that, but somehow family style (which you would expect to be cheaper) still ended up being like $60/person. Shame too, because the food was pretty decent.
author: Alexander Y.

description:
Don't know what all those ppl saying food was only OK were talking about --- the food we got today (new years eve) was AMAZING! 

Ambience is excellent. Love the decor. The seating gives a communal feel but every "table" still gets their little privacy. 

You get a little handwash from a silver basin before and after the meal. A very nice little touch.

Our set menu for NYE was $49 (or $45, I forget). Appetizer includes spicy lentil soup (delicious and not too spicy), cold plate of eggplants, cucumber and other veggies (I don't really care about pickly stuff so no comment), and something called Bastela which is a pastry that contains minced chicken HOWEVER the crust is phyllo dough with powdered sugar! I have never had a savory meat dish that has sugar on top, yet in this case it works perfectly! LOVE LOVE LOVE the Bastela! It is a must have dish.

For entree, we got fish tangine, lamb/chicken with honey and almonds, and lamb/chicken with lemon and olives. All three dishes were amazing. The meat was extremely tender (I asked the chef and the secret is just low simmer for hours) and requires no knives. The seasoning was just right, not too much spices or salt, but a very nice delicate balance. If it's any evidence, my 16-mo toddler cannot handle spices (she rejects Ethiopian food and Indian food), but was able to gobble down the fish, lamb, and chicken with a voracious appetite. 

Dessert is very simple. Banana fritter and sweet bastela, accompanied by sweetened mint tea. Overall the portions were very good, not too much of anything, and I feel satiated but not overly full at the end.

Finally, there is entertainment. When dessert came out, so did the belly dancer. She performed 4 - 5 pieces (including a knife dance), and then asked the audience to join for dancing. I thought that was very fun and I shamelessly joined in :) after all...it's NYE! She was very engaging and professional. My little toddler was very intrigued by the dancing!

The chef came out several times to check on the guests. He also constantly made sure the waiters were attentive. 

Perhaps this is a special occasion and thus everything was especially cared for. Nevertheless, I have had such a good experience here, that I cannot give it anything less than 5 stars! For sure I will be coming back.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: I have eaten at over a hundred Moroccan restaurants around the world (one of my favorite cuisines).  Tonight 3 of us had the Feast with Lamb with honey and almonds and Lemon Chicken.  Great food, excellent service.  This place ranks among the best I've had. Would go back again.
author: Laurence D.

description:
Ok I came here with four other friends. We all thought the food and the decorations here were spot on. The restaurant was really authentic; they even had a belly dancer. 

HOWEVER, we thought we only ordered the lamb and vegetable couscous, but the one waiter there just kept on serving us more than we ordered! We ordered only 2 of the main dishes and planned to share it "family style", since we are all college students on a budget and the place was a kinda pricy. BUT the waiter took "family style" as give these people all the food on the menu!! So we kept getting big plates of food and even dessert. We thought came with the meal because we didn't ask for dessert. 

We expected to pay no more than $90, BUT when we opened the check the bill as a whopping $220!! We were all shocked! He even charged us for the dessert! I feel like they took advantage of us by just giving us food and not telling us what we had to pay for. The waiter just kept on saying, "oh it's ok, it's ok" whenever we asked questions.

SOOO if you have tons of money and a hunger for Moroccan food definitely go here! But if not, STAY AWAY. THEY WILL JUST KEEP ON GIVING YOU FOOD WITHOUT TELLING YOU THE PRICE & YOU WILL HAVE A GINORMOUS BILL.
author: Brie G.

description:
Spent V-day here with the beau and it was absolutely perfect.  I knew I wanted to go somewhere romantic and not too stuffy.  El Mansour definitely fit the bill.  Upon opening the door, you are whisked into the main dining room.  The seats are lined up against the walls to create an open space in the middle.  Everything felt very exotic - from the curtains hanging from the ceiling to the arabesque lamps lining the wall.  The decor are deeps reds, golds and greens.  

The menu is a five-course meal where you just have to pick your entree.  The meal starts with washing your hands in a beautiful silver bowl while the server pours the water from a pot.  This instantly set the mood that we were in for something different. 

Next the lentil soup arrived with bread for dipping.  I loved that it arrived piping hot.  Next, a salad  of various vegetables - carrots, and cucumbers and other pickled selections similar to a mezze plate.

Then the Bastela du Chef which was a puff pastry made up of sweet and savory fillings dusted with confectioner's sugar.  

For entrees, we had the Moroccan seafood with shrimp and scallops served with coucous and the Lamb and chicken.  Everything was delicious.

For dessert, we had banana fritters and the Keneffa - a sweet puff pastry with cream and almonds.

Wait..there's more!  As a palate cleanser, our server pours us hot moroccan mint tea with a touch of honey.  My favorite part was watching our server pour the tea from high above into the cup.

Needless to say, we were absolutely stuffed.  At the end of the meal, the server comes out with the wash basin for us to wash our hands.  As an extra touch, he also sprinkled rose water into our hands. 

The cherry on top was the complimentary rose at the end of the night.  

And of course, the belly dancing!  She came out twice during our meal for about 10 minutes each.
author: Hieu H.

description:
My family has been dining here for some 30 years. Until last week it was one of my favorite spots to bring SF visitors... 
El Monsour has changed ownership. They seem to be cutting corners. Although it is still the same beautiful building, all the little differences really added up -especially at $120 for dinner for two. Most notably;
1. Servers no longer wear traditional dress or serve homemade bread in the traditional lidded basket.
2. The menu is the same but the food is different. Not only smaller portions but the food.The 2nd course eggplant salad is mostly sliced pickled vegetables and dessert is a fried banana instead of that delicious fried honey stuff they used to have.
3. They gave us FORKS! This bothered me the most and really killed the remaining ambiance.

Nonetheless the friends I brought here really enjoyed it and it is still one of a kind; but, for me its lost its magic.
author: Miss J.

description:
First date? Night out with some kids? Need some entertainment with your meal? El Mansour is totally the place to go. 

PROS: Great food, semi-pre-fixe menu, gorgeous interior decor, parking easily available across the street, bellydancers nightly, outstanding service

CONS: Ok, it's a little pricey. 

The menu at El Mansour is mostly pre-fixe; choose you entree and the rest is taken care of. 

Your meal starts with a ritual hand-washing in a warm silver basin with towels (you're gonna eat with your hands). Next comes a harissa spiced lentil soup you'll sip from the bowl or sop up with homemade bread. A veggie course is next with a platter of 4 salads (tomato and pepper, roasted eggplant, pickled cucumber, and spicy carrot). Third course is the bastella, which is a thin and crisp philo dough filled with a savory-almost-sweet blend of chicken, eggs, and spices (this one is truly unique!). Your entree of choice will come next, and after digesting they'll bring out a fried banana dessert and a lovely pouring of moroccan mint tea. To wrap it all up, you'll wash your hands in warm water again, and the waiter will sprinkle rosewater on your hands so they don't smell like food. 

El Mansour is solid moroccan food with a serving pattern that you can chat about with your fellow diners. The pre-fixe setup allows you to try small portions of things you might not otherwise order, and get a great sampling of the cuisine. 

5 courses for $38? Not bad!
author: Laura J.

description:
tl;dr If you eat here, the food is a mixed bag, but ponder this: you must tip the bellydancer or risk looking like a jerk.  

My girlfriend and I spontanteously made reservations for 7:45, based on the great reviews.  We didn't know a ton about the place.  The decor is excellent and the opening washing-of-your-hands ritual is really welcoming.  Confusing menu.  You have to work it out - you're getting a price fixe menu, not selecting courses.  We ordered, eventually.  

Very good soup and very good bread, which showed up eventually.  I liked the salad; girlfriend found it bland.  The bastela du chef, which came out eventually, I liked.   My girlfriend found the combination of powdered sugar, pastry and chicken to be an abombination.  She took a bite and then stared at the poor thing like it was a spider or running for president.  We have had hundreds of meals together but I've never found a dish that made her angry before.   If she had a time machine, she would go back and distract whoever invented that combination so that this travesty would never happen.  (Me, I liked it.)  

Our main dishes were fine.  My girlfriend liked her chicken with prunes and honey very much.  My kebob was seasoned beautifully and the vegetables and coucous were tasty, but the texture of the chicken itself was strangely grainy and rubbery in a way I couldn't identify.  Then there was a very long pause for dessert, an excellent fried banana and chocolate number that could hold its head up high.  The ending tea was refreshing and sweet and served oddly -- I don't want to spoil the entertainment value but sit back from the table and be prepared for splashing.  

You can't seriously complain about how long Moroccan food takes, so I'll just say we were there for two hours.  And there were two babies who were also there for two hours.  

About the bellydancer.  She was good.  However, I hang out with some dancers, and if you know bellydancing, she was -- fine. Ms. bellydancer, if you're reading this, apologies for the critique, I know you work hard and you love the form, and when you worked with the sword, that was quite lovely.  I'm glad that folks danced with her.  But I came for the dinnertime conversation, and if you want to distract us from that, please be excellent.  What was actually distressing, though: we couldn't help overhearing jerks who were calling her fat.  Note: Saying "she put the 'belly' in 'bellydancing'" isn't witty.  It's depressing.  

After a couple of dances, the waiter put a dollar in her pants and then it was clear she was going to get tips from us.  That, I hadn't been prepared for.   Of course, she works hard, but I hadn't a clue money was going to be part of it.  My idiocy, I suppose.  One tips entertainers, but this felt like we were caged into it.  Tip or be a jerk.  

Here's how that resolved: a table across from us was made up of a pair of men and an older couple, man and woman.  One of the men was focused on the dancer in a way that made me uncomfortable.  It was an ogle.  Which was strange because he was gay, and he was there with his husband or boyfriend.  And yet the look on his face was almost Tex Avery-style lust.  And then I realized what was going on: he and his mate were at dinner with his mother and step-dad.  Who didn't approve.  You could see it on Mom's face -- she was clearly not enchanted with her son's life.  And the evening became clear: the young men planned it. Of course, your parents are coming, we'll bring them to that place with bellydancers.  WE WON'T EVEN HAVE TO TALK problem solved.  

So they had many many dollars out.  The spouse danced with her.  The tension was diffused.  Yay, bellydancer!  It didn't work so much for the mother having an awkward birthday dinner with teenage daughter.  Nor my table, where it was fast becoming apparent that I was uncomfortable and feeling like sort of a grinch.  My girlfriend and I have friends who are strippers, something I hadn't really thought about until just then.  The dynamic of putting money onto a lady because she has aroused you wasn't something I was planning on doing that night.  It felt like going to an innocent time share condo meeting and then having a contract put under your nose at the end.  I didn't tip.  

There were several birthdays.  There were people having a lot of fun here.  So that's another data point, right?

The next morning, my girlfriend and I exchanged texts about our dinner.  I said I felt hungover.  She said she wondered if my chicken had been frozen.  I asked how she felt, and she said like there was still chicken and powdered sugar in her mouth.   Your mileage may vary.
author: George G.

description: Came here on a Thursday night and was told belly dancer had cancelled for the night. They should have mentioned something when I booked the reservation an hour earlier. Great food but without live entertainment it is a bit pricy.
author: vahid r.

description:
Came on a Thursday night, and since we have a 10 mos old, we were there when they opened.  At first there was one other party, and the end of dinner there were 4 parties in total. 

Décor was lovely; felt like we were back in Morocco.  

The food was great.  The fresh bread was yummy.  We ordered the lamb with honey and almonds.  The lamb was cooked perfectly; and while the dish was on the sweeter side, it didn't over power the dish.  I wish the dish came with cous cous or rice, but really with sooo much food I probably wouldn't be able to eat the whole entrée.  Hubby ordered the rabbit; to me this one was the star of the night.  The dish was sweet and savory, and a good size portion.  All the courses were very tasty.  The waiter/host was very nice.

The only negative, if you can call it that, was the time between courses was too long.  As parents we have a bedtime ritual we need to keep, so a 3.5 hour dinner is not what we expected.  

With that being said, we'd like to go back.
author: Kris Marie D.

description:
This seems to be the only "traditional" style, multi-course Moroccan restaurant with bellydancers that I have been able to find in SF, and compared with others I have been to in other cities, this ranks high up there - delicious food, good service, bellydancing, ambiance! 

First, the food: The lamb + couscous was AMAZING, so tender! And I usually don't like lamb dishes. My husband's rabbit tagine dish was delightful. Every course was delightful (not a big deal and doesn't change my high opinion of the restaurant one bit, but I think they could improve on the dessert - I'm personally not a big fan of fried bananas and phyllo dough with almonds, but others in my group enjoyed it).

Second, the experience: Interestingly, it doesn't look like a restaurant from the outside - the ceramic tiles on the wall and blue door are full of atmosphere / character, and the inside is cute as well. Service was attentive. 

Unlike in similar restaurants, the bellydancer doesn't merely go up to each table and do a little dance and move on to the next (we did go on a Sunday, so it was less crowded), but she performed for almost 30 minutes straight while we were there (starting at 7:30pm) and used props such as cymbals, a drum, and a sword. She also did some interactive dancing - I enjoyed dancing with her!
author: Jan Z.

description: My family and I really enjoyed our experience. The atmosphere was authentic, the food was excellent, the service was superb and the belly dancing was entertaining. Would definitely recommend to anyone . Truest a great evening.
author: Anna S.

description: First time seeing belly dancing! Food was pretty good. Menu is a little atypical, but the staff is really great and attentive.
author: Tabi K.

description:
I usually don't like to give 4 stars when only experiencing a resturant once but the service here was impeccable. I was a virgin to Moroccan cuisine but thankfully to my brother, he chose this quaint little resturant for his boyfriends birthday which myself and a small group of friends attended.

Upon arrival, we were greeted and explained how all meals are pre fixed. Certain traditions were kept like washing hands before meals with rose scented water.  We were constantly checked on throughout dinner which is very important in my book. The belly dancer put on an amazing and engaging performance, pulling me and some of my friends to join in on the fun. Overall service was amazing. 

Next, the food. The menu consisted of specialty entrees like seafood platters, choices of meats like chicken, lamb and couscous, with soup, bread and an interesting chicken pastry for an appetizer. My friends and I chose to do the family meal option which allowed is to try a tasty variety of food. I really enjoyed the rabbit and the tender honey and almond Lamb really satisfied my palate. Overall good tasting food and a pleasant variety to choose from. 

Last is the ambience/atmosphere. I was very pleased to see that they stayed true to the Moroccan design. With very exotic decor, bright hues and detailed linens and light fixtures took me away on a faraway retreat. Linen Canopys hang above and the different designs and textured patterns pleased my eyes. For a moment, we all forgot we were in SF due to the beautiful surroundings. 

In conclusion, this little Moraccon treasure can be pricey but the overall experience was worth every penny. I would definitely visit this prized jewel again.
author: Eddison C.

description:
It is and interesting concept, very Mediterranean. The bellydancer was somewhat entertaining, but she was very stiff, I wouldn't rate the performance that high. It was nice that she interacted with guests. 

They definitely need to have additional help, when we entered we were not greeted and were forced to stand awkwardly at the entrance.
There was only one server, who was quite nice but even with the somewhat slow Thursday night he definitely could have checked in on us and brought out the wine/food a bit more promptly.

It seems as though it is a popular Birthday spot, as there were three other groups celebrating as well as our group.

The food was Ok, not that great but nothing too horrible, well...other than the scallops. 

I ordered the Mediterranian seafood Specialty, that came with prawns and scallops. There were about three decent prawns and four tiny scallops that tasted like they had been sitting in water. There was no taste or flavor to them and we'rent even seared properly. 

The traditional hand washing with the silver basin at the beginning and end was nice. 

All in all, if you are going for more of a special occasion/Mediterranean experience then it is fine but if you're a foodie-I would skip it.
author: Javi Alexa A.

description: Amazing performance and great food. The owner was nice enough to come out to greet us.
author: Eggie S.

description: Very fun place to go with small to large group of people. Food is so fresh and yummy. We ordered a bottle of white and red Moroccan wine and it was very good, and reasonably priced. The belly dancer was impressive and let's you dance with her. We were sceptical but it was a great dinner for celebrating a birthday. We had a memorable time and loved the food and staff!!! Also scored a close parking spot with little effort.
author: Maree D.

description:
We just finish to eat dinner at that place .
Love the marrocan food .
Nice belly denser and great place .
The price was ok .
author: Tom G.

description:
I been craving to see some good belly dancing and this is 1 of 2 places to watch and enjoy over some good food 


5* for exceptional service.  Plenty of attentive waiters.  Warm water to handwash with towel is great.  Rose water at the end the dinner.  

4* for the ambiance and belly dancer.  Nice decor and entertainment to boot.  I disliked the seating as it was extremely unconfortable.  The tables were low so you are basically eating on a elevated floor.  However the floor is small hard bench.  The decorative pillows help a bit. 

2* The food is not something to praise over.  Certainly the quanity is there but the quality lacks.  The price options are basically set at 36.50 and 38.50.  You pay whether you want the lentil soup, salad, basteya, dessert.  The food tastes like a buffet, a bit stale.  I ordered the rabbit for the first time and I have to warn you its very gamey.  However, I didnt mind it.  The sea bass is just sad.  It has the texture of a canned fish, soft, and over cooked.   It also comes out cold soaking in clay pot.   It does not have the texture of a firm flakey and fresh sea bass that one would expect.  The dessert is ok.  Nothing to rave about.

Other than having bugs bunny on the menu, I probably will not be visiting again.
author: S F.

description:
I came here a few months after coming back from a vacation in Morocco. I haven't been to any other Moroccan restaurants in the city so most of my comparisons are based on my memories from there. Overall, I had a great experience at this place and I would rate it 4.5/5 stars but I'm bumping it up to 5 because of the excellent service. 

The first thing that I noticed when I walked in was the décor. The restaurant is beautifully and colorfully designed. Everything about this place, including the patterns, textures, furniture, ornaments, and some of the silverware was very reminiscent of what I had experienced when I went to Morocco. The atmosphere was authentic and unique. There was a brief moment, upon entering, when I forgot that I was in San Francisco and felt like I was instantly transported to an exotic land thousands of miles away. 

The menu is pretty straightforward, you order an entrée or a special and it comes with all of the works. I went with my girlfriend and we ordered the fish tagine and the couscous with chicken and vegetables. 

They first brought out the soup with some bread. The soup reminded of the South Indian soup rasam, although it was not nearly as strong. I liked this soup better than the rasam because it was not overwhelming and I could taste the flavors more. The bread was good, but it wasn't the same kind of bread that I had in Morocco.

The next dish was the salad, which contained four separate portions of eggplant, carrots, cucumbers, and some sort of salsa looking thing that looked oddly similar to pico de gallo. The former three were delicious, varied, and flavorful. Unfortunately the latter one was disappointing - I'm not sure what they were trying to do there.

After the salad came the pastilla. My judgement here will be unfair because in Morocco I had a home cooked pastilla that would probably be almost impossible to beat. Nevertheless, the pastilla here was fine even though it did not have as much flavor as the one in Morocco.

Afterwards, we had our entrees. The couscous with chicken and vegetables was excellent although it was slightly too salty. The fish tagine was a little disappointing because the portions were small, there wasn't a lot of broth, and there wasn't really anything else there besides the fish itself. I also wish they brought it out in an actual tagine with the lid on, but that's probably just me being too pretentious about Moroccan food. Despite all that, everything tasted fantastic and was well cooked. 

The dessert was pretty good as well and consisted of fried bananas and some other thing. It was good, but didn't really stand out.

The last I had was the mint tea, which tasted very similar to what I remembered.  

Besides the amazing atmosphere and good food, the service was also on point. Everyone was kind, friendly, and quick to attend to our needs. There was also a belly dancer performing for everyone. She was entertaining and fun to watch.
author: George Z.

description:
My positives about the restaurant in the same order: Food, Ambience, Belly dancing show, service. The food was really unique and authentic. It is a go to place for vegetarians. Belly dancer was very talented, performed well and interacted with the customers. She taught some belly dancing moves and was really sweet about it. Ambience is really good. This place looks authentic but is still bright and cheerful. A great place for large group of people as the setting still feels very intimate - not like a long table where u only get to say a Hi and a Bye to people in a group. 

Negatives - The waiter spilled hot tea on my friends legs which was a burning experience. 

Overall, this place gets a thumps up from me.
author: Nidhi P.

description:
Great food
Great  atmosphere  
Very  relaxing  
Belly dancer...what  more could you ask

Mint tea  is incredible
author: Rodger R.

description: We loved the decor, food, and service in general and would definitely return. We were never asked if we wanted to order any drinks, only offered water, although later we saw guests drinking a variety of beverages.  It was a Sat. night, and they never mentioned if/when there would be a belly dancer.
author: Renee W.

description: Good food, entertaining dancers, great atmosphere, and the staff was accommodating for veggie eaters in our party.
author: V V.

description:
This was epic. 

The food was spectacular, the service impeccable, and the belly dancer was perfection. This was such an awesome night and we will definitely be back. 

Oh, just one thing, parents please don't bring your kids here. C'mon, seriously!
author: D. S.

description: Not as good as it once was.No longer run by Moroccan owner and staff.  No longer worth the splurge.
author: Mike I.

description:
Had a dinner date here yesterday and the food was great. I tried the seafood entree while my fiancé had the chicken and lamb dish combination. We shared each other's plate and we truly had nothing bad to say about each dish. 

The decor feels very authentic and the service was friendly. I would definitely come back and bring a group of friends here!
author: Sienna O.

description:
This review is rated R for strong sexual content and a slight chance of embarrassment.

Being a large birthday group, we did a mix-and-match of all the $37 prix fixe specialties at each table, which came with the standard accompaniments.   Everything tasted delicious and unique with nothing being generically found elsewhere.

Accompaniments:
- Harira Soup - Great for dipping with the bread.
- Salade Mohammed V - Diced marinated/pickled veggies - not just plain ol' lettuce.
- Bastela du Cheg - The baked chicken pastry was amazing, and the unexpected light dusting of powdered sugar on top was an interesting contrast to the savory pastry.  My favorite dish of the night.
- King Hassan & Keneffa - The banana fritter and sweet bastela were pretty good sweet treats after dinner even though I was stuffed.

Specialties:
- Moroccan Seafood - Big shrimps and scallops.
- Fish Tagine - The sea bass was braised rather than battered and fried.
- Chicken Kabob & Lamb Kabob - The lamb chunks were tender but gamey.  (I like gamey.)
- Almond Lamb - Bone-in lamb was tasty but gamey again.

The Birthday Girl and Mr. Popular Yelper (who shall remain nameless yet be immortalized in a scandalous picture on Yelp) got some nice sensual belly action, as the sexy belly dancer was very friendly, if you know what I mean.  The experience was fun for a group, as long as you don't have all partypoopers.  It's not a place you'd go repeatedly, but the good food and entertainment was worth the $60ish total price per person after wine and birthday bubbly.  Just don't take the girlfriend/wifey/date here on a date and say, "Hot damn, why don't you dance like that anymore?"
author: Kevin W.

description: My girlfriend took me here as a surprise for Valentine's day. I can't comment on the food because we were never seated. She had booked reservations for an 8:30pm time slot weeks in advance; however,  the restaurant severely overbooked. We arrived ten minutes early and waited over 40 minutes. Finally we approached the manager to let him know about our situation and that we were not satisfied. Unfortunately, he dismissed our concerns as unimportant. Any other night this would not have been a big deal, but this was a special night that we had anticipated for almost a month. I can understand chaotic situations in restaurants, but to be so unapologetic is inexcusable.  Not only were we livid about our treatment, our special night was ruined. I will not recommend this place for special events or any occasion.
author: Chase B.

description: Went for a friends birthday. We came in 30 mins late into the belly dance performance but got to see the last 30 mins of it. It was such a fun start! The food here is so flavorful and decadent. My friend and I hate lentils, which also includes lentil soup. When we tried the lentil soup from here, we completely changed the way we looked at lentils! It was one of the best soups I've tried. The servers were so nice and entertaining. The best thing about it was the way they served our tea, it was awesome! In addition, it was one of the best teas I've ever tried and authentic tasting. Great experience and great for birthday parties!
author: Judy C.

description: Price is not worth is. They don't sell hard alcohol and place seems a little dirty. Waiters were great though.
author: Yezi C.

description:
My sweetie and I had an early dinner here before going to a show. I can't say enough good things about our experience. The service was impeccable; the wait staff was gracious and helpful, and hoovered discreetly. Each course was delightful. I had the lamb with lemon and olives--butter tender, moist, and delicately flavored. My honey had the lamb and chicken--super tender and moist.
