Had the Casa Morrocan beer with dinner, and would definiteley recommend it. The prix fixe menu was very generous, a great value.

Overall a really fabulous experience. Though we live about an hour from the City, we're already planning regular visits!
author: Carrie C.

description: Terrible experience.  Ripped off. Belly dancer who really put the belly in belly dancing. Air was off and door closed.  I was sweating as was the dancer. Party of 10. We chose family service and they charged as if we all had a full meal. There was not but 3 platters for us to share. Left hungry. Horribly disappointed.  Complained upon getting the bill but they didn't care. We will never be back and hope to see this place boarded up the next time I drive by on my way to another establishment.
author: D A.

description:
3 stars for food, 5 stars for belly dancer (she was HOT!).

The food was just OK. I'm not a huge on Moroccan food, so my review for their food may be bias. I wasn't very comfortable sitting on those small seats either (esp being pregnant, I wasn't able to lean forward). We came in a group of about 15 and decided to get the prefix menu:

- Lentil soup: I normally dont care for lentil soup but they made it pretty well. Went well with their unlimited, warm, toasted bread
- Salad/dipping dish: Had a variety of different dipping sauces, one of which tasted like salsa. It also had eggplant and cucumbers. 
- Meat combo dish: Honey prune chicken, lamb, shrimp and scallop. My fav here was their chicken. It was soft, tender and ripped right off the bones.
- Chicken pot pie: On the sugary end, really only liked the crust.

The dancer was HOT (pictured). I've been to other Moroccan restaurants before where their belly dancers were not very pretty and in fact had some rolls on them (and when youre rolling with rolls, it just doesnt look that great if you know what I mean). The dancer we saw looked like a 6'1" tall model. She danced very gracefully even when balancing a sword on her head. 

Each person ended up having to pay like $70. It was an interesting experience but I don't think I'll be back.
author: Rosie W.

description: Huda and Jack are excellent hosts. Food is excellent, service is enthusiastic and cheerful without being intrusive, environment is authentic.
author: Moses M.

description: I have never been to a restaurant like this before.  The service was great.  The food was great.  The decor was great.  The belly dancer was great.  I don't hand out 5 stars lightly but they nailed it.  The only bad thing is that parking can be a challenge but that's to be expected in SF.
author: Eli F.

description: Great atmosphere and a fun date. Adil was very nice and worked the menu to accommodate my Gluten Allergy. Very good service.
author: Sean W.

description:
Ah, only if they had hookah! 

I enjoy eating here, a bit slow but delicious. Moroccan tea, lamb, belly dancers - I was smitten by Masha tonight!
author: Anelya S.

description: This was more of a splurge meal but definitely worth it. I came here for my birthday recently and I had a great time. The staff was welcoming and pleasant. The experience was loads of fun. There was a Moroccan hand washing ritual, belly dancing, and you eat with your hands (optional). Food was really good too. We got the family sampler which is based per person so no need to worry about not having enough food. Everything also came with appetizers and desserts. This was a great first impression on Moroccan food!
author: Fran P.

description:
When visiting SF, my friend's fiance who knows SF well suggested we go out to dinner here one night. This is not a restaurant I would have visited on my own but I was plesantly surprised with the food. 

They only serve prix fixed menus. I ordered the seabass and my boyfriend ordered a combination of chicken and lamb kabob. They start everyone off with a small bowl of lentil soup and a piece of bread. Then you get a three combo of salad served family style. I enjoyed the tomato based salsa like salad when eaten with their bread. Your last pre-entree course is this ground chicken pastry topped with powdered sugar. It sounds quite horrendous but it was surprisingly fantastic. Wish I could have had that all to myself as it is served family style as well.

My sea bass dish came out in a clay put drenched in a red sauce. Warning, it comes with the skin on which caught me by surprise. I also got a small bowl of couscous, although no vegetables unlike everyone else. The fish was not bad, probably one of the lighter options they had. And for dessert they give you a relatively cold sweetened mint tea, I don't like sweetened teas so I was not  fan, and fried banana fritters. Again, just okay.

I would have preferred the ambiance wasn't moroccan/circus like and that there weren't loud belly dancers every other hour so I could just focus on dinner with my friends and the food. But there were a few birthdays there that night so I guess some people actually enjoy it! 

(Also be prepared to spend 2 to 2.5 hours at dinner!)
author: Roxanne G.

description: I feared my rowdy group of 20 would be too much to handle for this place.  Nah!  The folks at El Mansour were all top notch.  1st - staff - they wanted nothing more but to keep you fed, comfortable and happy.  2nd - food - everyone could not stop eating and raving how yummy the food was.  3rd - ambiance - comfortable and exotic.  4th - entertainment - everyone enjoyed watching and participating.  Overall - come and enjoy the El Mansour.  To Jack and the rest of the staff at El Mansour - much thanks for all your hard work and helping me with my husband's surprise party.
author: Yvette H.

description: Great for a group party. Came here for a birthday celebration with some friends.  I'd recommend the family style. The menu can be confusing. Just ask the waiter to set you up.  The owner Jack is a nice man and likes to tell you stories about the history of the restaurant.  A++
author: Yayuan S.

description:
Pros : I ordered their chicken and lamb and it was very flavorful. It was fun to sit in traditional style and the way they bring the stuff to wash your hands. The banana dessert was very yummy. 

Cons : we had a Asian man waiter who was beyond rude and refused to let us only order one item. My fiancé had a large lunch and was not very hungry, and we always share our food in general. The man charged us for 2 although we only ordered one dish. The soup and salad was okay. I
author: Girl M.

description:
It was my first time to have Moroccan food and it was not bad.  

The restaurant is small but inside is so unique.  Great ambiance.  Perfect place for a date and fun for a group.  Their highlight of the restaurant is the belly dancing.  The dancing is about 30 minutes long.  Try not to miss it because the dancer is pretty, sexy and hot.  You can even have a chance to dance with her...pretty fun.  

The service was great.  It was kinda slow because he was the only waiter for the night.  

My friend and I got the specialty from the menu.  It was $36.50 and you can pick one meat selection and included salad, dessert, etc.  

Here are what we had:

Moroccan Seafood (Prawns and scallops) - It was ok.  The seafood was tasty especially the prawns.  

Chicken Kabob - It was good.  The chicken was tender and juicy.

Harira Soup (Spicy Lentil Bean Soup) - The soup was not too spicy but it was flavorful.  Good for dipping with the bread.  

Salade Mohammed V (Combination of Tomatoes, eggplant, carrots & cucumbers) - It was ok, nothing special.  It was just dipping sauce for the bread.  

Bastela du Chef (Pastry filled with chicken, almonds, and assortment of spices) - This was my favorite dish of the night.  It was like chicken pot pie and tasted very good.  The chicken inside was flavorful and I especially like the powder sugar outside.  Very unique and interesting pastry.

King Hassan (Banana Fritter) - It was good, not too sweet.  Perfect portion after a pretty big meal

The A La Menthe (Mint Tea) - It was tasty.  Very refreshing.  

Overall, I had a great time here.  The food was good, belly dancing was fun, unique decor and great service.  Just FYI...be sure you are not in rush because my dinner was about 2 hour and 15 minutes long.
author: Liza T.

description: The ambiance is good and the belly dancer was awesome! Will definitely recommend this place and will plan to go back too
author: Anubhuti C.

description:
My husband and I enjoyed a nice evening here with tasty foods and pretty good entertainment for the price $$$. 
LOVE THE FOOD!!! Belly dancing is also pretty cool, so do bring some cash to tip the dancers!
author: Natalya V.

description: This place is a perfect place for yummy food and great entertainment. The lamb was delicious and the salad was great. The belly dancing was awesome. I would recommend this place if you want to have a great time with a group and enjoy nice evening with amazing food and great ambience. Overall go enjoy the moroccan cuisine.
author: Dinakar R.

description: This place is amazing. You walk inside and feel like your in another country. It is such a fun atmosphere, not to mention the food. We had their fresh made bread with lentil soup with a few courses in between followed by scallops and prawns. Nothing but good things to say!
author: Francesca P.

description: Went for a team building event for work. This place is such a delight. The food and service were fantastic. Wish they had a better wine list, but that is my only complaint.
author: Chili W.

description: The food was DELICIOUS and the staff there was so kind and professional. I highly recommend this place if you want to eat great food, have a fun time, and feel like you're being transported to another country. All in all great vibes and tasty food!
author: Sunny D.

description:
I'm not sure why this place is rated four stars instead of five.  We came on a Friday night,  reservations for six.  The place was pretty empty at 7:30. I was a little scared at first since it wasn't busy.  But oh my gawd, I'm so glad we came here.  This place deserves five stars for the all around experience.  The decorations and layout were very cute, the food was delicious,  The wine selection cost was reasonable,  the food and service was outstanding-thanks Yanni!

Our server recommended we do family style which I recommend for larger groups. All meals come with lentil soup, salad, bastela du chef, banana fritter and keneffa, and mint tea.  Our entrees were such a party for my taste buds. I really wish we could have this restaurant in Austin.  There are many places that try to do Moroccan and really is the best.  

Oh and I almost forgot to mention they have belly dancing too!  

You should visit this little gem!
author: Jessica E.

description: This was a pleasant totally new eating experience.  After our rental car got broken in, and my wife lost her handbag with all her belonging this restaurant restored our faith in San Francisco.  At the beginning I thought the restaurant prices were too high, but they deliver a lot for the money. It was a six course meal, and every dish was a pleasant discovery. I had the lentil soup, the Moroccan seafood  which contained huge shrimps and scallops with couscous,  salad, some huge chicken pie . This pie was different because it was salty with a sweet crust that gave it a new twist to my taste buds. At the end dessert and mint tea were served by our friendly waiter in a particular way. There was also a belly dancing show as part of this culinary experience.  We were invited to dance and managed to do it with the dancers help. Conclusion : extraordinary experience worth the money.
author: Benigno P.

description:
We recently celebrated my high school bestie's 40th birthday with a girls' night out to Marrakech. We were treated to an opulent Moroccan meal as we sat on cushions.  I ordered Chicken with Lemon and Olives but had already enjoyed the rich Harira soup and the much-loved Bastela du Chef, not to mention several slices of freshly baked bread.  (Oh thank you, epic weight loss for allowing me to enjoy such enormous meals without too much guilt.)  By the time the beautiful desserts arrived, post-birthday cake, I could not eat another bite.  

We cheered on the birthday girl as she and several other patrons joined the belly dancer. The dancer was supermodel statuesque and had a sense of fun.   Bear in mind she is a professional dancer, not a stripper, so she would shimmy away from folks trying to stuff tips into her costume and/or require that they do some dancing first.  

Service was great.  The birthday girl was quite late(as is sort of a running joke) but this presented no problems for the staff.  

I'm budget-conscious these days so I can't foresee heading all the way out to the Richmond just for dinner. However this is a  great spot for a special occasion and worth the drive/expense.
author: Julie C.

description: Sooo much fun.  Hubby took me here for my birthday.  At first I was afraid that it would be all about the belly dancing and not about the food, but boy was I wrong.  The food was amazing AND the dancing was very cool (Although seriously people, I'm not sure you're supposed to put dollars in the girl's dress?  They are belly dancers not lap dancers, but maybe I'm wrong).  I had a lamb and eggplant dish that was incredibly tender - fall of the bone wow tender.  They bring bread around to eat the soup and salad in it was so good.  The atmosphere is very fun too, soft couches you can sink in to after a few glasses of wine.  Wow, I'm looking forward to going back.
author: Greta R.

description:
Superb and De-li-cious!!!

Came here for my birthday celebration and OMG I love this place! The food, the decor, the staff, the entertainment... all 5 stars in my eyes. BTW - I've never had Moroccan food before and now, I'm a fan!

Booked a table for 7 girls for a once a year birthday extravaganza and the staff were so accommodating from start to finish. They made sure we were satisfied and entertained throughout our 5 course dinner. We decided to do the individual plates so we could all try different dishes and we were beyond stuffed.

5 Course (sorry the list is long!)
Starter: Spicy Lentil Bean Soup w/ bread - Amazing, tastes like a healthy version of a chili, totally scrumptious. 

Salad: Moroccan salad including tomatoes, eggplant, carrots & cucumbers - Get your veggies in! The vegetables were lightly marinated and crunchy. I can eat this forever.

Appetizer: Bastela du Chef (Pastry filled with chicken, almonds, and assortment of spices) - Genius!! Omg this dish is sweet, savory, and crunchy. Must try! 

Specialty Entree: Rabbit Kabob - Big portion, I believe I got two huge rabbit legs but I was not complaining because the rabbit by far was tender and perfectly marinated. Tastes like a leaner chicken but better :-)
  
Dessert: King Hassan (Banana Fritter), Keneffa (Sweet Bastela with Cream and Almonds) - Cleanse your palate but also leaving you totally stuffed. The fritters were mouthwatering - can not put into words how amazingly delicious it was!

Tea: The A La Menthe (Mint Tea) - Wow, if you're a Boba tea lover... man-o-man, you are in for a treat. This tea is sooo good, you'll have to ask for more -- which they will refill for you!

Bottle service: I decided to bring my own bottles of wine since the corkage fee was not bad and the staff were so accommodating about it.  

Decor: You are transformed into Morocco. Trust me.

Belly Dancer: Gorgeous! we came on a perfect Saturday night! Not only was the dancer beautiful but oh so sweet. She was trying to get everyone outta their seat to dance -- of course we were quite a shy crowd. 

Price: A little more than $38 per person because of the wine, tax, and gratuity. Totally understandable. I would bring about $50-60. 

Overall, don't be fool by reading mixed reviews on yelp, check it out for yourself. You will be amazed like I was! Definitely recommending this for everyone. 

Thank you to the staff for being so welcoming and personable! A great place for any occasion!
author: Julia K.

description:
Great ambience, terrific entertainment and fantastic mint tea.  This is a pretty vegetarian friendly restaurant - but definitely on the "pricey" side - unless you take into account the entertainment (the bellydancer isn't just working for tips, I hope!).

Unfortunately, some of the dishes are not vegan - like the bastela - but most of the other items are vegan.  Great service and delicious food.  Combine this with an afternoon at the Legion of Honor, a sunset hike along the path above the mouth of the Golden Gate, then walk back on Lincoln (unless you brought a flashlight!) for dinner and a show at El Mansour.  Always call ahead to find out the schedule for bellydance performances and try to get there at least 30 minutes ahead of time so you can get your food ordered and start enjoying it before the dancer takes the floor.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I was clearly disappointed by their service when we were there for dinner on a Saturday. Firstly they want to pack as many people as possible in a tiny space. The service was fast but they also want to get you out fast  so that they can pull in more customers. I was also surprised that this place is run by some Asian/Chinese and not Moroccan. The people who run this place don't know how to create a good atmosphere for customers to enjoy the good Moroccan food.
The food here is not cheap. With an average tab of $50 each I think the customers should expect more and also get more. Even if I am in the neighborhood I will not  go back again. 
Lastly the belly dance performance they have at 7.30pm on the weekend was not bad.
author: Raman S.

description:
FOOD: Pretty good, I'd say.  It's easy to think everything is absolutely delicious when you wait twenty minutes between courses, though, so I hope it's real.  I was ready to eat the lap towel I was so hungry.  Seriously, though, we didn't understand the lag.  

It was a nice change to eat with my hands.  Who needs a fork when you get your hands washed at the table, you get a baby blue dish towel to wipe them on, wipe your mouth with, clean out the food particles from underneath your nails with...it's GREAT!

AMBIANCE: Sexy!  Golds, maroons, purples, rich, dark.  But it's also a family place.  I think four times this night, some strange Disney-come-Morocco "Happy Birthday" song came on, along with a candle and something on a plate.  So, think about a couple smootching in the corner, but with grandpa and grandma smiling from ear-to-ear, happy to be out and about on a Saturday night right next to them.  Epic stuff, right there.

SERVICE: Slooooooooooowwww, but always with a smile, so you can't even be mad at that.  

BELLIES: There was only one (I have no idea if there's ever more than one) and she was pretty hawt.  Great smile, amazing dance moves.  She also got lots of different types of people to dance with her: young, old, male, female, married, single, everyone was up for grabs.

Heh heh, get it?
author: Tamar D.

description:
this was my third time eating at El Mansour, but my first check-in / review since the first 2 times were before the existence of Yelp (gasp - i'm old).
overall, El Mansour is a great dining experience. the food is relatively good and authentic, there is belly dancing, and the decor takes you away to south of gibraltar. for the belly dancing, my first time eating here the dancer was not very good nor attractive, which made the experience a bit awkward. this last time at El Mansour we had a very attractive and friendly dancer who was also quite good at dancing - that's a win / win / win in my book. 
if you are looking for a complete dining experience and want to be transported to lands far far away, El Mansour is a solid recommend.
author: Xander C.

description: We went out of our way to try to experience a Moroccan restaurant and choose to go here. Except for the belly dancer act and the tent like decor, the food is not good. First and foremost it's just a plain tourist trap. The menu has no flexibility and the cost per person is unreasonable. One point I must stress is that it's not clean and the floors are filthy. I don't recommend at all.
author: Keith D.

description:
Head waiter = very nice. However, we arrived with a large group and a reservation for a birthday and were made to wait for at least 20 min before they sat us; they left smaller groups sitting in the larger corners rather than initially sitting them up front so they could accommodate us appropriately.

When we asked about it the manager responded, "but is your entire party here?" no, but we are a party that made a large group reservation and we are about to drop major money with you for a birthday so ...? don't you want to treat us right?

so they seated us late, and in a cramped area too small for our group. when the other smaller party left we uprooted to finally go sit in the original area we should have been in. all of this hoopla means we began dinner late - so we ended up staying way later than we intended and staff were literally shutting up the place and leaving but the head wait, who was cute, was super nice and patient and understood  and was super kind about us finishing at our leisure.

belly dancer does the sword dancing, which you don't always get to see, so that's neat.

food was okay, not enough for me to return again.

place is actually pretty tiny, but is nicely decorated. i really wanted to steal one of the tables, alas they are too big. but fine, handmade craftswork.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Overall AWESOME.

Amazing food. Pre fixe multi course meal- everything was so good (without ending up overly stuffed at the end). Also, nice that you just have to choose the main course.

We loved El Mansour for a great brainless Friday night date. You get to sit on comfy couch-like seats (with towels in your lap) in a nice dimly lit room while someone serves you course after course of delicious comfort food, delicious wine and mint tea. Yes please. The service was amazing too. Anytime we needed something, the servers had it there instantly. 

Lots of nice touches that push it to a 5, like they wash your hands at the table before and after the mean and belly dancer was fun too.
author: K A.

description: I've gone here several times and have  been comfortable, well fed, entertained and impressed every time. Can't wait until my next visit! The pastilla is my favorite.
author: Angie N.

description:
Dinner at El Mansour is such a fun experience. When we first walked into El Mansour, we felt like we were in a totally different city. The colorful fabrics and unique tile-work surrounding the entryway definitely left a great first impression. The ambiance is cozy with dim lighting and music playing throughout the night. 

The menu is divided into "Specialties" ($36.50) and "Entrees" ($34.50). The specialties include cous cous and vegetables, but the rest of the sides are the same. I ordered the chicken with honey and prunes, and my boyfriend got the seafood special with shrimp and scallops.

The entire meal took around 2 hours, with a total of five courses. We ate with our hands the entire night, which was pretty amusing. Our server came by often throughout the night with a huge plate of warm, fluffy bread, which we totally used as our utensils. My favorite part of the meal was the Bastela du Chef. Flaky phyllo dough with chicken and almond filling, with powdered sugar sprinkled on top...yum! I am a huge fan of sweet and savory, so this was an A+.  

The rest of the food was delicious and well prepared. The chicken was tender and moist, and I loved the flavors of the honey and prunes. (again with the sweet and savory!). My boyfriend's shrimp and scallops were cooked perfectly, and I kept sneaking bites from his plate. However, I wasn't a huge fan of the fried bananas as the dessert. They were a little too mushy for me. 

We also loved our waiter. He was amazingly attentive and he truly made our dining experience special. The belly dancer was entertaining and definitely a highlight of the night. 

Overall, I definitely recommend this place if you want a lively dining experience. I wouldn't say the food is extraordinary, but its delicious nonetheless and the service is wonderful. It seems like it would be fun to celebrate a special occasion here because of the awesome atmosphere!
author: Vanessa C.

description:
This place gets an additional star because of the fun belly dancing and nice, casual environment for a large group.

The food, however, was just simply not good. The standout---not in a good way---was the lamb. It was a cheap cut and literally bathed in oil. The accompanying eggplant also was oily, and was just a mushy mess. Other dishes also badly missed the mark.

I wanted to like this place more. But with so many other Middle Eastern options in the city, I'm not going to lug myself out to the Outer Richmond for this place any time soon.
author: Paul K.

description:
So my lover brought me here and all I can say is that it was simply marvelous! 

The food, the atmosphere, the service and of course the pillows were all lovely! Overall it's a different experience but an enjoyable one. 

TL:DR: The food just kept coming and I just kept eating.

We had the 5 course meal on the left of the menu with the kebabs. They were as follows:

Lentil Soup: It was good, it tastes almost identical to the one mother makes. If only she knew I was paying $15 for this soup with homemade bread.
The Salad: The flavors all come together very nicely! My boyfriend had to explain what each sauce was but I devoured everything.
The Bastila: I was not a huge fan to be honest. I'm not someone who likes mixing my sweets with the salties. I guess the combination of both the chicken and the powdered sugar with drizzled chocolate caused confusion in my mouth? However, our waiter did say it was pretty popular? I might be a weirdo? 
The Lamb & Chicken: SO GOOD! The chicken and lamb filled my mouth with SO MUCH TENDERNESS! I did not expect that at all. Very rich in flavor as well.
Dessert: Absolutely delightful! Not too sweet, the crunchy exterior with the soft gooey hot banana made me feel all tingly inside.
Mint Tea: The perfect ending to the meal, you sit there in utter comfort and bliss, sipping your tea, admiring the view...smelling yourself because you have just been blessed with rose water...

I like how La Mansour spaces your dinner accordingly so that by the end of your meal you aren't left with a bloated stomach. 

In the end, it's not that pricey if you put it in perspective, all this would cost you about the same if you ordered appetizer, entree and dessert at any other restaurant.
author: Jenna D.

description:
Not only is this place super awesome looking inside and out (some might call the arched doorways, Moorish tiles, pillows and draped sheets cheesy, I call it authentic!) but the food is top notch. Went here on a random Tuesday for a late dinner so it was pretty much just us and another 2 people in the entire place making it cozy and intimate.

The service was very attentive and entertaining - this man poured our tea from about 4 feet up just for wow factor (and luckily spilling only a little). I enjoyed the little details that made this place stand out for me - at the start of the meal they wash your hands in a Moroccan handwashing tass and from there you eat the whole meal with your hands. 

The four course meal is definitely the way to go - the starting lentil soup is hearty and full of flavor, the salad is alright, and the pastilla (meat pie) is phenomenal! I admit my tastebuds were a little confused to be tasting chicken and powdered sugar (what? who thought of that one?) in the same bite but somehow it worked. For the entree my date got the lamb with honey & almonds (again, the sweet and savory factor was a little weird here for me but it wasn't bad) and I tried the rabbit with grilled vegetables. The rabbit was great, not dry at all like I was dreading it to be. Finishing up with the King Hassan (banana fritter) was great as it was perfectly carmelized.

This place is definitely in a random ass part of town but worth it if you find yourself in the depths of the Richmond and want a memorable dining experience.
author: Tiffany F.

description:
Do you want to be whisked away to a different world?  Are you ready for an adventure that encompasses a night of belly dancing, good food, and good company?  Look no further - join your friends and family at El Mansour.  You will be entertained by a beautiful belly dancer and fun waiters.  The food is delicious too!

FIVE STARS for the wonderful belly dancer!  Not only was she beautiful but she also has plenty of talent.  The woman can dance while balancing objects on her head!  At one point she danced while balancing a cane on her head.  Later in the evening, she danced while balancing a vase on her head!  Truly amazing! :)

El Mansour provides a fun atmosphere and a simple menu.  There are two set menus that are reasonably priced: $34.75 (for the specialties menu) or $31.75 (for the entrees menu).

My friend and I ordered from the Specialties menu.  Dishes and comments below:

**Starters**
(1) Harira Soup(Spicy Lentil Bean Soup)
Yummy - they serve this with their soft but densely packed house-made bread.  Moroccans take pride in their bread - you will not be disappointed.

(2) Salade Mohammed V (Combination of Tomatoes, eggplant, carrots & cucumbers)
This refreshing dish is filled with light spices and perfectly cooked veggies.

**Mid-course**
(3) Bastela du Chef (Pastry filled with chicken, almonds, and assortment of spices)
Chicken and all of the above encased in a light and crispy filo dough with powdered sugar on top.  This is pretty good but I've had better elsewhere (in Morocco).  The Bastela is one of the better known dishes in Moroccan cuisine.  Had this dish blown me away, I would have given El Mansour 5 stars.  Yeah, I know, I am a tough judge. :)

**Main Course**
(4a) Moroccan Seafood (Prawns and scallops)
If not prepared well, prawns can taste very plain and overcooked.  It is certainly NOT the case at El Mansour!  Succulent and juicy prawns and scallops with just the right amount of sauce.

(4b) Lamb & Chicken (with almonds)
The lamb meat falls off the bone - yeah, it is THAT tender!  Prompts to the chef for this dish.  Lamb meat can taste very gamey but not the lamb meat in this dish!  The chicken is very tender too.

The main courses come with Couscous and Vegetables, which are absolutely delicious! Wish I can make couscous taste this good.

**Dessert**
(5) King Hassan (Banana Fritter), Keneffa (Sweet Bastela with Cream and Almonds)
Nice and light dessert to complete the dining experience.

**Moroccan Mint Tea**
(6) The A La Menthe (Mint Tea)
It is quite an experience to watch how tea is poured into glasses in Morocco.  El Mansour has replicated that art right here in San Francisco.  The mint tea is really good too.

If I ever want to entertain a group of people, I will definitely bring them here for dinner.  This place is super reasonably priced for the quality of food and entertainment experience.  Thank you El Mansour for providing such a fun dinner venue.  I'm a BIG fan!
author: MyGirl L.

description:
I came here for my friends birthday dinner. The lentil soup was very good.  I liked the combination salad because it had a lot of different flavors all on one plate. I was surprised with the pastry filled with chicken. It seemed like a dessert right in the middle of the meal because it was sweet. I had the lamb with onions and olives. The lamb was super tender and full of flavor. The olives were kind of salty. The pouring of the mint tea was really cool. They pour the tea from above their head into glasses on the table. I got really full because you eat everything with bread. The fried banana dessert was just ok.  

The belly dance show was pretty good. It was fun watching other people dancing with the belly dancer. 

I like the interior decorations. Its totally different than any other restaurant I have been to. There is fabric on the ceiling that makes you feel like you're in a tent. The tables were kind of low. My knees were above the table top.
author: Alexander L.

description: Came here with girlfriends to celebrate a birthday and what a fun night. The decor and ambiance is really special. Service terrific and attentive. The bellydancer was fun, talented and what a nice person. The food though was phenomenal. Fresh, delicious and each dish was a feast for the senses. Loved the mint tea service and rose water sprinkled on our hands.I was still smelling the soft scent hours later and remembering the fun evening. Love to do this again one night. Wonderful and memorable! Lovely people. El Mansour does not disappoint!
author: K W.

description: I have been to El Mansour many times over the years, and always enjoyed it. It is decorated to give the impression of being in a big Middle Eastern tent, the servers are dressed appropriately, and there is belly dancing (if you are not a fan, make an early reservation, since the belly dancing starts around 7:30). All entrees come with the same (lovely) appetizers, including a lentil soup, and a savory chicken pastry. Of the entrees I've tried, I favor the lamb with lemon and olives, and the chicken with honey and prunes. The wine list is just okay, so you may opt to bring your own, and pay the corkage fee.
author: Jethro B.

description: As soon as we get to the city, we run to El Monsour. Kind of off the beaten track but so beautiful, so authentic and the people are wonderful, the service is so kind and the food is just fabulous. The dancing, the kindness, the deliciousness. It just happens so rarely.
author: Garth G.

description:
This is the first time I came here, intrigued by the fact that a belly dancer would perform while you eat! 

There are two shows that go on in the evening, 7:15 and 9ish. Even with reservations, be prepared to wait half an hour or more. Since I had come here on an occasion to meet with old friends, it didn't matter to me, but did concern other there since it was a bit chilly outside. 

The decor is something special, curtains and vibrant colors; it really tries to be a unique Moroccan experience. The seats are stumps and a comfy couch that runs along the walls accompanied by a low round table to eat on. Seriously, there were details down to the small tiles that ran along the hallway to the bathroom (which I actually think looked like chess pieces, what can I say, I had a little to drink). The waiters are dressed the part as well. The belly dancer was gorgeous wearing a jeweled costume and had moves. She would interact with you and try to get you to come up to dance with her, which is hilarious since belly dancing is quite a talent. (I'll post a picture).

The place is great for groups, the meals are usually served in a family size of about 4. The food is pricey, I'll admit that. I really have no idea what the names are of the things I've eaten, couscous, lamb, shrimp, some kind thing that had powdered sugar, etc. but all I need to say is that it was so surprisingly good that I didn't mind the cost. Definitely a must try once (or more) in your lifetime. 

The delicious mush of food is meant to be dug into with your hands!  Unsanitary? not entirely.. someone will come around to do a sort of hand washing ceremony with a tea kettle AT your table before and after you eat (second time with fragrant rose water), so you KNOW your neighbor about to dig into YOUR food has "washed" his hands. Be warned, since food is pricey and this place is so unique, about every 15 minutes, the birthday tune would come on for 9 out of 10 groups present. Man oh man, was a bunch of people born that day... 

Totally would recommend this as a surprise event for a group of people like a birthday or graduation or some sort. I just wouldn't bring really young kids since the belly dancer is only clothed so much. If you mind that kind of thing. But the food is still awesome! Just bring blindfolds.....
author: Angela L.

description:
Took the girl here for her birthday.  The other guests must have had the same idea since at least 5 different groups were celebrating birthdays as well.

Judging purely their food, they were ok.  Some good meals, some ok meals, nothing horrible, but nothing I was craving the next day either.  However, as an experience, it's truly unique.  First, the dancer was amazing.  We hung out there for a while so we saw her come out twice, but the first time I don't think either of us took a bite during her entire performance.  

The staff was very friendly, although pretty slow.  Give yourself a couple hours, sit back and enjoy.  Plus, you get to eat with your hands!
author: Denis S.

description:
Not a bad gig.  The belly dancing was cool.  The chick was attractive, approachable with an easy smile & that's all good.  the food was delicious.  We ordered a few items off the Specialties List:  lamb & chicken kabob, fish & bastela du chef.  Service was fine.  The server was friendly.  
Corkage fee was $15.  We had heard their wine list was so-so hence we brought out own bottle.  Good thing we did because their wine list consisted of overpriced mediocre wines.  
We also had a Restaurant.com coupon for $25 off but was told that does not apply on Saturdays.  It doesn't say that on the coupon but it's fine.  Don't sweat the small stuff...
Overall, it was relaxing, entertaining & fun.
author: Michael L.

description:
I absolutely LOVED this place. The food was great, the service was attentive and friendly, the bellydancer was beautiful and entertaining. Overall it was a fantastic night.

I loved the pace of the courses. The servers didn't try to rush us they were really good about getting the food out when we wanted and letting us eat more slowly through a few of the courses. 

Honestly there weren't many things that I disliked. I wasn't a fan of the Salade Mohammed V, but that was solely because I don't care for pretty much any of the ingredients. 

The Harira Soup was a fantastic way to start the meal. It was flavorful and warm which was appreciated on such a cool summer night. 

The Bastela du Chef was surprising to me. I'd never had it before and was a bit confused by the cinnamon and powdered sugar on top of what the server had said was a pastry with chicken and almond filling. But it was great. The pastry was flaky, the filling was yummy and it surprisingly worked great with the sugar and cinnamon. 
 
The meal ended with a banana fritter that was great. Nice and warm with a great fried dough. It was just enough sweet without being to much to end the big meal. It was served with a mint tea that I also enjoyed. Sweet and minty and warm before we headed back out to the cold. 

There were three people in our party so we chose to dine 'family style' so we could try the different specials instead of getting stuck with just one. It was a great idea because some of the best things I wouldn't have ordered on their own. The kabobs we delicious especially the lamb. Lots of spice and very tender. I was originally planning to get the Moroccan Seafood platter and while I wouldn't have been terribly disappointed with that choice it definitely wasn't my favorite. The scallops were great but the prawns weren't anything special. The almond lamb ended up being one of my favorites. Another in our party didn't like it and mentioned she thought it was a bit dry. The piece I tried though was incredibly juicy and falling off the bone. 

The entire night was fun and definitely made for some great memories. 

A few things to keep in mind:
if you get a soda, the refills are NOT free!
It's far from downtown and finding a cab is next to impossible (drive!!!)
It's really easy to miss if you're not sure where it is so use GPS and look for the big blue door.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Wow the deco of this place is awesome as soon at you get to the outside door you can see the middle eastern influence. The walls are tiled with a big door. Inside is small but it can hold alot of people. I came here with about a party of 15 or so and they welcomed everyone in because we all came at different times.

I got the Seafood (Shrimp and Scallop). It was too salty for my liking but at the same time it was my 1st time trying Morrocan food. I enjoyed all of the other veggie dishes. And the Bread was the best!!! My bf got the Rabbit Kabob. He really enjoyed it and said it serious just taste like chicken and it seriously look just like chicken. I tried it and I wished I got this dish inside of mine. Also since I am Asian I wish they had rice with their dishes (balsamic or brown, any rice would work). 

Belly dancing starts at 9pm-10pm. She was great and sexy!!... Make sure you tip her and dance with her. Also at the end of the night they brought my friend a big big dish of deserts and we got to sing happy birthday to her...

Def. will be going back!

$35 for speciality meals and $31 for the other meals (simply menu)
Make sure you try the Casa beer.. Tastes like cider.
author: Rany M.

description: Really good food, and the music and dancing makes for a fun environment.
author: Julia H.

description: Wonderful experience here!  The food is spectacular, the service is warm and helpful, and the belly dancing is a lot of fun!  I've been dreaming of their honey and almond lamb and rabbit stew ever since!  Can't wait to be back!
author: Chelsea D.

description: Belly dancing, great service, fantastic atmosphere, and good food. Yay! I'm a fan is the right classification for this. Weekdays are pretty empty so give it a shot then to try it out. The menu is fixed, but they offer a decent variety of stuff to give a nice overall experience. The chicken and lamb kabobs were really good. Also seems like a really fun place to host a party - this restaurant has a lot going for it.
author: Ali H.

description:
Al Mansour balances kitsch and authenticity, and dining here is a recommended experience.  The decor is quite fabulous--right out of Arabian Nights--with low tables, tent-like walls, and draped ceilings.

The menu isn't terribly diverse--coucous, lamb and chicken with some combination of lemon, olives, honey, almonds or onions make up the lion share of the menu.

Dining at El Mansour is a leisurely experience. First comes a server with a kettle of heated water to pour over your hands for cleansing. Then soup with no utensils--soak it up with bread or lift the bowl to your lips. Then comes a family-style salad, which I found a bit difficult to eat without utensils.  Next comes the entrée, at which point our party gave up and opted for utensils.  Desert is included in the meal.

We found the food very tasty.  The lamb and chicken were delicious and very tender, falling off the bone.  

The experience is enhanced with a belly dancer performing once an hour.  She was pretty amazing and interacted well with the diners, but I had two complaints:  First, during her 15-minute extended dance the music was  almost painfully loud. Secondly, the final song involves people tucking dollar bills into her bedazzled bra or revealing harem pants; perhaps this is a tradition in Morocco but it felt a bit too strip-club for the family restaurant.
author: Augie R.

description:
I have been here a few times.  This last time I went I brought a few friends from out of time.  There food was good - but noting amazing - especially in light of the prices.  It was a bit expensive - but you did get a lot of food. It would be nice to have a larger menu with some smaller options if you weren't as hungry but still wanted to enjoy the experience. 

The belly dancer was great and engaging. 

Overall it was okay but I have been to other comparable places that I enjoyed more.
author: Chandra P.

description:
According to Yelp, there are currently 8 restaurants in San Francisco that serve Moroccan food--only 5 of them feature Moroccan cuisine exclusively. 

El Mansour is the only one of these 5 restaurants that I've been to (twice), and furthermore the only Moroccan food I've ever eaten. So right off the bat, I wasn't sure exactly how I should rate it, since I don't really have any other experiences with Moroccan food to compare it to. 

So being the Yelp dork I am, I did a lil research...

Unlike some of its competitors in the city (which serve items ala carte), El Mansour ONLY offers complete dinners, which I've gathered in Moroccan terms means a lavish, leisurely 5-course meal. Price-wise, here's how it matches up with the other restaurants that also do it this way: 

El Mansour: 5-course meal, $28.75 / $30.75
Radio Africa & Kitchen: 4-course meal, $40 (not exclusively Moroccan)
Aziza: 4-course meal, $50
Pasha: for parties of 6 or more ("family style" meal), $35 / $49
Marrakech: "full dinner," $34.95

So comparatively, El Mansour's prices for the complete dinner are by far the most reasonable. 

Still, even at their rates going here last weekend for my friend's birthday was not exactly a CHEAP experience for me. But with that said, we all know that price ain't the only thang that makes a place what it is, and all around I've really enjoyed my experiences at El Mansour. It's given me a great impression of Moroccan food (chicken bastilla! yum!) and an appreciation for its showy presentation--ie, feeling like you're sitting in Genie's lamp, handwashing with rose water at the table, eating with the hands, the grandiose pouring of the mint tea at the end of the meal, etc. The location of the restaurant is also good for people who have cars (plenty of parking that far down on Clement and Geary) or those who live in the Western neighborhoods. Just be prepared, if you have a large party (which is the way to go here), to drop at least 40 bucks on dinner.

Oh yeah, the only thing we felt could have used some work in the presentation was the belly dancer... it's not that she was bad, but after her short performance she walked out the front door with her rolling suitcase and regular clothes! Yeah, yeah, I know she's just a normal person, but come on, it ruins the magic just a little...
author: Kate V.

description:
Took me many months to finally write a review about this restaurant. Decided to come here with a friend because of the $50 off coupon that i got from restaurant.com. Although you get $50 dollar off, it was still expensive but it was worth it. When you walk into this restaurant, it looks like you are in another world. the decor here/table setting are different from most restaurant. There are 4 section of seating areas. The cushion seating chair are connect to the wall more like a lounge u sharp with few tables. Each tables has a candle which makes it more a romantic feeling. And it has a color clothes  and lights hanging on the sealing wall above. Their floor are actually carpet.  

You get about 5 course meal, tea, and a free belly dance show while eating your meal. If you want to see the belly dancer, you have to call ahead of time so you'll know what time they are dancing. Its entertaining to see the belly dancer while you are enjoying your food. You can also dance with the belly dancers when she comes to your table. The dancer of the night i went was a really good dancer.

Its cool how you get your tea. The waiter comes to your table with teapot and then start pouring the tea to your cup while holding the teapot as high from his crest area. The tea is warm and sweet.

Before you start eating your dinner, the waiter wash your hands for you with warm water and then gives you a towel to dry your hands.

1. First course is spicy lentil bean soup. You can eat it with bread if you want too. I like this soup a lot since it has the hearty flavor. 
2. Second course is the salad. This dish i believe you eat with your hands. But you do have breads to help you pick up the vegetables. This dish is also tasty
3. Bastela du chef: it has this powder on the outside which make this dish very sweet. It has great flavor, soft and textures of the bread from the chicken, almonds, and spices.
4. My main course was lamb & brochette kabob with vegetables. By this time you start to get full from all the appetizer you had. During the main course, you have an option to eat it with your hands or with utensils. My friends and i decided to eat with our hands. It has a lot of flavors from the spices and other sauces that they put into this dish. This dish is not quite big but it was still delicious. You can eat it woth bread too to dip in the sauce. After this i think you wash your hands again. 
5. Lastly its the dessert. Its the king hassan which is the banana fritter and keneffa which is the sweet bastela with cream and almonds. Their dessert was so yummy. Its sweet and flaky especially from the taste that they add to the dessert.
author: Julie N.

description: Visiting San Francisco the labor day weekend. Food was great. Service was empecable Adil was AWESOME.
author: Mesha M.

description:
I love this place!! Come here and get transported. It's a dinning experience of another kind. 

Entertainment. A belly dancer girl glides around the restaurant.  I found it very fun and entertaining. You may even tip her for her performance. Before eating, they pour warm scented water over your hands with a fancy pitcher. A gentle rinse is offered to everyone in your party. The staff is very kind and accommodating.

Good Food, I recommend the Almond honey Lamb. Although all the dishes at our table were very delicious. I remembered the Honey Lamb the most. I enjoyed every bite. 

Atmosphere. Top to bottom, surrounded with color and texture. Comfy seating with cushions and pillows. Great place to be entertained and fed.
author: Charlene K.

description:
A pretty neat place! Intimate setting and love the decor, comfy too!. The food was good, especially the Bastela Du Chef (pastry with chicken appetizer), wish we had more of that. Music was low most of the time so it is a nice place to catch up with friends.

One negative though is that some entrees are extremely small and not filling while others are huge. I ordered the Moroccan seafood, and it literally had 4 shrimps and 2 scallops. Since I came in a party of 4 and we wanted to try everyone's dishes, I was only left with 1 shrimp after sharing. On the other hand, my buddy ordered a lamb dish and it was HUGE, I wanted to eat half of his plate so badly.

Anyhows, cool place, do ask the waiter the size of your entree before ordering to ensure you get enough food!

The mint tea at the end was yum too.

Food alone isn't really worth the $50 per person... but I guess it comes with belly dancing and cool decor, so....
author: Katherine C.

description:
This is a super fun place to go to with a big party. I had friends in town from LA and wanted to take them somewhere unique - this hit the spot.

I loved the lentil soup, the phyllo dough pie, and the lamb with honey. All delicious! And of course, the entertainment and belly dancing makes for a festive, fun environment.

Highly recommend!
author: Inna T.

description:
Okay, I've gotta say I'm NOT big on Moroccan food, and was extremely skeptical about coming here, but because it was my gf's bday, I thought I'd be open-minded and give it a shot. And to my surprise, it turns out to be a really great place! I'd definitely come back. 

The lentil soup was good and went great with the warmed bread, salade Mohammed dish which consisted of carrots and cucumbers marinated in some spices were ok, another side of tomato and peppers- tasted like salsa and it also had eggplant with something else mixed together was good. I found that the spices they used made it more lively and I found it quite delightful. (and I don't like eggplant at all). 

Their honey-prune chicken is a a must get (the chicken is soft, moist, tender and falls off the bone like butter), nothing like I've ever had before and their lamb skewers and lamb shank were good also and I hardly ever eat lamb and for me to say it's good, that says volumes because I'm exceptionally picky about my lamb, how it's prepared and I can't stand the gaminess of it. 

Their couscous I can live without, their seafood, shrimp and scallop was okay, didn't seem anything out of the ordinary, chicken pot pie was interesting. I say that because I am not a fan of sugar on my savory chicken pie, but the crust was soft and flaky and the filling was good.

We also had a side dish of fish tagine, which is seabass, but I wasn't a big fan of it. 

I loved their mint tea, slightly sweet and had a great hint of mint to it.

I could have gone without the fried bananas, but overall, I give it a B+.
Service was great, servers were great and our belly dancer was HOT and super sweet. The only thing I didn't really like was the ambiance and it felt a little awkward and so was our seating arrangement, but other than that, I loved the experience. 

For those of you who are skeptical of coming and trying their food, come with an open-mind and be willing to try anything at least once, hey after all yolo, right?! you'd be surprised with the results, I was.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I recently came here for a b-day dinner and it was really fun! The decor is exactly what I'd expect the inside of a genie lamp to look like. I was expecting it to be a little bigger but there was just one room with a few large seating areas. It's an easy place for a group dinner since everything is prix fixe. For around $34-$36 per person you get a lot of food: soup, salad, a chicken pastry, your meat selection, fried bananas, and mint tea. 

The soup and salad were fine. The bread they give you is pretty plain. I think it's funny they don't give you a flatbread instead to go with it since it would be a lot easier to pick up the food. The chicken pastry was yummy; a good balance between sweet and savory. Instead of picking one meat our waiter said we could do sampler platters between every 3/4 people. It allowed us to try a variety of chicken, lamb, and a little bit of seafood. Everything was pretty tasty and the meat was much more tender than I expected. I especially enjoyed the lamb kabobs, chicken with onions, lamb with almonds, and the scallops.

The belly dancing portion was fine, but I was hoping there would be multiple dancers. When we went there was only one, and it felt like she did do a lot of the same moves over and over. I probably won't go back anytime soon, but overall a fun place for dinner and especially accommodating for groups.
author: Alice J.

description: My mom drove out to have dinner here when I mentioned there were dancers each night. The decor was good and the service was great (poor guy as taking care of all of us himself!)  We each went with the pre-set menu and they were really great in making sure no nuts were involved in my moms food (she'd allergic) and no meat in mine (vegetarian). All of the pre-entree food was amazing! The entree itself I would rate a 4/5 (the vegetarian option; my mom really liked her chicken).  Service 5/5, food 4.5/5, dancing was probably a 3.5/5.
author: Sheena C.

description:
Dancing belly.

Hers: http://www.elmansour.com/index-4.html

Mine: Enjoyable Moroccan feast of lentil bean soup, chicken almond pastry topped with powdered sugar, chicken kebab, soft bread, couscous, scallops, prawns and mint tea.

Place was awkwardly empty except the very nice gentleman delivering the goods. He told it's packed on the weekends.

Comfy couches were perfect for the food coma that followed. And to take in the show.

Meal and show will set you back about $35 plus tip. Uniqueness of the experience, friendly staff and quality of food felt very worth it.
author: Jason B.

description:
I've been dying to try this place for years. Mostly because of the giant gold door (I have yet to be disappointed by anything that shiny). So I decided that a 12 person birthday party would be a great occasion. I called to make reservations 3 weeks before the event, and after a few back and forth between the owners (very sweet) and myself we had everything arranged for 8:00pm on an upcoming Saturday. 

Here is where El Mansour loses a star in my book. We arrived at 8:00 to a packed house, so much so that we couldn't all stand inside to wait to speak with a hostess. So while my party was waiting outside in the cold, I waited for 15 min before anyone came up to see what I may want. Although they seemed familiar with my name and the very large party I had reservations for, they told me it would be a little while. Being understanding I said ok and that we would be outside when the tables are ready. One HOUR later our party was able to sit down. It's a party of 12 - with reservations set 3 weeks ago, not cool. Also we did get a brief "thanks for waiting" but nothing was offered as an apology for the horrendous wait in the cold. 

With that said, the evening turned out very pleasant. We all ordered different dishes and everyone was pleased with the quality and taste of the food.  I think by far the overall winner was the Bastela du Chef which is a phillo-like pastry filled with chicken and spices. I had the rabbit which was phenomenal (and for $32.75 for a five course dinner, is very reasonable). My Husband tried the Lamb with Honey & Almonds which was amazing. 

The service is not great (ie if you ask for some hot tea, because you are cold from the hour long wait outside, you'll have to ask a couple more times before anyone brings you anything)  - but you have enough distractions (like the belly dancer) to not really notice. 
So overall El Mansour gets 2 Stars for great food, 1 star for great ambiance,  1/2  a star for great  price, and  1/2 a star for service (benefit of the doubt, will try again). I would love to give this place the full five stars, but between the service and the HOUR long wait (with three week standing reservations) I simply can't.
author: Katya B.

description:
Dining here is quite an experience!
Overall, good food, good service and good entertainment (belly dancing performance).
All meals include lentil soup, salad, chicken and almonds pastry, entree, dessert and mint tea (everything was full of flavors and yumminess). You have the option of selecting your entrees. We had the Moroccan seafood and Chicken kabob entrees, both were delicious. But my favorite was the Moroccan chicken pastry, so scrumptious!
author: Kanwal A.

description: Once a year I go to this restaurant and I look so much forward to it. It's a little pricy but you do get a decent amount food and it's very tasty. I am partly Moroccan myself so the food tastes like home and the surroundings (carpets, lamps, long scarfs) look like my old bedroom ha ha. First they wash your hands in water, dry them and they have you start off with bread and harira soup. During eating, a bellydancer comes and dances for a while, although I felt a little awkward because it just went on and on and she was dancing for money. My favs are couscous and any kind of tagine. Pretty much everything they have on the menu. After dinner they wash your hands again and then sprinkle rosewater over them so they smell nice. Love that touch. And then of course the waiters in Jellaba, which totally finishes the Moroccan experience.
author: Assia H.

description:
What an experience!

Food was excellent (we had the specialties course - for a few $ more felt like it was totally worth it! (though I don't know what you would have got for the other course so can't really do a true comparison)

Service was great!

Belly dancer was fun to watch.

Definitely would come back for an authentic ethnic experience. 

I thought the actual main portion was pretty small but with everything else that we had (appetizers etc) I was full and satisfied by the end of the evening.
author: Sujan H.

description: Place has awesome food, service was great and the price not too bad.  Come with an empty stomach though, there is a lot of food.  We didn't even eat the dessert.  So why did I only give it two stars?  Well we really wanted to see a belly dancer, we called earlier and they said "yes" there would be a dancer at 8, well 8 came and gone, and the main person at the restaurant told us she wasn't going to show.  We were disappointed to say the least, we felt lied to just to get us to the restaurant.  Will I go back if ever in San Fran again, yes, if we are not lied to I'll bump up the score.
author: Steve M.

description:
not in love with it 
 good food but really hard to sit and eat. Their table are no very confortable
author: A. M.

description: The food was great and so was the belly dancer!  The wait staff was also very accommodating. It was a bit loud as there was a group of women having fun. This is not the first time I've been there and it is always the same - great!
author: Deborah T.

description:
2 1/2 stars but service was really good. 

The food was better then I thought, but this really isn't my type of food. I tried everything that came out and it just wasn't good enough. Soup was nasty, bread wasn't warm, the chicken pie wasn't bad. Has a sweet and savory taste, but the dough was a little hard, the chicken skewers were dry, the scallop was under cooked, the shrimp was good, the lamb (which I don't eat), people said it was the best. For dessert was fried banana, but i can see more batter then anything.

It's a very loungy area and they bring a pot with water to wash your hands before and after dinner. You are suppose to eat with your hands, but I asked for forks. The waiter kept refilling our water which was good for a party of 25, but the food came out way too slow. 

The belly dancing was all right. The girl had a little belly and love handles. Not very flattering.
author: Karen H.

description:
This is the place you'll want to spend the whole evening to enjoy your dinner, chatting and entertainment. If you just want to have a quick dinner, go somewhere else. 

After you pass through the front door, you're in Morocco. The decor, the music, the way of seating and the fragrance in the air, you don't need to read the menu to feel this. It was the experience of 5 senses. Everything we ordered tasted delicious. I read some reviews talking about too entrees sweet with honey, it was actually my favorite dish, just perfect for me. The belly dancing was good. I also like the orange-blossom in our hands after dinner. The fragrance stayed the whole night. I definitely enjoyed the whole evening happiness since I entered El Mansour's door. 

Here the price range is $$$, but it's actually not that expensive. There are only 2 prices, $32.25 and $35.25 and they have everything including dessert, mint tea and the performance. In many $$ restaurants we spend more than this.
author: V L.

description:
This was my surprise pre-Valentine's Day dinner selection from my wife.  I had never had Moroccan food before so I was excited to try this place out.  It was packed inside and lots of large groups were there.

I'd recommend for ladies not to wear short dresses as the seating arrangements make it a little odd for that and since you're eating with your hands I'd recommend not wearing the best of clothes though.

The menu is pretty straight forward as it's multiple courses so you select the main entrée you want and everything else comes with it.  The chicken pastry (Bastela du Chef) was probably the best thing we had.

My wife timed it so we were able to see a belly dancer too which was pretty cool.  All around a great and different experience.
author: Blake B.

description: Great atmosphere and excellent hospitality by the hosts. This is an unique one of a kind, traditional dining experience. The chicken and lamb (not the sweet version) is excellent and so was the Fish Tagine. The banana fritters for dessert was also great and so was the tea.
author: Gopi V.

description:
This review is months overdue but better now than later...or never.

Came here to celebrate our girlfriends' birthdays on a Saturday. Right off the bat Customer service was attentively wonderful and we were greeted by very friendly servers. More than half of our party was late but they were accommodating nevertheless. Parking was surprisingly easy compared to the traffic on the way there. 

From my recollection (of what I recall anyway) I remember we ordered a 6-7 course meal starting with the lentil soup and bread which was delicious! I didn't hesitate to ask for my bread as I soaked it in the aromatic savoriness. After this the hummus and assortment of vegetables were brought in on silver platters, let the belly dancing begin!! We were thoroughly enjoying ourselves laughing along as our bottles of wine came. Our group wanted to take photos with the belly dancer and it was apparent my opinion didn't matter at that point, rather it was ignored. Each of us tipped the dancer generously, she gave a great performance! we were entertained.

As the remaining courses of lamb, fish and veal were gobbled up we felt more and more satisfied. Our server was not only charming but easy on the eyes ;-) and assisted us in taking our pictures. He even offered to help cool our huge bottle of champagne as we waited for dessert :). After dessert  he brought the bottle out and we insisted he join us in the celebration. Perfect gentleman. 

The evening was filled with laughter, hugs, appreciation and humor. All in all a fabulous experience and it didn't end there...the remaining moments of the night we'll keep to ourselves, PG-13: discretion advised. What I will tell you is, when I revisit this place there will be more fun times to come!
author: Jade D.

description:
The GOOD: Great finger licking good food, hospitable staff, and great ambiance...

The BAD: Lack of hard liquor, yeeesh... at least let us have some shots if we're going to wait all night... the belly dancer was very nice and friendly but belly dancing means dancing with your belly... not sucking you gut in and out... when your jelly belly has more than a few lbs (lets be nice and say a modest 20) on it, let's not do a dance that requires it to be out...

The UGLY: The wait is redonkulous... really, the patrons here are jerks... if you're done eating, please don't sit around for 2 hours while other patrons are waiting to eat... the people who go here are about the worst customers I've seen... we had a dual-birthday party to celebrate and had to wait an hour with reservations... of course, being courteous, we got our bill white waiting for dessert... 

I would definitely come back if the staff would have the guts to have a 30 minute time limit on their patrons... if you're done eating and already have the bill served to you, then you need to leave... 2 hours to eat sure, but another 2 hours to sit around denying other patrons their dinner is just rude... some guests are not from the city...
author: Nathan D.

description:
Wow finally found a Moroccan place!! I got the lamb and chicken. The lamb was soo tender. Hubs liked it more than his fish tagine (sea bass). It's a flat price of $36 but like many Moroccan places I've been to, it's multi-course. It includes a salad -ike dish, a chicken pie dusted with cinnamon and baker's sugar (way better than pot pie), your selected main dish, banana fritters and vanilla creme dessert, & finally mint tea. Mid-week there was no belly dancing but still worth the trip!!!

makes a fun grp place to go if everyone's ok with sharing or a nice romantic place to share a small table in a unique setting. Very pleasantly surprised to see this all the way on the other side of town, across from a Fresh n Easy market.
author: Emm C.

description:
If you're looking for a one of a kind place to take some friends out in SF this is it. Been going here with my family since I was a little kid. Although a lot has definitely changed since then it is still a great place. It's one of the top spots I bring friends and/or visitors!

I highly recommend making a reservation-no matter the size of the party. 
Belly Dancing nightly supposed to begin at 8pm-usually starts later than that though. Don't be shy, when you are there the dancers will try to coax you into getting up to dance-Do!! 

Being a vegetarian one of the only options is their Veggie Couscous, but it is delicious-mention that you're a vegetarian (if they don't ask) and they'll bring every course as such. Speaking of which they serve set courses (check out their website). I always leave stuffed. 

Lastly, one of my favourite moments is when they bring the warm, steeped orange-blossom water out to the table for you to rinse your hands-refreshing.
author: Brighid F.

description:
I was introduced to this little restaurant in San Francisco by a work colleague. He had been here before and loved it so decided to take a different group back. We made a reservation beforehand which was confirmed with a phone call. Upon arrival we had to wait for a table to to leave which was fine because the majority of our party had not turned up yet. 

We ordered the sampler, basically trying some of everything they have to offer. The washing of your hands is a unique and interesting experience but makes sense as most of the food you have to eat with your hands. There was live belly dancing during our meal which was entertaining and added to the atmosphere. 

At the end of the night we left a tip for the restaurant however did not realise that the tip was already included in the price we were given. The owner was kind enough to call me to let me know that but also to let me know he would not add our additional tip to the charges.
author: Andy M.

description:
The BF took me here for Valentine's Day this year.....same spot we went to our 1st Valentine's Date 4 years ago :)

I absolutely love everything about El Mansour--from the decor, service, food, and overall ambiance. I used to love how dim the room was with just hints of candles on the tables to give a little light....very intimate :) They've lit the room up a bit more than it used to be but you'd be surprised how cozy and romantic it is while you're lounging on sofas while eating with your hands with your special someone. :)

For dinner, we had:

Appetizers: Harira Soup (Lentil Soup), Salade Mohammed V (Eggplant, Carrots, Peppers), Bastela du Chef (Shredded Chicken in Phyllo) 

Entrees: Moroccan Seafood (Prawns and scallops) and the Lamb & Chicken with almonds

Dessert: Dessert King Hassan (Delicious Phyllo with Cream and Bananas)

Beverages: Rodney Strong Cabarnet and Mint Tea

D-E-L-I-C-I-O-U-S. The Lentil Soup was so hearty and warm...the Bastela was amazing....and my Seafood was cooked and seasoned perfectly. 

The mood---the food---the company---everything was absolutely perfect and romantic :)  Perfect Valentine's Day Celebration....and they even gave red long stemmed roses to each of the ladies. :)
author: Nam N.

description: Food was ok...the honey lamb was way too sweet...service was bad & charged me $20 for an extra cup of lentil soup....totally ridiculous!!
author: Homaira A.

description: Food was good, service was good and overall a nice date spot!
author: Lauren K.

description:
Decor was excellent, service was excellent. It was my first time trying Moroccan food and it was delicious. I don't know how it took so long for me to try. We came in here for my birthday dinner with a group of ten. 
First they bring water, then they bring you water to wash your hands and give everyone their own towel. You get soup which was a flavorful lentil soup. Then salad followed by appetizer. You eat everything with your hands no utensils!! I thought this was cool. You then get your main dish which I ordered the Moroccan seafood(prawn and scallops) with a side of cous cous and vegetables the garlic and oils on the seafood melted in your mouth. 
The table then gets desserts which is fried banana and some kind of extra in the middle of the plate. I don't know what it was, but its good!!  You end the meal with a delightful cup of mint tea. I will for sure come back here again
also a bellydancer for entertainment
author: Mary Jane P.

description: We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to El Mansour. The food was fantastic. The service was attentive and friendly. There are these lovely couches and stools to sit on, it feels very family oriented. The belly dancing was a unique touch. All the decor made me feel as though I had traveled to Morocco. The only reason its not 5 stars is the price and lack of attentiveness at the end. The price seemed a bit much, our total bill was 370 dollars for 6 people. And there is no way to make it less, its a fixed price per person. Additionally it took about 30 minutes at the end to get our bill and pay. We were done eating long before we could leave. Prior to our meal being completed we were attended to every few minutes, but at the end perhaps they just liked us too much to let us leave.
author: jenn g.

description:
Good food, but I've had better.  It's an eat with your hands place.  I don't mind doing it, but I don't prefer it.  We ordered a platter that was supposed to be enough for four people.  Honestly, I didn't think so.  I basically got a little bite of each thing.  For $35.75 a head, I expect more than 2 mouthfuls of chicken.  
  
Excellent Bastela du Chef (Pastry filled with chicken, almonds, and assortment of spices).

The cool thing of the evening was the belly dancer, only she didn't just do one song.  I think she did about 10.  A little long.  The music is turned up so it's hard to talk to your group when she's dancing.  

Definitely make reservations.  It's definitely a limited seating (as in each service takes a while before a table clears up).  

Not sure if we would go back.  I just don't think it was worth the price.
author: Denise M.

description:
El Mansour has all the ingredients for a great group dinner, be it celebrating a birthday, catching up with friends from out of town, or just wanting a little novelty with your fine dining.  Very nice staff, great ambiance, delicious food, and lots of quirky attributes we all enjoyed (very talented belly dancing, interesting hand washing experience, and awesome technique to tea pouring).

We ordered family style and all agreed the sweet meats were our favorites.  I'm allergic to eggplant and they were very accommodating! I got my own salad dish :)  The appetizers and desserts had a lot of great flavors, and the wine selection was fantastic.  We ordered two bottles. All in all, highly recommended for a LIVELY special occasion.
author: Desiree C.

description:
Great food. My party of 5 went on a Wednesday night and the place was pretty empty. We primarily came for the belly dancing but unfortunately the belly dance performance was ending when we walked in around 8:45pm. What we missed out on in entertainment was made up for by the food! We got the family full course and everyone enjoyed it.

If you're in the mood for cocktails, don't come here. There's only beer and wine.
author: Elisa H.

description:
:-)

"Sim Sim Sala Bim!" It's like a ride on a magic carpet. Yay, I'm a fan!

I've never had Moroccan food before.... and thought this place sounded like a good idea for a party! I was the best man at my older brothers wedding, so I had to pick a venue for a bachelor party type event. This was his second marriage, so nothing wild and crazy... (whew! that's good, cause wild and crazy for me usually meant losing track of a few days.... lol)  Luckily, he wanted something more respectable and mature. 

I'm glad I did my homework, cause in the end, it all paid off.

http://www.elmansour.com/

El Mansour! Don't let the name fool you. It's not Mexican.. its Moroccan. And way out in the Richmond (San Francisco). 

From the outside, El Mansour is pretty much average looking; but from the inside, its a whole different story. Dark and cozy floor to ceiling ethnically printed fabric envelopes you and entices you to enter. Hold onto your passport -- it's as if you've stepped out of the desert and into a Sultans tent. Don't bother clapping for your needs... At El Mansour, its all taken care of.

http://4.bp.blogspot.com/_-jjnGX_fcRI/R7OFew9TygI/AAAAAAAAAEc/q3xTpXInzzU/s320/clapper.jpg

After an initial "whore's bath" (washing of the hands in a shallow bowl with a fragrant water concoction and towel) we began the feasting. And no, its not just about the tasty cuisine, there's a belly dancing show to go with it! Yes BELLY dancers! BONERZ! 

I didn't know how it would all play out since I've never really hung with my brother AND his friends.... But tonight was perfect since this place had something for everyone. 

We all sat on cushioned low seats as tray after tray of exotic dishes, like couscous with lamb, chicken kabobs and other finger type foods arrived. Fresh baked moroccan style bread, Harira soup, Kanefa and the ala Menthe only added to the out of this country experience...

http://www.elmansour.com/index.php?p=Page_Specialties

But I must say, of all the dishes, my all time favorite was the Bastela du Chef (a pastry filled with chicken, almonds, and spices). I could eat that all night. Bastela du Chef is like having a light filo pastry, aka greek bakalava, only lighter still, stuffed with chicken, spices and almonds, and baked to a crispy light texture! The flavor and texture is very unique and quite exotic. Paired with their wines and dancing girls, El Mansour dining makes for an excellent tasty and entertaining event filled evening. 

http://www.elmansour.com/index.php?p=Page_Wine

All in all i think I won the respect of the bachelor party, and quite enjoyed myself as well. 

4 Woofs, I'd definitely come back to this place, and I'd recommend the dancing fo sho! Don't pee in the parking lot cause thats just tacky!
author: JöHnNy A.

description:
We had a party of 11 for my sons birthday last night. We wanted to try something a little more special for a 20 something guy.
We decided to try this Moroccan restaurant based on reviews and word-of-mouth.
We were not disappointed at all, although the prices per person were a tad bit more than I really wanted to spend, the ambience and the bellydancing and the food made it just about worth it.
  The owner (Jack) was very gracious in helping us with a reservation and even changing it to a different time and even change it once more as we were running late.
  Don't know how he was able to do it because it was fully packed when we got there but sure enough we were seated without any problems immediately.
 The food was anywhere from good to great too awesome depending upon which of us were giving our opinion. Definitely not one single item by any of us failed to at least get a " that's good" " opinion.
 The waiters were all great and personable and when you step inside to the restaurant you truly feel like you are in a different place.
  I highly recommend this restaurant both for a unique family experience or as a place to take your out-of-town visitors for something different.
  Do be aware though that this is a dining experience that takes around two hours so don't expect to just come in and eat and run.
author: Eric H.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! Coming here is like a treat for me...only because it is a bit pricey. But once walking through the door anyone should feel like they are in Morocco. 
The food is so good and well prepared!!! One of my favorite courses is the pastry with the meat. Oh and I love the bread...I am getting hungry thinking about it.
This place can get a little packed on the weekend nights. But I have never felt rushed to leave. Even with lots of people around sitting very close to you, there is still an intimate feeling. 
There is a belly dancer that comes out in the evening. She wants group participation, which is fun.
Can't wait to come here again!!!
