author: Danielle G.

description: We have been meaning to go to El Mansour for years, but somehow always forget. Fortunately the restaurant around the corner had a long line and we were not interested in standing out in the cold. We walked a bit and found El Mansour open. They serve a per person price for their five course meal, you choose your entree. The restaurant is set up like a large Moroccan tent with low tables and cushioned seats, very warm and welcoming. The meal begins with the washing of the hands ceremony, a delicious lentil soup with warm bread arrives first, then a flavorful yet simple salad, followed by an amazing chicken pastry with almonds, spices and a lightly sweetened pastry shell. For our main dish we braved it and ordered the chicken with prunes and honey. It sounds strange, but it was so good! We also tried the lamb kabobs with the lamb shank, also very good. The belly dancer who performed during our meal was quite engaging and entertaining. I loved how she got both men and women up to learn a few moves. The second washing of the hands does just before the dessert and mint tea. The service was excellent, the food a unique mix of flavors and the ambience made it an all around great dining experience. I would definitely recommend this place.
author: C L.

description: Very fun experience! I never experienced Moroccan food (or belly dancers) before El Mansour. The staff (owner I assume?) was wonderful, sweet and attentive. The food was delicious and the experience was FUN!
author: Kirsten B.

description: I really like El Mansour. I first came here on a date and try to make it back once a year or so. Great food, friendly service, fun belly dancing. The prices are a little high, but it's worth the experience. El Mansour is a great place to introduce someone to Moroccan cuisine. Or introduce someone to yourself. For the most part it's a good atmosphere for conversation, but if things ever get awkward, you know the belly dancing will commence shortly and you'll have time to think about additional things to discuss, such as the belly dancing.
author: Courtney P.

description: We love this place! Be sure to get there early and be ready to dance!
author: Francis H.

description:
El Mansour's food is what anybody can cook after a week with, say, a "Moroccan Food for Dummies" recipe book.  

The lentil soup is, effectively, the end result of a good hour's of cooking time, some canned broth, and a few dried herbs.  It's not spicy at all.

Salad Mohammed V:  if the great Sultan ate this, then surely the leisurely life of North African royalty is not all it's cracked up to be.  Every component is seriously lacking in elemental spice and flavor; especially the eggplant which reads watery and even a bit undercooked.  It's served on a chintzy bit of lettuce and, frankly, the cucumbers were the standout on this drab plate.

The filling for the "bastela" is simply bone-dry shredded chicken, not integrated at all into a proper pie.  It's a mess; there's a desperate attempt to mask the bland mediocrity with excessive sweetness and cinnamon.  

The fish tagine is a hot mess.  There's sea bass that isn't even properly de-scaled; you get a few fun surprises in every bite.  The fish tastes a bit rank, either because of questionable freshness or the simple fact that an oily fish like sea bass doesn't play well in an oily sauce.  

Good couscous is fluffy; the grains are distinct from each other; it's moist without being gloppy.  Theirs is anything but.  It's served with what looks like a mashed potato scoop -- the inevitable result is to retain too much heat and moisture in the dense middle, and to produce a mushy texture.  

Anybody who's even made couscous from a box knows it needs to be fluffed prior to serving; ideally it's spread out on a plate to promote an even heat distribution and release of moisture.  This approach is borderline insane coming from a _Moroccan_ restaurant.

The chicken is competently done, if not having any characteristic spiciness.  The lamb seems to have been done in a pressure cooker, which means it's tender but hasn't had time to integrate the flavors of a proper Moroccan stew.  Again, there's no spice; it's basically just a braise in salted water with just a hint of what it could be.

King Hassan apparently had a thing for banana fritters.  Who knew?  Or perhaps it was just made up by the owners.  Regardless of His Royal Taste, who wants a banana fritter alongside a sweet "bastela"?  I don't know, but it's there.  The basic strategy seems to be to multiply the number of fritters by the number of guests.  This is crowd control, not dessert.

And there's mint tea to finish the meal, certainly the highlight after so many obvious missteps.

To put it bluntly, El Mansour is to Moroccan what your typical Hibachi Grill/teppanyaki joint in suburban America is to Japanese food.

The basic strategy seems to be to substitute the flair of belly dancing and a bit of a bachelor party atmosphere for authentic and well-executed Moroccan cooking.  

That's a shame.  

Great Moroccan food is extremely soulful, one of the best cuisines in the world.  It should be enjoyed in its own right because it's delicious and, by its nature, it should be relatively inexpensive.  I don't have any problem with enhancing the experience of "mere" Moroccan food with entertainment or a festive atmosphere.  But the food should be given its due respect, and the experience should be built around great food first, because that is the bedrock of any such cultural exchange.
author: J W.

description: Mediocre food, or maybe it's good but I am just not a fan of this type of food. Belly dance during the meal is entertaining. Five of us sat in a corner, it's kind of hard to have everybody sit comfortably yet being able to see the performance.
author: Tian W.

description: I set up dinner for my husband's birthday here on a Tuesday night and had a party of about 14.  We mostly had the place to ourselves.  The music was great, the belly dancing was a lot of fun and the service was first rate.  Leandro the waiter was as good as good service gets.  We danced with the belly dancer and even my 8 year old was so entertained he behaved and had a blast.  We were having so much fun I think we were there for almost 4 hours!  And I almost forgot to mention, the food was delicious!
author: Rebecca M.

description:
I really enjoy this place. It looks really cool on the inside, like a Moroccan tent or something. Its pretty intimate. We got the "family style" which is $34 a person for 4 courses
- lentil soup: pretty typical, so good
- some salad: u have to share which is a little awkward, and u dont get plates
- some meat cake/pie- REALLY GOOD my favorite
- a bunch of meat: impeccable lamb, honey n almond chicken, rabbit, and they brought a separate thing of sea bass
- some dessert thing with bananas also good

The belly dancer was really good and crazy. She had crazy abs and did a good job at entertaining the place. (she deserved good tips)
author: Nikita K.

description: Great food, had a party with a large group of friends and class mates ! Killer deserts and bread ! Also a beautiful belly dancer
author: Gerard F.

description:
It was a cultural experience.

We did one of the family meals thing, where you get a sampler plate that has the kabobs, almond lamb, couscous and a chicken.  I would had prefered to get the almond lamb all to myself. I was a little skeptical about the lamb at first becase I tried other African cuisine and the lamb had turned out gamey but this wasn't gamey at all.  It was sweet too.  They also had this thing that was like a sweet and savory pastry.  It was like a puff pastry covered with powdered sugar and filled with chicken. 

I do love the fact that this place keep a lot of the Moroccan tradition, such as the hand washing at the beginning and end of the meal at the table, the belly dancing, and they don't give you utensils unless you ask for it.
author: Mimi P.

description:
Had a great time here:
- food was excellent
- service was incredibly nice and helpful (considering we were not familiar with this type of cuisine and how to eat it)
- atmosphere was relaxed and fun (think Morocco - the restaurant made me feel like I was back there down to the rounded blue door and wooden accents on the wall)
- belly dancing was a plus (reality is that it only last 20 minutes and is once a night, so it provides more of a brief moment of amusement rather than a full show.  My brother says he fell in love  with the dancer but that's another topic...)
- price could be beat (just over $30 per person for a 5 course meal)

In summary nothing "sour" and Mansour so "man up" and get over there soon!
author: David A.

description:
I came here for the first time on Saturday night with a group of friends and had a great experience.  

Like others have said, it's a bit pricey, but think of it as dinner and a show.  You totally get what you pay for and won't leave hungry...but definitely make a reservation!

For my entree I had the chicken with raisins and onions, which was quite delicious.  The meat fell off the bones and had just the right combo of sweet and savory spices.  I loved everything else that came with it too.  The appetizer was kind of like fried dough (think carnival) with chopped 
up chicken.  It might sound a bit odd, but I couldn't get enough.

The only thing a little lacking, which surprised me based on the other reviews, was the service.  Several parties around us, which were seated after us, had their orders taken and received food more quickly than we did and we never even got salad plates.  Regardless, it was a fun night with great food and friends and I'd definitely go back.
author: Nicole L.

description:
The point: eat here, or you missed out.

The service is nearly spa-worthy; waiters were providing very consistent attention, and our hands were washed with warm water twice. The first washing was accompanied by the waiter humming a song, and the second was followed by scented oil. I felt absolutely pampered :) . Seating is very accommodating for large groups, and the staff is more than happy to prep and bring out personal cakes that parties bring in.

The food is divine. 5-course meal of very authentic and absolutely delicious foods. It's $36 - $39 per person, but you can also ask to do the smaller dishes for $20. (My teenage niece & I did one full meal & one partial, which was more than enough food for the two of us). 

The decor and ambiance is highly authentic, beautiful, and very welcoming.

The middle eastern dancer was amazing. This is the first time I have ever seen a sword dance in person; her balance and skill were tremendous. 

This was an awesome find, and I plan to be back :D !
author: Becca M.

description:
Set menu is expensive and annoying, but you realize in the middle of the meal that it's dinner AND a show - in light of this fact, the price is actually not too bad.

::::::::::  Dinner  ::::::::::

Great food! Especially the chicken bastela - sweet and savory puff pastry; flaky, buttery, and delicious.

Sweet-and-savory anything is great here. Anything with honey, raisins, or prunes. Steer clear of the almond chicken; it was kind of bland.

::::::::::::  Show  :::::::::::::

Moroccan hand washing and elevated tea pouring are especially memorable.

Gorgeous belly dancers! You can get up and dance with them. So much fun for bachelor/bachelorette parties.

:::::::::  Atmosphere  :::::::::

Good for groups of 6-8; 10 or more makes it difficult for everyone to mingle because of the way the couches are set up.

Over-the-top decor; almost theme park-ish
author: Jen L.

description: The food was really great and the belly dancing show was entertaining.  We went on a Thursday night, so it wasn't packed. I suspect it's a lot more fun on the weekend when there are more people there drinking and participating.  We brought a cake in because it was my boyfriend's birthday and the waiter brought it out and played a fabulous birthday song over the sounds system.  It was great!!
author: Nicky H.

description: I have been back to El Mansour a few times and they never cease to impress with the food and the entertainment. We always take friends or relatives from out of the area to experience the fun and food here.
author: Greg S.

description:
I can't say much about the price, because for our party of 10, someone else paid, but DAMN the food and atmosphere is incredible!

I had an amazing experience here and will definitely go back for more special occasions.

Reserve a table, it was packed when we went.

The mint tea was delicious, and the different courses were very very tastey.

And they have belly dancers!!
author: Shannon M.

description:
We had a restaurant.com deal for this place, so decided to try it. The food was ok, nothing special, but nothing horrible too. When we got the check, and tried to use the restaurant.com deal, the owner gave us a really hard time about it. First he tried to tell us they didn't accept them, then he asked us if we bought it in Europe (wtf?) and after a very long battle, he finally gave in... but we really had to work for our discount (that we paid for). Yeah, not pleasant.. didn't get the vibe that he wanted our business next time. BTW, our waiter was really nice, it was the owner who spoiled it all.

Now about the food. The mint tea (served at the end) was pretty good. But it comes with sugar, so if you are not into super sugary drinks, don't forget to mention that before hand. The lentil soup and bastella the chef were ok, interesting, different. Everything else was pretty bland though.
author: CatsPjs Z.

description:
I liked the experience of this place. The highlights were definitely the sweet mint tea at the end of the meal and the belly dancer. The interior of this place was really unique, and I love how they spritzed our hands with rose-oil infused fragranced water at the end so our hands smelled nice. I didnt care too much for the food, but not from lack of appreciation of ethnic food. I love ethnic, and am actually a huge fan. 

I just didnt like the way the food was prepared I guess. We went in a group of 4 and ended up sharing most of our food since everyone ordered something different (all of it was recommended by our server). Most plates had too many bones or too much sauce and I couldn't really enjoy it. I usually love pastilla but I didnt even like that. Really sucks because we went for a group member's birthday, we were dressed really nice, some of us danced with the belly dancer and were in a totally festive mood but the food was a turn off. 

The wait staff was excellent (minus the recommendations), the interior and location were nice, I even liked the idea of the 4 courses especially tea at the end. Overall though, I will not go back because there are way better Moroccan food restaurants in the bay area that aren't as overpriced. This occasion in particular though, the prices weren't an issue since we were going all out and wanted to indulge in somewhere nice. Anyhoo, it was a nice experience at least.
author: Ria R.

description:
I'm not sure what all the hype is about, but this restaurant was a huge disappointment. I ended up spending almost $100 for a sub-par meal for two people. The restaurant itself is cute with comfortable seating. However, the food left a lot to be desired. My boyfriend and I ordered the pre-fixe menu. It begins with a lentil soup that tastes exactly like Campbell's canned soup-- not terrible, but not great either. The next course was the Bastela du Chef. That was delicious and ended up being the highlight of the evening, but it was all downhill from there. The entrees that we ordered (lamb and chicken) were incredibly oversalted. I like salty things, but I really couldn't eat mine. Also, the rose water hand washing that they do at the table ended up burning my boyfriend's hands because the water was scalding. The restaurant would do well to let the water cool a little lest they injure someone else. 

As for the bellydancer...I have to give her credit for courage. She clearly did not know how to actually bellydance, but was trying her best. I blame the restaurant for not hiring someone qualified for that position.

Overall, I would never go back.
author: S. C.

description: This is an amazing restaurant. Come here as soon as as is convenient. Love the mint tea in the end. And the soup, OMG. Is to die for. Slurp.
author: Anurag S.

description:
I got the chance to visit this place last night!  I decided to take my boyfriend and a group of friends here to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday.  

The service was amazing, the food was awesome and vibe was great.  The belly dancer was very sweet, and taught our group a few belly dancing techniques!

I made reservations, and asked if they could do something a little special for the boyfriend.  They followed through by serving our banana fritters with a special one just for him...his had a little birthday candle.  They also sang happy birthday, too!

It is a little pricey, but well worth it!  I think I just might have to come back and share the experience with some other friends, for sure.  :)
author: Pelon P.

description: Loved it! Good service. Unfortunately no dancer tonight but it was made up for with our sweet and charming server. There was 3 of us and ordered the off the entree menu. The lamb w honey and almonds was unreal. Sweet more than savory and falling off the bone. The chicken (whole) w lemon and olives was also very different and savory. Yummy. The kabobs were juicy and great accompaniments. We had our hands washed twice and then had rose water sprayed on them. So neat!  Anyway the experience was awesome and my cousins loved it!
author: Yasmin A.

description:
I love this place!  Been coming here for years and have never ever had a bad experience.  I just finished reading some other people's complaints and I have to say that I disagree completely.  The food is A+ as well and the service is second to none.  I've never been anywhere else where servers come and essentially assist you in washing your hands with jasmine scented water...i mean whoa!!!!  I always get the lamb plate because it's so good and it never gets old.  The belly dancers have always been incredible and the newest girl is an amazing dancer and very beautiful to boot.  I read a few other reviews that made reference to the owners/workers being Asian.....really?  How do you know they are owners let alone what their nationality is simply based on some biased opinion you formed on how they look TO YOU?  I certainly don't and I've been eating here for over 5 years.  I know the guy that is being referenced and he is always very polite and does his best to help people.....what does it matter that he (in you personal opinion) does not look Moroccan enough?  Jeez!!!! LOL!!!!  Sometimes the comments on here just irk me so sorry for the rant.  Regardless this is a great place to take a date....both you and your partner will not be disappointed.... and best believe I will continue to eat here and refer people here also.

***FYI  I should mention that if you make a reservation you still may not be seated at the time that you were told to arrive.  This is because there is limited seating, but then  again this only has happened to me on busy days like Valentines Day....but what place isn't busy on that day?  Either way it's well worth the wait! ****
author: Don C.

description:
Went here last weekend for a friends birthday and was pretty unimpressed with the food.  

Upon entering we were assaulted by music so loud that I was surprised my ears weren't bleeding.  If you've read any of my other reviews, you might already know that I am not a fan of places where I have to shout in the face of the person standing next to me in order for them to hear me, however this was so bad that the people I was with were noticeably irritated as well.  Thankfully it turned out that this was only for the belly dancers performance and they turned it down at the conclusion of her dance (which was lovely by the way).  My relief cannot be expressed in words.

Once the music was turned down and we went over the wine and beer list we chatted and waited for them to take our drink orders.  And waited, and waited.  After being there 15-20 minutes we finally managed to grab a waiter and force him to acknowledge our existence.  Much to my husband's dismay they were out of the only Moroccan beer they had.

Once the rest of our party got there we did the hand washing and they began serving the courses.  I'm not going to waste much time reviewing their food because there's really not a lot to say.  It was very bland.  I liked the skewered lamb, but again there was no spice.  If you're someone who doesn't like spicy food then I highly recommend this restaurant.  My favorite part about the meal was the sweetened mint tea at the end.  

After reading the other reviews for this place I didn't have highest expectations for the food, but they still managed to disappoint me.  It seems like most people go for the entertainment, which was very good.  The service, after our whole party arrived, was also quite good and everyone was very nice.  The food arrived in a timely manner and they were on top of refilling wine glasses and water glasses.

I had a wonderful time with my friends and they did well with our large group of 15.  Honestly this place would be great if they got a better chef.  It makes me curious to try the Moroccan place down the street from where we live and see what their food is like in comparison.
author: Megan M.

description:
I just loved everything about this place.

The decor - amazing. It makes you feel as if you're transported to another country. The love the low tables, the tent-like ceiling and walls.  It's attractive and comfy (try to get a corner table, it's super comfortable).

We arrived slightly early and were seated right away - the hosts and waiters were accommodating and very welcoming. 

Since we were new to the place, they were very attentive (though I don't doubt that they're attentive to everyone that comes into their gorgeous restaurant).

A server comes by early on and hands out some towels for us that also acts as our napkins.  You're supposed to eat with your hands, apparently (we didn't know this).  They'll come with a little "tub" that also looks decorative and nice.  You put your hand over it and he'll pour warm water over you.  Later on, he'll come by for a rinse as well, but this time with a type of rose water for a nice scented smell. 

They explained their price fixed menu - it's not very diverse, but you won't regret it.

There was a total of four for our party, and we ordered off the Specialty Menu ($34.75) and one from the regular Entree menu ($31.75):

Regular Entree:
Lamb with Honey & Almonds

Specialty:
Moroccan Seafood (Prawns & Scallops)
Fish Tagine (Sea Bass in charmoula with tomatoes, olives and lemons)
Lamb & Chicken (with almonds)

Everything comes with:
Couscous and Vegetables
Harira Soup(Spicy Lentil Bean Soup)
Salade Mohammed V (Combination of Tomatoes, eggplant, carrots & cucumbers)
Bastela du Chef (Pastry filled with chicken, almonds, and assortment of spices)
King Hassan (Banana Fritter), Keneffa (Sweet Bastela with Cream and Almonds)
The A La Menthe (Mint Tea)

- - - - - - -

I loved everything that they served, but these are the highlights that I loved the most.

The bread - it's home made bread; you won't be able to find it anywhere else.  We asked, and they say that they make it every day right before they open for business.  A reason why they taste so good.

The couscous and vegetables - Oh couscous they're so delicious.  I haven't had couscous but one of my friends said she has and the one at El Mansour is the best one she has tasted so far.

The Mint Tea - I had this one before in Monterey, but this version beats it hands down.  And the way they serve it - awesome.

Lamb with Honey & Almond - the others who have mentioned this type of lamb weren't kidding, it's delicious it makes you want to cry.  Try it with their bread, and you wouldn't know how to contain yourself.

Fish Tagine - Oh sea bass... you taste good no matter where you are.

- - - - -

The entertainment itself - the belly dancer - is amazing.  She's friendly and always has a smile on her face.  And wow, she has great control and posture.  I loved the way she balanced the sword on top of her head and spun.  :)

Go ahead and tip her - and if you're spontaneous or just plain daring and want to unwind - go up there and dance with her.  
It's wonderful.

- - - - - -

Overall, this place was a great find.

The only place I don't like is how difficult it is to find parking around this area - we circled around a few times before taking a chance at a very tight parking spot, 3 blocks down.
author: Nina M.

description:
Been here several times and I never have any complaints about this place.

The service is good.
The food is better than good.
Fantastic portions.
I'm easily amused, I'm a fan of the rose water hand washing and the genie in a bottle decor.  

Perfect for a large group.  Had my bday dinner here and I had an amazing time.  Also the belly dancer was fun to watch, she made people in my group embarrass themselves and dance infront of everyone.  

+5 for sure.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description: We have been there once before and we loved it so we decided to come back. Its a nice restuarant .. Great entertainment.  The food is over priced though for the quality and portion. We just come for the atmosphere.. Food is very standrad not that authentic. I'm from the Middle East .. Thats why! :)
author: Javier G.

description:
El Mansour is a great place to entertain!  The ambiance is so befitting with the staff dressed in traditional costumes, you sit on low benches around small tables and pillows and complete with belly dancing entertainment.  Complete with rose water washing of the hands and mint tea....your dinner and entertainment is complete!

The food is exceptionally good.  The Harira soup (spicy lentil) was delicious!  You just keep on wanting more bread to soak up all the soup.

I especially liked the bastela, salads and spreads that accompany the meal.

I always order the chicken with honey and prunes.  The meat is tender and delicious. It is both savory and sweet and is very fragrant of herbs and spices.

At the end of your meal, you'll want to pull one of those pillows, prop your head and fall asleep because you'll be so full!
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
Definitely one of the most interesting dinner experiences I have ever had - and I am of Middle eastern origin myself....

The restaurant is not in the best commercial area of San Francisco but it is worth the drive. As my friends and I arrived, there was a belly dancer but unfortunately she was on her last dance as we sat down. We did not have to wait for a table and the server was very attentive throughout the meal. The decor and layout/seating was very special and authentic.

The menu consists of two main categories: specialties and entrees. Within these two categories, there are many choices to choose from. Any option you choose comes with a 5 course meal... Soup, a sweet & savory chicken pie, a plate of salads/veggies, the main course, and desert + tea. 

Overall, this is a great place to come on a date or with family/friends!
author: Tania D.

description:
We went on a Saturday night and had a really fun time.  The food was outstanding and the atmosphere really fun.  The belly dancer is gorgeous....dancing & tipping highly recommended.  

We were a party of 5 and had one in our party with an almond allergy.  They were very accomodating BUT had to be reminded twice that we needed to be almond free.   Both times they brought out (within a few minutes) an almond free version of the dish being served dish.  The third time, we didn't even bother to say anything as it was really kind of annoying that every single thing they brought had the almonds in or sprinkled on top of the dish and they had to be reminded over & over.  So, our birthday girl had to pick around the almonds sprinkled on her cake.  

We all really enjoyed the food and despite some basic flaws in service, we would all go back.

Overall, the service was wonderful.  It is a slow dining experience and with 8:30 resevations, we did not leave until 11:30.  We continually got almonds on everything but all of the significant service flaws all happened in the last 30 minutes.  

We were never served our tea with dessert....kinda a bummer as we were looking forward to it but to be honest, at that point we were ready to go as service had slowed to a crawl at about 10:30.  

We were a party of 5 women and requested that they call a cab for us.  He told us that they usually won't come out to pick us up and suggested we walk over a few blocks and try to flag one down.  Ok, so maybe the cab service would have told him no, but he could have pretended to call for us.  Everyone in our party has AT&T phones and we did not have service...not very reassurring as you walk out into Outer Richmond at midnight.

Anyway, I would definitely go back.  I would arrange a car service ahead of time or drive out there myself.  Be sure to be there before 8:30 so you don't miss any of the dancing and earlier reservations may save you from the end of night slump in service we experienced.  

Off now to go find a recipe for their phyllo dough chicken appetizer thingy that was awesome!
author: Kelly M.

description:
Good food (three of us ordered the four course; one chicken/lamb, one fish, one seafood), ambiance, and entertainment  (Even the other diners). 
Great service. 
Restrooms can be a wait. 
Street parking.
author: qirk z.

description:
This is definitely a great place for a group gathering or birthday party. I'm so glad my friend picked this place to celebrate her 21st birthday. Once you walk in, it felt like you're in a genie bottle. The seating was so comfy I just wanted to take the little chair home with me.. 

It was a Tuesday so it wasn't all the packed. All the groups there had their little corner. 

It was my first time eating Moroccan food so I wasn't sure what to expect except for the fact that you eat with your hands. I'm all for anything that involves food in your hands. 

The menu was limited. There was two section, the Specialties and the Entrees. Specialties was served with couscous and vegetables, soup, salad, Bastela Du Chef (this Filo pastry filled with shredded chicken and dusted with powdered sugar.. it was some BOMB ASS Bastela!), your choice of entree, dessert, and mint tea. Entrees was served with soup, salad, Bastela, dessert, and mint tea.

I chose the Couscous with lamb and vegetables ($28.95). The lamb was fall off the bone and cooked perfectly. Couscous was delicious, and the vegetables consisted of cucumber and carrots. There was lots of food and I was literally gonna BLOW up by the end. 

The soup was lentil soup and it was yummy. They come by often with a BIG dish of bread and you grab one to eat with your bread, salad, and entree. 

Salad was a combination of pureed eggplant, tomato salsa thing, marinated carrots, and cucumber. It was damn good when you dip your bread in that purred eggplant!! HELLA GOOD

My favorite of the night had to be the Bastela Du Chef. The Filo pastry filled with shredded chicken and dusted with powdered sugar was totally awesome! It had a little sweetness to i which is why I loved it.. Cinnamon!

Dessert was the Fried bananas with another Filo pastry with cream and almonds. My second favorite... If only I could of have five all to myself! 

The dinner ended with a mint tea and that was also wonderful.. I'm not so into tea but this was one of the best I've had..

BELLY DANCING:
The belly dancer was seriously so HOT. She was great at every move she made and I liked how she have people come up with her and teaches them how to belly dance! Really entertaining!

If you're looking for a great Morrocan place with great food and great entertainment, this IS the place to go!
author: Juliane N.

description:
woohoo!! 
Its the best place to party!

So deserve 5 stars.
author: Sean M.

description: The food was amazing! The staff was so great and helpful and there when we needed! The entertainment was fun!! The place is clean and smells so good!! Decorated in a way it transports you to morocco !!!
author: Ruth M.

description:
I loved it! The dancing was really really nice, and I had chicken and it was very good and flavorful. I got to dance with the belly dancer...I am sure to everyone's embarrassment - but you only live once! 

The environment was really nice too from the walls to the tiles, to the iron door they had. Everyone was nice and they were as fast as they could be. The seating was these nice puffy cushions and it was a very enjoyable experience. I am giving them 5 stars because I thought it was a delicious and worthwhile restuarant and would reccoment it to anyone who wants to try Morrocan food. 

Oh but wait parking sucks....plan accordingly.

Cheers! : )
author: Rich R.

description:
The worst experience I never had in a restaurant.
We make the reservation 1 week before the day and I explained it was for a birthday for a person who came from Europe.
When we arrived, we received a table for 2 but I reserved for 3.
we asked to have an another table, the restaurant was almost empty, but they said us that if we were not happy, we could leave!
We left and we had to find a another restaurant to celebrate the birthday but it was 10 pm!!! 
I work for an international magazine and I will wrote a review on it!
author: Melki T.

description:
Ever since I saw Along came Polly,  I've been dying to find a fun moroccan restaurant where I can eat with my hands and sit on pillows.  Not only did this place live up to the gorgeous moroccan decor I had imagined, the food was equally amazing.  From the chicken, to the lamb to rabbit (but not the cute ones)  all the food was prepared with a home cooked taste that you just don't get at your everyday restauraunt.   

The only draw back to the evening was that there seemed to be a lack of waiters serving our party of 15.  They were sincerely apologetic however; a party of 40 happen to come in the same night, that never confirmed their reservation.  

Either way, this is a great place to host a large party, or an intimate party of 2.  They start the evening with a ceremonial washing of your hands, and serve everything family style.   They even  have a belly dancer that entertains while you dine.  I will def. be back.
author: Michelle C.

description: This is my absolute favorite restaurant.  I drive up from the South Bay just to eat here.  The food is amazing and the interior of the restaurant is gorgeous.  All servers are friendly and willing to help.  Just keep in mind that it is a five-course dinner so it takes about 2 hours to eat.  But everything is delicious.  And there is a belly dancer every night, too.
author: Rachel C.

description: I LOVED this place!! The server was great and so was the belly dancer!!! We had some sort of fixed party menu that was delicious. The soup was hearty and tasty, all the dishes in between were great and the fried banana dessert was one of the best ever!! The server washed our hands and rinsed them with rose water ! I hope that scent stays on my hands permanently!! It was super fun! It was on the pricey side, though.
author: PM P.

description: Looking for something different, comfy and fun? This place is great for groups of friends. Super friendly and heartfelt service, delicious food experience, authentic Moroccan atmosphere, and beautiful belly dancing. Yes, it is an experience that will take a few hours, but in good company, it is so worth it! If you haven't been, check it out!
author: Aiola K.

description:
Wonderful experience all around- ambiance, service, food, and entertainment! 

With so many restaurants in SF to choose from, there are only a handful of places I would ever make a return trip... and this is one of them.
author: J S.

description:
What a little gem in the outer Richmond!

Great:
- to hold a big group dinner for birthday or bach party (we went to a joint bachelor and bachelorette gathering)
- lots of variety of food to share and sample (rather than ordering individual plates)
- staff is super helpful and friendly
- delicious Moroccan food and belly dancers- what more do you want at dinner?

We had a great time on a Saturday night and came to a packed house.  It's a set price with various menu options that are all published online, which I appreciate.

My only criticism is that I would've preferred to just order my own food.  The sharing for our group of 12 was fine, but left me with certain items that I didn't love (lamb with prunes... don't want prunes as much as they're good for my digestion).  Dessert was skippable, but I LOVE MOROCCAN MINT TEA.  I just never understand why it's served in such a tiny glass.  Leave the pitcher!  

If I were to come back, definitely hit up the kabobs!  DELICIOUS AND SO TENDER (LAMB AND CHICKEN).

Make reservations and parking wasn't too bad.  Definitely check it out if you're trying to find a place for 6 or more!  Don't forget to bring some singles to tip the belly dancers!
author: Christine K.

description: LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this restaurant!!! Very authentic and customer service is beyond what one can ask for.   Even when the house is completely full and people waiting in line you never feel like you are getting rushed or pushed out the door. Oh and can't forget the belly dancer, she was very, let's say... talented! LOL
author: Chauntelle W.

description:
Note: There's a parking lot about two blocks up the street near the park.

I really enjoyed my experience here. The moment you walk in you don't feel like you're in SF anymore. Love the decor and welcoming atmosphere. 

Five-course preset meal but you choose the main entrée. We got the honey and almond lamb and lamb with couscous and vegetables. 
If you're a big eater then maybe you'll need your own entrée but I think I could have done with just one main course since you eat the first two appetizers with bread. The honey and almond lamb was recommended and it was good. Sweet but not overpoweringly sweet. Also really enjoyed the lentil soup and quad salad-very flavorful. 

Stasha the belly dancer was very entertaining and friendly. She tried to get everyone to dance with her...maybe if I had a glass of wine-- next time I'll order a bottle!

And I especially loved it because I always say we need to revert to eating with our hands and walking around naked! 1 out of 2 is good enough for me.
author: Katie T.

description: We love this restaurant so much . The food is so delicious specially the rabbit kabob . Also we love the tea that they served us . Also , they have a very interesting Belly Dance, the dancer may invite you to dance with her so a lot of people do and they seem so happy and excited while dancing.... I really recommend this place for people who are looking for an arabic night!!
author: Razan S.

description:
Happy Birthday Juicy.

- Only for you would I sit on cushions at a table that's not low enough and not high enough.  
- Only for you would I sit in the path of a gyrating belly dancer
- Only for you would I eat with my fingers and share a spoon with a Mexican't.

Being here felt like we were on vacation.  Lots of groups, noisy, chaotic.  Service was solid as they are probably very use to the rowdiness. Food was really tasty - I like phyllo dough.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
I used to go to this place in the late 80's and early 90's when it was next door. I loved it then but was always terrified the belly dancer would catch me. 

Now that I'm no longer socially phobic and actually quite enjoy being center stage, this no longer bothers me. We went back about a year ago, and the waitress actually recognized me! Wow!

I think it's the best Moroccan food I've had in this country. I love the appetizers and always get the rabbit. 

Go for it!
author: Nobbi L.

description: Overall, my experience was mediocre. My favorite part was the belly dancer and the dessert. However, the service was horrible. I initially made reservations for 7:00PM. I got there on time and didn't get seated til 8:00!!! I'm giving it 3 stars for the amazing belly dancers.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I went here for my 27th or 28th birthday a couple of years ago and it was awesome! The area was spacious and the belly dancer was a nice touch!!! The food was great and interesting, family style.

Overall, great ambiance and experience!!! Reservation is a must for a large party.
author: Nhung T.

description: I read the YELP reviews that advised against the family style option but the waiter 'highly recommends' it.... $38p/p with a variety of meats included. The scallops/prawns were good but the other meats were small, boney and not easy to identify (chicken, rabbit, lamb?) Very small portions for 4 people to share. A great deal for Mr Mansour but not for the customer!!
author: T S.

description:
My husband and I had our wedding reception here.  We chose to have our celebration at El Mansour because we didn't want a typical cookie cutter reception with average catered food in an impersonal banquet hall or Chinese restaurant. We've all been to those before, many, many times : ( 
Moroccan food was a new experience for most of our guests and they had a great time. 
El Mansour exceeded our expectations. Having a dinner here is truly an experience to savour and enjoy. They were great in accommodating some of our picky guests when they wanted plates and silverware instead of eating with their hands. The belly dancers were very  popular among our guests, food was delicious, and service was quick and efficient.
author: Shelly R.

description:
My first date with my girlfriend at the time. She's a complete germ-a-phoebe, so, taking her might have not been the best idea. It's Moroccan food, so, you will be eating with your hands, sans utensils. To my surprise, this was one of the most romantic dinners we've ever had and she completely enjoyed herself. She loved the decor, the ambiance of the entire place.

You start off by "washing" your hands at the table. The waiter comes by with rose water. It's basically like a 5-6 course dinner. Portions are somewhat small, but honestly, you get full. Even for a big guy like myself, I was stuffed walking out of here. The belly dancer that night was very playful and fun. The staff overall was very accommodating. 

If you're never been to something like this with your significant other and they don't mind being somewhat, um, physical with you at dinner, this is the spot. My companion described the dinner as "sensual".
author: Wes S.

description:
This place is pretty cool. The decor is amazing.. its pretty dark inside but not as bad as outback steak house. There are stools and bench like seating.. at least I wasn't in my dress sitting on the floor. I totally forgot Moroccan food involved eating with your hands.. so the experience was unique. They wash your hands in the beginning which is cool.. something different. We had a obvious set menu for our party. The soup and appetizer dish was pretty good.. and this pie like entree which was sweet and salty was good. I'm not a fan of lamb.. and that is obviously the meat they love to eat.. so I wasn't enjoying my main course.. Overall this place is pretty good.. just not a fan of lamb.
The belly dancer.. was old.. and creepy, but she was nice to me when she wasn't in dancing in her costume.
author: Tiff C.

description:
This is more of an attraction than an eating place.  As soon as you walk in, you know you're in for an experience.  

The decor is amazing.  It is so over the top, it can border on kitsch, but the authentic hand inlaid tables and the draped celling all seem to make it work.  

The best part about our dinner was the food.  The rabbit and the fish were two of my favorite dishes,and I really wished I could bring the lentil soup home with me.  We ate ourselves stupid, and everything was amazing.  It's a great place for a group dinner as well as a date.
author: Lisa R.

description:
So MUCH FUN!! Happy Bday Marcus! 

Marcus picked El Monsour for his bday. If you haven't been you must! It was sensational! 

Everything we ordered was fantab!! The lamb, the chicken... everything!! Although I must say my hubby had the lamb with honey and almonds and it was soooo good.. I couldn't stop picking at his plate. 

Have the leftovers for lunch today. can't wait!

Make sure your hungry.. Tons of food.

AND the entertainment.. 10 stars! Stasha was phenom! She was both talented and ohh soo hilarious! She really made the experience excellent!
author: Monica S.

description: Straight up the place was tiny! They made up for that immensely with their service, food, entertainment and hospitality. We went there for my friends birthday and I didnt even have to tell the gentleman who seated us my name, told him I had a reservation and he knew who I was immediately (and even pronounced my name right!) . The fact that he took the time to remember who has a reservation at certain times without looking in a book or on a computer amazed me.   When I made the reservation it was through a third party site and I mentioned it was my friends birthday never expected them to even notice that little note, after dinner was over they brought her a special birthday treat without anyone mentioning it that whole evening. The food was amazing, they bring you rose water to wash your hands and those are your utensils. They supply silverware, but the fun is in doing it the way it was meant, use your hands! It was family style, which means everyone shares off a plate in the middle except for individual entrees..And the tea! The hot tea was absolutely amazing! The belly dancer came on once while we were there, she was a ton of fun to watch, highly entertaining and absolutely stunning dancing. Never wanted for anything,it was quite relaxing, we spent close to 2 hours in there just enjoying the atmosphere and each others company.
author: Ferrell O.

description: been here twice now.  love the atmosphere...sooo fun.  the servers were very nice.  the belly dancer was really entertaining and since there was a good group of people in the restaurant who participated that made it a better experience.  my fave is the moroccan chicken pie and of course loved the moroccan mint tea.  the sampler is the best thing to order in a group so you get a bit of everything.
author: she q.

description:
I was really looking forward to a good friend's b-day at El Mansour.  I've eaten at many Moroccan places in the past, and always had a ton of food, fun, and good belly dancing.  Although the belly dancing was okay here, there wasn't much for me to rave about the food.

I will say that we had tasty soup, the salad was almost nonexistent in size (we had 8 people, 6 of whom paid for the full boat).  El Mansour doesn't let you order separately or have a fork, that's just not their way.

Instead our paltry feast came for 6 and there was barely enough food.  For over $32 each before tax, tip, drinks, etc., there was literally a tablespoon of cous cous each instead of a huge mound.  Some of the meats really tasted good, but I would have preferred my own plate, a fork and a mound of veggies and couscous for the high ticket price.

Additionally, the photos here really make this place look great!  We thought we were in for a treat, expected a bar and full service.  What we got was a one room, sort of faux Morroccan home sewn project with the local belly dancer.  It really wasn't worth it.

Oh, and parking SUCKS!  No one moves their cars in this neighborhood, so plan an additional 15 minutes to find the nonexistent spot.

~ Ms. Ali
author: A W.

description:
I've been coming to this outer Richmond landmark for at least 30 years.  You sit on cushion or a couch at a low table amidst a tent-like décor.  Eat with your hands but not to worry - before dinning, a waiter brings a pitcher and basin for all to wash their hands.  Dry your hands with an almost full-sized bath towel that also serves as your napkin.

Then the course after course of marvelously spiced foods begins to arrive.  Lentil soup accompanied by home-made bread, a plate of 4 salads including carrot, tomato, eggplant and cucumber (and more bread), a hot phyllo dough wrapped sweet cinnamon chicken pie and then, if you still have room, the main course of your choice from various chicken, lamb, fish, couscous and vegetable dishes.

While dinning, you'll be entertained by Stasha or one of her colleagues - all beautiful and accomplished belly dancers.  Make no mistake; these women are not there as sex objects rather they are friendly and non threatening hostesses who will entice you (whether you are 7 or 70) to come up and dance with them.

After dinner, another round of hand washing (with a sprinkle of rosewater) followed by elaborately served mint tea and fried bananas.  The food is always tasty and consistent.  The staff is always friendly and attentive.  

The parking is a little tough but you'll be glad to walk-off some of that food on the way back to your car.
author: Jeff F.

description:
Fun, fun!  I was here when they had a smaller restaurant a couple of doors down and loved it.  

Came back recently to bring out of towners to something memorable.  The place still looks the same, but much bigger than years ago and with the same vibrant decor and tent feel.  Still a great place for birthdays and now they can accommodate more people.  We called the day before for a Friday night dinner and they were able to accomodate us.  The staff is a lot friendlier and gracious than I remembered, so that was terrific.

Entree is served per person (unlike other places where everyone's order is in one big communal plate) and huge portions.  Rabbit and lamb was fabulous, though we didn't finish all.

The belly dancers are prettier than other places though not as skilled.  They dance at 7:30pm and at 9pm, so if you time your dinner well, you can see both performances.

Try it, you'll love it.  And for heaven's sake, tip the dancers!  Some of them are grade school teachers and moonlight as belly dancers.
author: Amihan M.

description:
Great place, awesome decor and excellent service. I will definitely go back here. The food was delicious!  The really great thing is the restaurant is really on top of portion control. I usually leave Moroccan restaurants feeling too full and unable to move, but El Mansour got it right. They use quality ingredients and given the many courses give you just enough food to keep you entertained and comfortable. The mint tea is amazing! Your best bet is to make reservations. 

Great experience and awesome way to celebrate an occasion. 

The belly dancer put on a wonderful show and it seemed to last a lot longer than other similar restaurants I have been to.
author: Olya S.

description:
Last year for my birthday we were crossing the Atlas Mountains to make our way into the Sahara before heading up to Fes. For my birthday this year, I wanted to revisit that Moroccan time, this time bringing along my friends. The staff was so accommodating in ever-changing head counts for my reservation and was incredibly nice throughout the whole night. One of the servers and I even had a great conversation about where he was from and what cities we've seen and want to see. 

We were all going over the menu and the owner suggested that each table could have a platter with a sample of various dishes, so we went with that (even though I really wanted to try the rabbit tagine). All of the food was as good as I remember, including the mint tea! My only disappointment was with the bread: the round, flat loaves in Morocco are heavenly and have not been recreated here.  

The most fun part of the night came when the belly dancer came out. She was beautiful and an amazing dancer. She had people from each of the groups of diners come up and dance with her, teaching us the moves. In our group, after the gals went up, she called up the guys to dance, too, which was hilarious and fun!

I will definitely go back, if for no other reason to try that rabbit tagine!
author: Amy B.

description:
Please do not even get me started on this place, came here for my birthday, there were 9 of us adults and we had 8:30 reservations. We walk in and notice the place is full and the belly dancer is Performing, which the belly dancer was fabulous. After about 5 minutes of waiting we finally get the attention of the server and tell him we have reservations, his response was, we are full when people leave, you sit down. It was rude! So after waiting another HOUR PAST our reservation time, we finally get seated. The busser starts bringing out our drinks and the first part of our food and they had not even come and washed our hands yet. 
All in all the service was atrociously horrible, the belly dancer was great and even got a few of us up there to dance with her, the busser was so so nice and did everything our rude, rude jerk of a waiter did not. The food was good, but very small portions. The menu also said they were going to have rabbit which we were all looking forward to trying and when our main course got there, we did not have rabbit, there was no warning of this, we had even made mention, that we were excited to try rabbit, to the very rude waiter and he never let us know we would not be getting it. The busser was the one who brought our food out to us and explained what everything was and apologized for there being no rabbit. At the end of our meal, they gave us our check and let us go on our way, not that I am into huge birthday songs or anything but that night, while we were there, we heard about 8 birthday songs to other people, I never got mine and my most wonderful sister made sure they knew it was my birthday so they had no reason not to celebrate it with me. 
They charged us $80 in gratuity which was absolutely ABSURD seeing as though the waiter never spoke more than 10 words to us, ignored us, and the busser took care of us the whole night. We tipped the busser appropriately and changed the tip to what we thought was fair for the server and left that exact change. The restaurant had the nerve to call us (they had the phone number from the reservations that they did not honor) and tell us that we owed them more money. The server might have been mad but he did not even deserve the $20 tip that he did get. We took care of the busser and the belly dancer, they were the ones who made the night any worth while. 
The server absolutely ruined this place for all 9 of us, which is a shame because they have decent potential, decent not great potential.
So I would say if you do not mind being ignored and treated like crap from a very rude waiter, and not having big enough portions for everyone in your group and do not mind leaving a little hungry still, then please have at it. I know I will NEVER EVER be back!!!
author: Sara H.

description:
I have been coming here for years with a particular friend who has almost always celebrated her birthday with Moroccan food. 
This is a good place for large groups due to the communal feasting set up and it never disappoints with the quality of the food and service.
If you live in the SF Bay Area and haven't tried this restaurant at least once, you're missing out.
author: Shivaun O.

description:
Amazing! I'm from the Netherlands, where you can find a lot of authentic Moroccan food and I must say, this is the best Moroccan Restaurant I've tried in the entire United States (not that I've been to all the Moroccan Restaurants, but from the once I've been to in New York, Seattle and San Francisco, this is the best). The food is super authentic (delicious) and the atmosphere is just great (it's exactly what I love about Morocco). Every night they have a belly dancer, and the staff is just super friendly. 

This is definitely different, and you must be prepared to eat with your hands (yes) and to sit on a couch while enjoying the dancers and the waiters wearing traditional Moroccan clothing in a dark restaurant. But it is amazing and you will definitely LOVE it. The owners actually do this as a side job, because they love it so much, you can totally notice that they enjoy their job, it shines through everything (food, decoration, friendliness, you name it). 

Go, try, and enjoy! :)
author: Helen D.

description:
Never been to Morocco before, but I think this is about as authentic as it gets in the states. In case you didn't know, you will be eating with your hands here. 

Meals are 5 courses and around $30 per person. I went with a group and we had a few bottles of wine and we were about $60 a pop after tip, but totally worth it! 

Before you eat the server brings out a huge container filled with water to wash your hands at the table and again at the end of dinner but with Rose water! Oh, Belly dancers; who doesn't like to have those around? 

Needless to say I had a great time, the food was awesome and I felt like I got more than my money's worth.
author: Blake H.

description:
So we went to El Mansour for two of my good friends birthdays (a girl and a guy.) This was my first time going and my friend (the girl)  who's birthday it was picked out the place. I did briefly skim a few reviews before going and the couple of things that stood out to me was 1) the price for the food was pretty pricey and 2) they had belly dancers Now back to #1, if the food is pricey, my only concern is that it better be good and there better be a lot of it. The belly dancers we'll get to later. 

Anyway, we got the restaurant at about 8:15 with about 13 of us and first off this place is like a hole in the wall on Clement. It has not windows or anything, just a sign over the two painted red doors. Going inside, the waiting area is really small its about 2 feet of space and your basically just crammed in there until you get called on by the host. With 13 of us plus other parties waiting to be seated, it did kinda get crowded fast. After waiting for about 20 minutes we were finally seat on plush couches with small round tables around us. Overall the atmosphere and seating was very comfortable. 

For a Saturday nite it was pretty packed and I can tell for a good reason. We ordered the food and the plates were priced around the $33-38 range. I was expecting this because of the reviews I read, so was not too worried. Overall the food was good, traditional Moroccan style dishes with scallops, chicken, lamb kabobs, uniquely made breads and of course the International beers that they carry, they really hit the spot. At the end of the nite, we racked up a bill between $700-800 or so, I did expect that as well with the amount of people we went with but at the end of the night, I was still kinda hungry and so were some of my friends. 

Simply put for the price, the food was good, but the amount was not. The amount of food per plate is pretty minimal, and it goes fast if your with a group of people. I understand its exotic unique delicacies and food will cost more, but that doesn't mean there should be less of it. That was probably the major thing that put me off to this place. Every dish that was brought out, I kept thinking was an appetizer, but really it was a main course dish! 

Lastly to the belly dancer, at first I was going in with low expectations thinking it was going to be some 40 yr old chick shaking her hips, but to my surprise she was pretty hot. Just picture Hilary Swank, but not really Hilary Swank, someone probably 10 times as hot has her and without her horse teeth. The dancer was hot, she knew how to move, and put on a great show with a couple of my friends even joining in on the fun,..I would say that kinda evens out the whole food thing. Overall, good experience I guess.
author: Nick P.

description:
The real chef must have escaped...this place 'used to' have the most authentic Moroccan food in the bay area (I lived in Morocco).   Now this restaurant is not much better than bland food court fast food.  'Salads' were dripping oily indistinguishable messes thrown together on some lettuce, had very little flavor - they all tasted the same.  Bistella was incredibly tiny - about 2 bites each, and all you could taste was the grease and powdered sugar it was smothered in.  Honey-prune 'chicken' (maybe a small cornish game hen, definitely not chicken) was well done, but drowning in a sweet gooey Chinese-style sauce and hidden under a handfull of sesame seeds.  Really?  The 'dessert' was inedible - battered, deep fried bananas that oozed oil when you touched the breading (Moroccan???) and a hard square thing with brown goo in the middle of the plate that they called kunafa (look it up - this had zero resemblance to the real thing).  Tea was warm sugar water - no tea at all - and way too sweet.

The napkins they gave are really hand towels - they were old, beat up (shredded and torn), stained and did not smell fresh.  None of the plates/dishes/glasses matched, glasses were smudged, not clean.  They brought funky forks that were corroded.

We were rushed through each course as if we were on a timer.  The minute the belly dancer was finished, the waiters were literally running to get everyone's payment.  When we tried to leave, It was hard to get outside because there so many people trying to get in at the same time.  

What happened to the table for the entire evening, 3 hour leisurely meal,  incredibly succulent North Africa flavors?  

I work hard for my money and don't mind spending $100 on dinner once in awhile, but it has to be worth it.

If anybody knows where the real chef is,  I would love to go there...won't be coming back to El Mansour.  Ever.
author: blue c.

description:
The ambiance is a great. The seating arrangement is also good. The food is good considering it was the first time I tried Moroccan. The service was also super friendly. For the price of each entree (a real 5 course meal) which I think is a steal, my favorite is the bread which is offered with the soup, salad and your main dish. Plus the dessert was great... As if all this was not enough, the belly dancer came out to put on quite a show and the show was very family friendly. 

I'd go back here in a flash. To think that this place has been here for so long in my neighborhood is surprising. I guess I need to eat out more often.
author: Marv M.

description: Nice first time experience.  Belly dancing and simple tasting menu.  Many of already wrote the positives and I agree.  The only thing I didnt like about this place was their fish.  It tasted like canned fish...definately not fresh.
author: Kimmy C.

description:
I came here on a Saturday night for a friends birthday. The food was really good. (I liked the rabbit.) The service was great. Everyone was really friendly and helpful.
The belly dancer was very talented... Don't forget to tip her.
author: C M.

description:
This restaurant/entertainment spot was a HUGE DISAPPOINTMENT ! WHAT A SHAME...IT HAS SOOO MUCH POTENTIAL! If, the OWNER/Management would revise and clean up this misleading/misrepresentation of a dinning/entertainment restaurant. Star #1, for beautiful setting, 2nd star for tasty food/friendly service. Bellydancing as like any other entertainment place should every hour between 7p.- at least 9 or 10p. The family dinner should not have to be shared like on their 2nd, 3rd and dessert, and still be charge as if, they all had their OWN 5 courses, which is prix fixed, $36.- $38.- Plus, they charge for the bread...$5.- and not even your own basket! The portion of the chicken brochette is a smallest and skinniest piece I ever seen on a skewer. I took my boyfriend there last Sunday for his birthday. No belly dancing entertainment, because she started earlier than scheduled, she was done for the evening by the time we already got there...which was 7:40P. ONLY ONE ON SUNDAY...LAME!. We would have left earilier when we found out there wasn't going to be anymore dancing, but, the waiter convinced us to stay, because he said since they're more people who came in after us they were going to try to have dance again. By,  the time we were done with our first entree..she(bellydancer) never talk to the manger/waiter again (saw her out in front part of the restaurant), and left out the door.  We heard other people by earshot complaining either about their tab or the non entertainment. Later, the waiter/manager told us she wasn't going to preform anymore and he was willing to comp. us on 2 drinks. I think for the beginning, he knew she wasn't going to stay, but, overheard my boyfriend and I talking about going to another place.
The evening was such a bust that MY BOYFRIEND felt so bad for me...he insisted to pay for 1/2 of his SUPPOSE TO BE...HIS SPECIAL BIRTHDAY/DINNER EXPERIENCE...$92.-.!!
I cannot recommend this place to anybody and already have told people of this bad experience. Good Luck to this place otherwise Good Riddens!
author: Claudette J.

description:
A MOROCCAN CHRISTMAS (Please see this episode of The Office--how can it be a coincidence? They write my life.)

This was my second time having Moroccan food (first time was at Morocco's in San Jose) and although the experience with this cuisine is getting better, I'm still not quite a fan.  I'm trying to be as impartial as I can while writing this.

It was very easy making a reservation a week before for a group of 9 for our work Christmas party.  We originally wanted to go to Aziza but they were booked completely for a private event.  We got to El Mansour at about 6pm on a Wednesday night and there were only two other small parties there.  Most of the night was pretty dead but I kind of liked the intimacy that our group got.  We sat in a lovely little corner on low rising sofas and little round cushioned seats.  The sofa is definitely better especially when the belly dancer comes out so you don't have to keep turning around.

Now the menu was very confusing.  They have two kinds of prix fixe menus which seem somewhat similar but different in price.  While our waiter was explaining everything to us, I was thinking of the Kitchen Nightmare episode where Gordon Ramsey went to Sebastian's (if you've seen this, you will know exactly what I'm talking about): "There are 26 different combinations... you can choose meat/seafood/veggie... you can put it in a pasta/sandwich/salad... blah blah."  In the end, we all chose the $32.75 menu which includes (in this order):

-Harira Soup (spicy lentil bean soup): A lot tastier than it looks; not spicy at all.  Reminded me of Indian daal but much thinner.  The waiter comes with around with a basket of thick slices of bread for you to eat with it.
-Salade Mohammed V (combination of tomatoes, eggplant, carrots & cucumbers): Very good!  The tomatoes were reminiscent of salsa, the cucumbers & carrots were crisp and refreshing, and the eggplant was more like a mushy dip.  Also comes with that same thick bread for you to top it with.
-Bastela du Chef (pastry filled with chicken, almonds, & spices): Sweet and salty!  I've noticed that these moroccans love cinnamon on everything even on what we're use to as salty dishes.  The ground chicken filling was very tasty... and the powdered sugar & cinnamon top offset it well.  The thing with these is that it was crisp and slightly hard to break through.  Some people eat with their hands here (they don't give you forks unless you ask) but I find that with this particular dish, a fork is well needed.
-Your choice of specialty entree (I chose RABBIT KEBAB!): Even though I've had rabbit meat before, I felt a little wrong eating this because they give you two hind legs. I could tell my rabbit did a good amount of running while he/she was alive because the meat wasn't as tender as I expected.  Texture is like chicken but the taste is definitely distinguishable.  Herbs on the outside were good but overall, the meat tasted a little off.
-Couscous & vegetables: I'm not a fan of cous cous to begin with but this is just a small ice cream scoop full. Veggies included zucchini, garbanzo beans, and carrots.  I wished they were blanched like in the appetizer but they were cooked longer and kind of soft.
-King Hassan (banana fritter): Tastes like the same kind you get at Thai restaurants.
-Keneffa (sweet bastela with cream and almonds): I really like the thin layer of cream in the middle!  It's got a cool temperature and tastes smooth on your tongue.
-The A La Menthe (mint tea): Watching the waiter pour this is more exciting than drinking it. It is VERY flowery and minty.

I don't know if the belly dancer comes out at the same time every night but it was nearing 9pm or so. She was fantastic and beautiful!  Since there were only three groups there, she danced around everyone and even got some of our guys to go up there and embarrass themselves.  You can put some money in her clothing but she won't take $1 so make sure you bring some $10 bills.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Best Moroccan food! The meal starts off with the server washing your hands in rose scented water. Then you get your lentil soup, which btw is the best, and I don't even usually like lentil soup! Next comes the salad which you will have to eat with bread as your utensils. The chicken cilicia is next, which is my favorite. It's really hot in the beginning so beware. I'm not sure what it is that makes the cillcia so good but it's sweet and salty at the same time! I usually order the honey lamb but the almond chicken is not bad either! The best part is of course the mint dessert tea and the banana fritters.

The ambiance of this place is incredible. Walking in, you will never guess what is behind those doors. I highly recommend coming to this place with friends, out of towners or even family. The couches are comfortable and the food is amazing. I will definitely be back whenever I have a chance to!
author: Tiffany U.

description: I was just there...again...last Saturday night with family; and it is as great as ever!  Of course, I ordered their lamb, with eggplant this time, which was super tender and deeeelicious; like always.  I really am amazed that every single time I go their lamb (that is all I order here, as I love it!) is so tender and delicious.  They are also so nice, helpful and funny.  This time there were a couple of tiny differences.  For example, they didn't use the rosewater on the second hand washing, which I loved :( and the cups and teakettle were different when they poured the delicious mint tea.  Rooooosssseewateeer! :(  Anyway!  They, including our neighbors (sorry?), were so nice, as we had two little girls with us who were running in and out of the restaurant the whoooole time.   I do say, it is a fun place for kids, as there is a belly dancer, but perhaps ones under the age of five might find it challenging to sit for the whole time!  ;)  Still amazing!
author: Delicious B.

description: We have been to this place twice and have enjoyed ourselves thoroughly. They have a multi course meal starting with a hand washing ceremony. Every course from the appetizer to the desert is elaborately prepared and  is an experience to cherish. They also have belly dancers which come around and help you work off some of the calories you have ingested. Highly recommended.
author: Neeraj S.

description:
So fun!!

We went here with some friends after trying to get into Aziza, and I think our night was better for it! We had no trouble getting a table for our party of 4 at 7:30 on a Friday.

Loved that it's a full, multi-course meal, loved the family-style dining, loved the no silverware, loved that it's more of an experience than just a meal. I had lamb and chicken for my entree -- both so well cooked, just fell off the bone. I generally don't like eating with my hands, but this was so good I didn't care.

The service was good, quite attentive and friendly, bringing food and bread and water for handwashing and pouring mint tea into our cups from 6 feet in the air. The belly dancer is also an awesome touch.

I don't know that I'd go here regularly, but it's definitely great for something different and a fun night out.
author: Megan D.

description:
i must make my way here again!

a few nights ago my comrades and i came here to celebrate the birthday of the eldest in our crew.  this place has low sofa and ottoman seating, so ladies, as fine as y'all look in those dangerous heels, kick them off or leave them in the car for later nighttime partying. the tables here are low, and you don't want your knees to be in the way of your eating pleasure.

also, all y'all eat with your hands here. alright? don't get all OCD wanting forks and spoons. wash your hands when and how you're told, and dig into the food with aplomb. using cutlery is like making love through an interpreter, a wise king/prince/someone majestic once said. and this is too true.

our feisty, aging table of 6 opted for family-style dining. started with an amazing lentil soup, in which we dunked pieces of bread. oh the lentil soup. i think of you still. call me.

a huge platter of eggplant dip, tomato chutney-like dip, and marinated slices of cucumber and carrot was served next. deeelish. we almost got full from this. watch the bread; there's much more food to come.

next, a pie of sorts with chicken filling, almonds, and a sweet pastry crust. GREAT JUICY HEAVENS this was delicious. i would recommend having an extra order of this.

the main course consisted of various types of meat (rabbit, beef, chicken, lamb), seafood (prawn, scallop), and couscous. the meats were cooked in different styles, some with honey and prunes, some with lemon, some with almonds, some with onions, and the seafood was in a spiced light sauce that was oh-so-dreamy. we dug in with our hands, cos we keep it real. the skewered chicken and beef were beautifully moist and perfectly charred. the 'wetter' dishes were flavorful in their own right, distinct and amazing.

EVERYONE WANTED THE RABBIT. got damn. so good, it hurts.

finished off with a fried banana dessert with a cream-filled pastry. gorgeous. the pulled mint tea that came with? sweet, refreshing, and rounded up the meal in boss fashion.

make reservations, folks. also, tip the belly dancer. she balances a sword on her head......TIP HER.
author: Eliza D.

description:
Went here with a party of 10 and enjoyed the food very much.  There was an abundance of food, and by the end of the night we were all completely stuffed.  The food itself was very delicious.  Highly recommended if this is your first Moroccan place.  The waiter was also very polite and filled drinks and brought extra bread very quickly.

The environment, on the other hand, was just "eh".  Could have been better, could have been worse.  It's literally one room thats decorated.  The belly dancer certainly needs to visit the gym a little more often.  And maybe take a couple more classes..

If you want somewhere with good food and decent environment, I recommend trying El Mansour
author: Barry A.

description:
Once you step into this place you feel transported to somewhere extravagant and exotic. I was particularly caught by all of the ornate details that are everywhere and just keep going.  It's dim lights, plush seating, and enticing smells set the perfect mood for a romantic dinner or a fun experience with friends.  Where else are you encouraged to eat with you hands?!  Which, of course, goes with their table-side rosewater hand washing...a personal fav of mine.

All of the food is well seasoned, tasty, and amazing!  One of the dishes that still blows my mind is the Bastela.  A savory app of shredded chicken wrapped in phyllo and finished with powdered sugar!  Weird you say?!  No my friend, amazing!  I was licking my fingers the whole way through my lamb and chicken entrée, the gf's scallops and prawns, and that ridiculously flaky dessert.  Top it all off with a mint tea pour that rivals the water show at the Bellagio?! ...okay so I might have exaggerated about that last bit but it is quite impressive.  

This place definitely gets my recommendation.  El Mansour is just as tasty as it was four years ago when I took the gf here for Valentines.
author: Isaiah M.

description: I took my daughter and 3 friends here for her 18th birthday last week and we could not have been happier. Great atmosphere, excellent service, awesome food and incredible bellydancing! Everything was perfect. Could not have been happier. Love this place, great for a celebration. They have a set price menu where you choose your main entree and they do all the sides for you... I don't know how their food rates compared to genuine Moroccan cuisine but we enjoyed every dish... soup, salads, appetizer, cous cous, desert and mint tea... wonderful. I love this place and my daughter and her friends had a blast.
author: Sarah S.

description: I went here for a work function.  I was pleasantly surprised at how good the food was. Really really tasty and unique. I loved the chicken appetizer that was also sweet. The mint tea was awesome, and loved that they had decaf. The eating with your hands thing always freaks me out a bit but...when in Rome.  The soup was great, as was the salad all the way through dessert. And the belly dancer was entertaining.   I will be back.
author: Andrea R.

description:
Yes, I've eaten the rabbit.

We went here for a friend's birthday a little awhile ago.  I absolutely loved the interior with all the rugs and tapestries.  There were no bare walls and you really felt like you were whisked away to some Morrocan dining area.  We sat in a corner near the door where there were basically padded benches situated around a table.

The food was excellent and the ambience was really warm and inviting.  The food came out in good time and to top it off, the belly dancer came out.  She was a little older but still attractive, and when she found out it was our friend's birthday, she was all over him like white on rice (see pics).  We all proceeded to get into it and took our turns dancing with the half-nekkid lady while other groups around the restaurants clapped and hollered.

You should definitely try this place out.  If not for the rabbit, or the belly dancer, then simply for the engrossing experience.
author: Dave K.

description:
I can't believe it's taken me so long to review this place! I've been here a number of times with a variety of groups and El Mansour always comes through. 

If you're looking for a total escape dinner, this is it. You sit on pillows, eat with your hands, there's a belly dancer mid-meal, and the mint tea at the end of the night makes you feel like there's no way you're having dinner in San Francisco. 

The food is delicious. The wine is very reasonable (go for the Moroccan wines!) and the staff is always happy to help. Oh man, I think it's about time I go back! I'm smiling just writing this review!
author: Kate P.

description:
I recently came here for the first time to celebrate my mom's birthday. The place not very big was decorated nicely and everything seemed clean and in good condition. You sit on comfortable couches which for me was a new experience. The food is great. A big variety to choose from. The service was good nothing to complain about. The bellydancing is what makes the experience what it is. A lot of fun and don't be shy to dance but just make sure you tip  in a place where isn't considered private :).
