The only con really is don't expect to eat a cheap dinner. A group of 16 cost over 800. You should call and reserve your seats to be safe. Overall, I think you should try out the place.
Pro- Great food, good customer service, fun and nice atmosphere.
Con- Price
author: Nick C.

description:
The ambiance in this restaurant will take you into a different world. You will find yourself sitting inside a sultans tent receiving royal services while sitting on flush velvet pillows. They start you off with a rose water hand wash then you dive into a shared style eating with your hands. The food is a feast for taste and other senses. The belly dancer and live band always can get the crowd to interact. Even my 4 year old girls got up and got their belly dancing 101.
You must order the Bastela Du Chet. This sweet savory dish is so unique, there's nothing like it. It's a combination of dessert and an chicken entree in one. Keep your eyes peeled while the guys pours you your mint tea from a Moroccan kettle while standing up. It's a performance within itself. It's amazing how he does not miss the tea cup. I recommend this place over and over again.
author: Rhodora E.

description:
This is a *great* date night place!

Stepping into the restaurant is like entering a new world. The furnishings are all velvet and plush everywhere you look. The lights are low, but good enough that you can see fine.

The food and tea are divine. We were encouraged to eat with your hands and the food really can get all over, especially if you go for the poultry dishes like we did. 

The belly dancer's fun and obviously enjoys dancing there. She was great at pulling out the shy people and teaching a group of almost-teens girls how to belly dance.

There is no outside seating.
author: N M.

description:
Yay! What fun!

It's not just a meal, it's an experience. The dinner comes in courses. Everyone shares, except for the main course which everyone chooses their own.

Dinner and a show, both rolled into one. Some people may not understand it, but whatever, more room for me!

I highly disagree with anyone who says that this place isn't good for kids. If you have a couple small children in your party, they will love the environment with all the pillows and carpets, and they will have lots of fun dancing with the belly dancer!

I was pleasantly surprised by the food. I went here with my auntie and uncles and when they said "Moroccan" I was kinda worried because I don't usually like Middle Eastern food (and I HAAAATE Indian food). But, this style of cuisine was very mild to eat, and very fruity/sweet in some cases. Also, the mint tea at the end was delightful and expertly poured. I read on the Wiki that the Moroccan mint tea is very artistically brewed, and that the ritual of drinking it together with family is important in Moroccan culture.

I think I would like to go back next time with a couple drinks in me, so that I can be brave enough to dance with the belly dancer. I recommend you do the same. And don't forget to bring some $1 bills. w00t!
author: Rachel H.

description:
The restaurant itself is an extravagance of Moroccan tile and fountains topped by a tented ceiling. The restaurant was built forty years ago and the decor never changed, so there is the tinge of faded romance in the air.

 
Sadly, the quality of the offerings ends with the atmosphere as the meal portions are small for the price, and one of the signature dishes of Morocco, Merguez Sausages is not on the limited menu. 


I have been here three times and can only recommend this place for atmosphere, service and belly dancing, so its great for a crowd that wants to party with belly dancers. There are other better, reasonably priced Moroccan restaurants in town, so I just can't recommend going here for the food.
author: Peter M.

description:
I came here for a birthday and was shocked by how empty the place was. I remember five years ago it was completely filled, but there was only one belly dancer present.  Oh well. She got 3 out of the 4 friends to dance. I'm not sure how I ended up on the floor since I only needed mild convincing. Oh, but its just me and I don't care if I act a fool from my lack of hip movement and my random octopus swaying arms. 

Anywho, the place is gorgeous as I remember because it looked like a harem. It slipped my mind we ate with our hands, but I think the staff overheard and provided forks for one of my ocd inclinded friend.  Our waiter was extremely nice and I couldn't stop staring at his mc hammer pants.  I kinda wanted him to bust out Michael Jackson moves, while he pour mint tea into our cups.  I love the tea by the way! I had seconds and it was sweet!  

The first time I ever had lamb was at this place and it was so awesome I decided to try it elsewhere.  Epic Fail!  So I anticipated the lamb here, but it wasn't too my liking.  It was better than most, but my memory had put El Mansour's lamb on a pedestal. Bummer. Aside from the lamb, they had Bastela du Chef, which was this flaky pastry with chicken inside.  The waiter said it was everyone's favorite and I liked it well enough.  I had to rave about their lentil soup because I wanted to lift the bowl up and lick it clean!
author: Amy L.

description:
My second trip here and it's still one of the funnest places to be. 
I love how they designed the place to look like what you would find in Morocco. I loved the Lentil Soup. I had the Moroccan Seafood which was great. The rose tea was tasty. Of course the belly dancing was VERY entertaining and the main reason we chose this place. I don't think there's another place in San Francisco that offers belly dancing entertainment with meals. The only thing I have to learn, is how to eat with my fingers. And having a big towel as my napkin.  But that was supposed to be part of the Moroccan experience, which I failed. :(  Luckily though, I was able to talk them into, a fork, spoon and knife. :)
author: Ms. T.

description:
i thought it was going to be not too great because places like this can be a tourist trap. But, love the location it was not in downtown so the parking wasn't too bad. The food was surprisingly REALLY amazing! the service was kind of slow, but I understand because it's a progression of courses. I was waiting in line to use the restroom, but i was very turned off by the man who was serving tea because he was chatting it up with some one in the kitchen and made a comment about how there's two more groups and they were not leaving. He was actually kind of giving us attitude when he was serving us, but that just put the cherry on top of his crappy server-ness. but other than that, the belly dancing was really fun! the good was delicious, and the company was awesome! great birthday dinner! 

oh! ps. just reminded me because of the good for kids section down here while you are typing up the review, there was a family with a bunch of kids under the age of 10, and this tiny little boy kept on wanting to stick dollar bills in the belly dancer's waist....it was kinda awkward. It was cute the first time, but the weird kid kept on wanting to do it over and over again, and made the dancer stop dancing for long whiles because he wasn't doing it fast enough! geeeesh. good for kids? oh hellz no.
author: Hanna K.

description:
I had wanted to eat at El Mansour since driving by it's ornately decorated storefront.  once inside, you will not be disappointed....it is lavishly decorated in all kinds of textiles from Morocco.  

Mo was our server and he was warm, friendly, and attentive.  We wrapped up our meal just before the belly-dancer began her routine (thankfully, I'm not big on the spectacle associated with that, but appreciate those who are).  

Back to the dinner....take note - go hungry!  The lentil soup was one of the best I've ever had.  I filled up on that alone.  Then....the bastela....it just about put me over the top before our delicious main dish arrived!

I like that you are able to order different entrees - it's not always the case at a traditional Moroccan restaurant.

As if you're not already stuffed from salad, lentil soup, bastela, entree...then you get TWO desserts and a tea?  Incredible!  The pricing is more than fair ($30/entree), the food is delicious, the service is attentive and warm, and the overall experience is one not to be missed!
author: Heather L.

description:
i haven't been to el mansour in a LONG time. i think i've changed since then, because the food was not as good as i remember. it was good but not amazing. the fish i got was SO salty that it gave me horrible indigestion. but this isn't even the worst part of my recent visit to el mansour! 

one of my friends (who had to leave a bit early) never got her main course before she had to leave, due to a "mix-up in the kitchen." she waited about 30 minutes, before she realized she would not have time to eat it, and would have to leave instead. 

long story short: man comes over with her bill, which is $20. we argue that it doesn't make sense since she only got the first 3 (small and unremarkable) courses. his response "it does make sense" (insistently, several times), so we paid it. i am pretty sure this guy was the manager, and if that's how he runs a business, then that's just beyond wrong.  it was el mansour's fault, not my friends'. she shouldn't have had to pay anything. 

needless to say, we slipped our main waiter some money and told him to pocket it, as i didn't want the tip to go to anyone else. he apologized several times after i told him we had numerous issues with our meal.

other bad things:
service was very slow.
they nearly forgot one of our courses and we had to remind them twice to remember to bring it.
we were surrounded by rude, drunk, obnoxious people.
the food was mediocre and the wine overpriced.

never again.
author: Kate W.

description:
Went here for a b'day dinner and had a great overall experience. 

The positives: The ambience was great, decent wine selection and a great belly dancer.

The negatives: The food was good but the quantity just didn't seem enough. I know my hubby was still hungry. I'm not sure if our server didn't order enough for our party (we were a large group) or what the issue was.
author: P From CA C.

description: Awesome. Amazing service and fantastic food. Great dancer. Had the combination platter to share family style. We came in for a late reservation and they were amazingly friendly and flexible.
author: Will H.

description: While it sounds lovely and the food is good, be well aware that there is only a $36-38 per head prix fixe so come very hungry, and the belly dancing music is loud enough that you can no longer hold conversation. In fact I had to leave the restaurant as it was triggering a migraine because it was so overpowering.
author: C B.

description: This place is a brothel. The food is mediocre and sparse for the high price tag. The group next to us was loud and sat on my jacket and progressively scooted over our way until we were almost pushed off the bench! I did not find the belly dancing to be in good taste, and the music was so loud we couldn't hear eachother talk. If it's good Moroccan food you're looking for, don't come here.
author: Ashley S.

description:
Fun!  Great for groups or a lively evening out!

The food is tasty!  I wouldn't come back for the food necessarily - but more for the entire experience: great service, good food,  Service was excellence.  Dancer was engaging and boy could she move!
author: Deanna A.

description:
Came for my birthday with a group of about 10 people. We had our own little corner. All the other groups were also there for dinner since we saw birthday songs sung throughout the night, maybe 5 times.

Food: Great! I had the lamb with eggplant, and it was very good. Tried my friend's rabbit and that was very flavorful. Like chicken but much better and more flavorful. The meals also came with lentil soup, salad consisting of tomatoes, eggplants, cucumbers, and carrots, bread, filo dough thing with chicken inside covered with powdered sugar, mint tea, and fried banana dessert. All were super yummy. You share the salad, dessert, and filo dough chicken thing with others. With the 10 of us, they brought us 3 plates, which made it easier.

Service: Great! The only weird thing was someone would come by with a basket of bread and we each grab one and then he takes the basket with him, then comes back later as we got something else that we could dip into. I guess we wouldn't overload on bread that way and it wouldn't take up too much space. They were very nice, didn't come by too often as to disrupt our meal, nor not come enough. We stayed until 11, an hour beyond their closing time, and were the last group to leave (same as Millbrae Karaoke House) and we didn't even feel pressure from them to kick us out. Just realized that all other people were gone, and my friend noted they had closed an hour earlier.

Belly-dancing: The woman was great! Ok, everything is great. I know. People sitting on the outside were embarrassed and didn't look at her at times to avoid her thrusting herself on them or being asked to dance with her. Very entertaining, and boy, can she move. She danced with individual people from all the other groups, and finally came to our group. My friends wanted me to dance with her since I was the birthday girl, and I was too embarrassed and wasn't going to get up at all, so she told all the girls to get up and dance with her. Two of my friends came with me, and she re-assured me that it wouldn't be embarrassing, and it was actually a lot of fun. Just kind of made us hold hands, move our feet, spin like a ballerina, shake our hips (she said that was for the waiters! :D), etc. Glad to know she can adapt to her audiences.

What else? Great place for birthdays! Fabulous service, food, entertainment, not overly expensive. What else can you ask for?

I guess I can rave some more, but I guess that's it. Toodles.
author: Anita C.

description:
I like this place well-enough, but I just don't think the price is worth it. It's about $40 a person, and more if you get drinks or whatever. Let me break it down in a mix of goods and bads: 

First, we had a bigger party (about seven people) for my friend's birthday get-together. We made a reservation, but we were not seated for over an hour. Horrible. The place was crowded and I understand that there is the belly-dancing show and whatnot, but we were just sitting there and nobody really came to talk to us. No good. 

Next, when we were seated, the lentil soup helped me get over the initial negativity. This was probably THE BEST lentil soup I've ever had, and I love lentil soup. HOWEVER, when we asked for some more of their delicious bread (you eat the soup with this warm, spongey-but-not-moistly-so bread, not a spoon), the waiter practically shouted, "you won't be able to finish the meal!" and not in a joking or laughing way, but in a gruff and borderline rude way. Maybe I don't get his sense of humor, but at least show us you're poking fun at us with a smile. And even if it's serious advice (which was good advice, given how heavy the food was), please be nicer about it. And note: I was able to eat my entire meal, despite the extra bread, small Asian girl that I am. 

Next, they ran out of the fish on the menu, which I understand I guess, but that was kind of a disappointment for some members of our party who wanted it. I did end up getting the fish, and it was fine for me, but my other friend who got it had an extremely fishy, briny taste to her fish. Seriously, it even smelled like the ocean. Not very appetizing. My friend who wanted the fish, and who got chicken skewers instead, had better luck. The chicken was well-marinated, tender, and very tasty. 

I don't really remember if we got dessert, but I do remember that there was a big bottle-service fee so we didn't end up opening our wine.

Finally, the belly dancing was very fun and provided for awesome entertainment. That part was definitely fun. 

So overall, the food is above average, but there are lots of hits and misses, so it's kind of risky. I like consistency in the quality of my food, and I didn't find it here. Most of all, I do not like paying a hefty sum for this kind of inconsistency, so my recommendation is try El Mansour if you're in the mood for Moroccan, but be wary of some of their dishes and their service.
author: J. L.

description:
Overall 2 Stars for the following reasons:

Food: We decided to go for the prefixed menu and got the following...

Course 1: Lentil Soup - This may have actually been my favorite portion of the meal. It was delicious, but the serving size was so small. 

Course 2: Salads - This was an extremely underwhelming dish. Not only were the salads smaller than what you would normally get in a pint size at a grocery store but they were anything but fresh. To compensate for the small serving of watery salads they continuously brought over loaves of bread that was good but not anything that would blow you away. This was one of the most disappointing salad platters that I have ever had at a restaurant period.

Course 3: Moroccan Meat Pie - This is a general dish that I have had at several Moroccan restaurants. The dish is normally one of my favorites. At El Mansour it was tasty but not incredible by any means. For the first time all meal I did feel like we got a decent serving size, which was nice.

Course 4: Meat and Seafood Combination - This dish was tasty, but again nothing that would make you come back begging for more of it. The shrimp and the lamb were the best parts of the combination plate. I found the chicken to be rather dry and lacking in flavor. The presentation of this dish was easily the best of the night. Unfortunately, it just did not have enough unique flavor to it in my opinion.

Service: The waiter was extremely friendly and the owner was a very nice gentleman. The belly dancer was definitely and added bonus and really kept the atmosphere lively.

Noise: Oh MAN! This place needs to do something about their speakers. They are outdated, project static, and are turned up way too high. Multiple times during my meal I felt like I was yelling to the person across the table.

Ambiance/Setting: The overall ambiance is fun/cool, however, you can definitely tell that it is a little bit outdated. The seats were rather uncomfortable for people that are tall. I enjoyed what they were trying to do with the whole room, but again the place needs a face lift.

Price: This place is not cheap. Most likely you are looking at in excess of $50/person.

Overall: In accordance with the YELP rating guide, I would describe this as a "Meh. I've experienced better." Quite frankly, I do not think I will be going back as I was not tremendously impressed by the food enough to pay the price. It may be fun for a group setting because of the way that you sit, eat the food, and can watch a belly dancer. There are much better places to go in San Francisco with a group, though, that are more affordable and much more delicious.
author: Bennett D.

description: This has been my favorite restaurant for many years. I love the atmosphere.  The food is amazing. The service perfect!  But, most of all it's the dancer named Stasha that keeps me coming back for more.  She is wonderful and innovative as well as incredibly talented.  I had another wonderful dinner there last night and it was memorable.
author: Norah M.

description: My husband and I wanted to try something new for our anniversary so we checked yelp and based on the reviews chose this place. When you see it, the restaurant seems rather small from the outside but when you get inside it is very cozy with cushioned benches and stools lining the entire restaurant. We had a 9:30 reservation and arrived a little after 9pm, the restaurant was packed and it took about 15 minutes for anyone to even acknowledge we were standing in the doorway, which was a bit frustrating. Once we got seated the wait staff were very friendly, they had someone come out with a kettle and bowl to wash our hands with then they took our drink and food orders. The meal was great! they start you out with a spicy lentil soup and bring out a big plate of bread that gets shared with everyone in the restaurant which was totally new to me but I went with it. Then you get your Moroccan version of salad which was chopped up eggplant, tomatoes, and some other veggies. Finally time for the main course,  I ordered the almond chicken and lamb and my husband ordered the rabbit. Both were Delicious! The lamb and chicken were so tender they were falling apart. The dishes all had just the right amount of spices, I will say though I wasn't expecting so much food! I thought the chicken and lamb would be half portions of each and man was I wrong! LOL just when my poor stomach couldn't take anymore, here comes this AMAZINGLY delectable desert! Two banana filled frittatas and another pastry with layers of light crispy goodness filled with custard. Along with the desert you are served hot green tea (as if your stomach could fit anything else in it).  In addition to the fantastic food and authentic atmosphere, you are entertained during your meal  by a belly dancer dancing  to moroccan music, crowd participation is highly encouraged :-) This place is a little bit pricey with your options being either a $32 meal or $35 meal per person, but it is absolutely worth the experience!
author: Amanda T.

description:
Okay, let's face it. We all want these places to be fun and kitschy and over the top. But, when you're paying $60+ for your meal and some wine, you expect something decent in the food department.

Nothing was terrible--in fact, the lamb kabob part of my dinner was tasty (all three pieces of it)--but if you're not going to serve pita then give us utensils. The Safeway bread chunks don't cut it. Eating couscous with my fingers reinforced my faith in Western Civilization. The appetizers and salad were sub-par. I liked the lentil soup, but my entree (lamb and bruchette kabob) was really difficult to eat as served.

I liked the entertainment (aka belly dancer), but the 30 minute wait for our 8pm reservation was a bit much.

But, if you're looking for overpriced kitsch and mediocre food in San Francisco, then El Man Sour might be the place for you.
author: Todd X.

description: I wasn't very impressed with this place. The interior is pretty, but the food is a little off. They brought us a ton of food and the only dish that was good was my lamb and honey with almonds. It fell off the bone and had a ton of flavor. Everything else was pretty mediocre at best. My friend and I were able to watch a belly dancer perform (my life story) and I got to see a bunch of old people make idiots of themselves :P so it created great entertainment for the night. It was a nice touch that the servers personally wash our hands the traditional way, and they also sprinkle rose water on us after (amazing). Overall, I would probably skip this place because after being spoiled at Aziza, which is in the relative neighborhood, I can't eat anything less. Aziza is so superior to this place.
author: Sheeva G.

description:
No one in our party of three have had Moroccan food before El Mansour and it was way beyond anything I had expected.  I found the set menu to be an excellent value.  About $32 gets you a five course meal with excellent portions and unlimited freshly made bread.  The belly dancer was also pretty cool and engaging.  

The mean begins with a brief primer on Moroccan food if needed followed by your server bring by a pot of hot water to wash your hands with.  After the meal he'll do the same followed by some nice rose water.

I don't think anything I had was bad by any means, though I think the Lamb kabob was a bit better than our Rabbit or Chicken and Onion entrees. 

Pros:
-Excellent quality food.
-Eat with your hands!
-Belly dancers!
-Outstanding value set menu.

Cons:
-The belly dancer may call you to dancer with her!
author: Hans -.

description: Came here under the recommendations of fellow Yelpers and once again they are right. It's off the beaten path but worth the drive. Everything was delicious. From the lentil soup to mint tea. Even the hand wash water smells lovely.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Belly dancing is always enjoyable to watch while eating tasty food IMO. We came for a birthday party and it was a lot of fun. Low seating, so if that is an issue you may want to pick another place. Food was good and the atmosphere is even better! Great place for a special occasion like a birthday. The have yummy rabbit dinners, chicken, lamb and vegetarian too.
author: Cheryl T.

description: Great atmosphere and cuisine... It is authentic food, a little pricy, but great food... My wife and I always frequent this place when celebrating something big... It has sentimental value to us.
author: Omar A.

description:
This place rocks! I've been here twice ( I think it used to be called Pasha a few years ago) & both times have been a great experience!  The decor makes you feel like u got there on a camel & the music makes you want to do a shimmy!
The food was tasty- a bit pricey- but pretty good portions!
The belly dancer was very beautiful & encouraged guest participation! 
I love belly dancers & can't wait to learn how to do the belly roll! hot! :)
This place is definitely a fun, different type of restaurant that i highly recommend! 
The waiter encouraged us to stay the whole night for this place turns into a lounge or something- but unfortunately the friends I was with were too tired from the day trip in Napa.....however I wonder how the nightlife here gets..hmm
p.S. they need to serve alcoholic beverages
author: Aida D.

description: Well 4 stars for Stasha who was the belly dancer on the night I had dinner with my friend.  Yay for Stasha.. she was really good with entertaining.. Food pretty much was A-ok.  If you order their specialty or the entree pretty much the serving is same except for the main course.  All the others like salad, bastella, tea, dessert is the same.  The ambiance is really nice and feels like u r inside a tent.
author: Hema K.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco my whole life and never knew this restaurant existed. My friend had her birthday dinner here on a Wednesday night with about 20 people. Once most of her party was here, we ordered our entrees, since the appetizers and dessert were the same for everyone. 

Because this is a Moroccan restaurant, you have to eat with your hands! When the soup came, there were generous amounts of bread given to each person. At first I didn't think that 1 piece of bread was enough to finish my soup so I asked for another piece. BAD CHOICE! Next course was the salad, and again more bread! The so called salad was a bunch of mush on top of a piece of lettuce. At this point, it was getting a bit hard to eat with your hands. If the salad was chunkier or had bigger pieces than I think it would be alot easier. Another dish came, which was a pastry with chicken inside... not too bad, but almost tasted like a dessert.

For my entree I had the chicken and lamb combo, which wasn't too bad. The lamb was very tender and the chicken was pretty juicy. Some of us were not use to eating with our hands, so we opted for some good ol fashioned utensils. ;) Oh, and did I mention they offer more bread?

For dessert, we had this banana fritter, which was OK, nothing special. We also had Mint Tea that was quite refreshing.

The highlight of the dinner was the belly dancer, who was very charming and interactive with everyone. If you like tons of bread and to eat with your hands, this is the place for you!
author: Cheryl C.

description:
El Mansour is more than just food -- it's an experience.  You don't do yourself justice if you evaluate this restaurant on the food alone.  From the instant you walk into the restaurant you feel like you are transported to Morocco.  You won't find any traditional tables and chairs.  Instead the restaurant has more of a lounge feel with small tables, sofas, and pillows all under a large tent.  The authentic Moroccan decor, combined with very polite service and a skilled belly dancer made me feel like I was in a Moroccan palace, not a restaurant in SF.

El Mansour's menu is impressive.  Our entrees were accompanied with lentil soup, salad, a chicken appetizer, dessert, and tea.  It's all wonderfully prepared and has some unusually great flavors.  We tried the lamb with honey and almonds on the recommendation of the owner.  It was some of the tenderest lamb I ever had and combining it with honey produced an incredible sweet and savory dish that is unlike anything I've had elsewhere.  I can say the same about all the dishes -- the flavors just pop in unique and interesting ways.

The next time you want to make a special occasion really special, think about going to El Mansour.  It will leave an unforgettable impression.
author: Brent V.

description:
The food here is above average and it has a myriad of choices.
It is also flavorful, so Definitely worth a visit.

So why am I giving it such average starage? Well, we made reservations for 10 in our group. So in we come, say our name, and get ready to be seated. NOT. they lacked seats so we had to wait a good 15 minutes to be seated. ANNOYING. I thought the point of having seats reserved is so that you can just go in, sit, and eat. Ugh. fail.

As far as belly dancing goes, however, El Mansour has the best i've seen in all the Morrocan/Mediterranean restaurants I've been. I mean, here, they invite you to dance with them, something i find funny and very entertaining. So definitely worth a go to for food and fun. Oh, and the whole tent vibe totally adds to the fun. woohoo. Just dont expect to be seated asap if you have a reservation and you arrive at dinner time.
author: Gabe R.

description: Belly dancers are friendly, ambiance is festive moroccan and fun!
author: J H.

description: I love this place! I have been twice, once in a big group and once on a date,  and both times were much fun! The food is amazing, belly dancing is interactive, and atmosphere is cozy. I can't wait to go again!
author: C. G.

description:
Overall, a decent dining experience-- Maybe I just expect more.

We had a birthday dinner for my mom with a party of 12 people. We made reservations in advance and were promptly seated. The atmosphere of this place is great: great decor and interesting seating. There were a few grannies in our group, so they were grateful to have couches and stools rather than floor pillows as I teased they would have (there were many jokes about picking them up using fork lifts, beached whale jokes, etc.). 

The food was satisfactory:
The lentil soup was tasty, but as my 14 year old sister pointed out, it tasted like progresso. There was nothing unique about it in the least. 
The chicken with vegetables that I ordered was delicious. The sauce was flavourful and the chicken was tender. While my entree was great, my father, who ordered the seafood entree has had some less than favourable results.... his stomach has been upset for the last few days. I'm just glad I'm not the one who has to clean the bathroom. My sister and I both have had some serious cumin-burps since we left the restaurant. The food was tasty, but man, does it stick with you. 

The most disappointing thing about this restaurant was the wine list. They only had wine in the 30-40$ range (which equivocates to about a 10-15$ bottle outside of a restaurant, a cheapass bottle of wine for my mothers birthday). THEN, they had an oddball 300$ bottle of wine. This strange selection made it difficult to get a nice glass of wine to compliment our meal. 

A note about the bread: they carry around huge bread baskets and offer you a slice with every course. With a large party, I wonder why they didn't just leave the bread with us... do you not trust us with the bread? Are you worried that we're going to eat all of your bread? I don't understand. In addition, we felt very rushed into ordering. We wanted to have leisurely drinks and enjoy the atmosphere (the belly dancing was great) but the waitress insisted we order everything at once. You would think with the purchase of 12 entrees at 35$ each AND the purchase of alcohol, the waitress would be more accommodating. Our water glasses were always empty, and they didn't offer refills of soft drinks for the kids. We also noticed that we were getting the same portions of appetizers for 4 people, as some tables of 2 were getting. That wouldn't normally bother me, if it weren't for the EXTREMELY steep price of the entrees. The bill totalled to about 700$.... I would expect to leave that restaurant fat, lazy and satisfied. Which I was not. 

The ambience is nice, the food is okay, the prices are ridiculous, the overall experience is just "meh."
author: Andi H.

description:
A paradise of finger foods. Gyrating women in bedazzled bras helps puff up the review too. Note to all business owners, this effect applies to anything. Bedazzled bra clad women gyrating on BART? Hell yeah my commute just improved. Who cares about a fare increase? I'm riding with a pocket full of extra singles! 

I went with a group for a New Years Eve belly-dance the old year away dinner. El Mansour had a relaxed and unique ambiance and a delicious menu of finger foods. The best part might have been the unique aspects of the Monsour experience. Specifically, the fun of having your hands washed with rose water, the artful pouring of mint tea, and best yet, seeing random strangers embarrass themselves by trying to belly dance. Really the last part is key. 

Food and a show. You get to eat with your hands. You get to laugh your ass off at someones awkward father who wants to shake it next to a Shakira clone. Can you blame him?
author: Aaron M.

description: Went here last night for a birthday dinner. It was nice, but pretty expensive. Our reservation was for 6PM, for a group of 20. Is there normally a time limit on something like that? The food was a good representation of Moroccan cuisine. Not sure what any of the names of dishes were, but there was a lot of meat and eggplant represented. The lamb was well cooked. There was entertainment in the form of a belly dancer. There were a lot of people going up and dancing with her. I'd have to say, one real belly dancer is better than 7-8 untrained amateur dancers. Wet blanket? No. But for $50/person, just give me the real deal.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Had reservations at 8pm.  Showed up at 810pm to be greeted by an old man in white that didn't even ask the name on the reservation but said he'd take care of us.  We were dumb enough to wait until 9pm until we finally left to go next door and eat(highly recommend pagan).

I don't even think they cared that we had reservations but it seemed like the type of establishment that just told you yes to get you in thinking they could get people in and out but this was not the case.  

Fail el mansour.
author: Henry H.

description:
We had reservations here for our friend's birthday so early arrival and no waiting. We were kindly directed to a comfortable seating area where the seats and tables sat low. The ambiance is peaceful and the decor is lovely. One would feel like they aren't in San Francisco anymore. We ordered the family style platters which included soup with bread, same sort of dip/salad, a big shared meat dish, and ended the dinner with dessert and sweet mint tea. All was yummy! The food is here very good (but hey, I love ethnic food). I can't say the same for my party who complained about dinner and wanted Jack in the Box afterwards. 

The waiters here are attentive and does everything in routine. We were entertained with belly dancing before the main meal arrive. Enjoyed the foreign music and was provided with great entertainment. Can't complain. 

This place gets packed so make reservations or arrive early and wait. The prices here are reasonable. I would come back again...
author: Dee T.

description:
Celebrated my birthday in this restaurant. I was thinking it would be a quiet affair, but turned out really lavish and unexpectedly very eventful. It was a Sunday evening and we were seated promptly upon arrival. The ritual started with the hand-washing ceremony using rose water. Then the four-course meals were presented in intervals, starting from soup, salad, bastilla (which was awesome) and the entree and finally the mint tea (a must). Everything was made to perfection and the food tasted  de-li-cious. The service was also very refreshing. To our surprise, there was a belly dance performance by a wonderful lady who stole the crowd's awe and got me dancing to the Arabic flavor. Overall, had a wonderful evening thanks to my husband's great recommendation and 'El Mansour's' food & service.
A 'savory' Moroccan place!
author: Lisa H.

description: I've come to this lovely place a few times and I just LOVE IT! Food is yummy and the staff is very nice. The only thing I have to complain about is the floor not being as clean as it should be.
author: Cat M.

description:
Wowzers...from tasty treats to dancing beauties this place has it all. Once you enter La Mansour you are transported to Morocco. The tasty vittles will knock your socks off. The place is a bite pricey at about $50 per person when I went for a Valentine's Day special. We were served several courses and had our hands washed at the table. I loved the rose oil at the end of our meal.

The food was well-prepared and the decor was outstanding. I would recommend this place to anyone. I plan on hosting some sort of party there in the near future. The staff was also very attentive and efficient. Reservations are best!
author: Regine N.

description: Food wasn't bad, but didn't quite blow me away. That was okay though, the ambiance , service, and belly dancing made up for what the food lacked. Had an awesome time, great for parties.
author: Julie S.

description:
This a really cool place with great food and great service. 

The interior is decorated in a Moroccan style, which instantly transports you Northern Africa. Good music too. 

Your meal is 5 courses, and you choose from the menu what you would like for your main (4th) course. Start off with the Moroccan beer. 

You start with a traditional Moroccan hand wash from a tea kettle. The first course is Lentil Soup with bread. The soup is not spectacular, but its good with lots of flavor. Drink the remainder -- dont ask for more bread. You'll have plenty of bread throughout the night. 

The second course is a quad of salads: eggplant, salsa, cucumbers, and carrots. It was the least satisfying course but I suppose its traditional?   I could do without this course.

Third is an AMAZING pie: chicken wrapped in phyllo and dusted with powdered sugar. Sweet, savory, crusty, delicious!  I could have it everyday.

Fourth is your chosen main course. I highly recommend the lamb with honey and almonds. So tender and sweet.  OMG Fantastic!  Everyone at my table was eating mine!

You have another hand washing and some sweet mint tea. Finally is dessert which, surprisingly, is not as sweet as the third course (or the lamb with honey) but it was a nice ending to the meal. 

The service was very friendly, although there should have been another server because once the place got crowded service was a bit slow. There was also a bellydancer at about 8:30 who was entertaining but, with such a small crowd of diners on a Wednesday night, it was a bit awkward at first. 

I will absolutely return to this place!
author: Jamena P.

description:
Last Saturday night a group of us all went here for our monthly "ethnic food" night, where we try food that some or all of us have never eaten before. Last month it was Eritrean (see "Assab" review), and this month, it was Morroccan! We had a really fun time at El Monsour, and the food was delicious. Also, one of my friends is half-Egyptian, and even she agreed that the food was superb (she's made home-made lamb tagine before, so we considered her 'credible'). :)

Fantastic Morroccan food - delicious fish tagine.

Great service - loved the rose water for washing our hands. 

Fun ambiance - tent-like, with couch-style seating with cushions, all surrounding circular tables. Community-style setting for parties.

Excellent entertainment - Stasha, the belly-dancer was beautiful, fun, sassy & impressive balancing a sword atop her head, etc.
author: Sally M.

description:
I came here for my birthday 2 years ago and had a great time!  I like this place because they have a live belly dancer.  She was great because she kept picking on my guy friend, who was pretty scared of her. haha It was hilarious, you just had to be there, especially when she was balanced the sword on her head.  There was a group of 16 of my friends so we got our own little corner. 

You can order a la carte or as a pre-fixe.  I recommend the prefixe menu.  It comes with a lot of food, and you guys can all share a variety of dishes.  Since it was so long ago, I don't remember what we got, but I remmeber the first plate being soooo good, it was some sort of almond puff pastry thingy with stuff inside.  They made the food depending on how many people you are sharing with.  So, not everyone gets their own puff pastry thing, except for the main dish.  What is cool about this place is that they serve mint tea.  Not only is it the best tea you'll ever have, but they also pour it from super high--above the waiters head, and it magically goes into your cup without any spillage!

Overall, everything was really good, entertainment was fun, and it's just a really cool atmosphere!
author: Diane L.

description: this is a great restaurant for light hearted fun special dinners. especially the birthdays group party. always respectful, attentive service.... excellent food, topped off by a single belly dancer.  note experience is pricey, but always consistently nice fun dinner... average 2 to 2.5 hours.  great for out of town guests.
author: Sharine d.

description: Food was delicious, service excellent, and ambience fun and comfortable. Lentil soup was so good.
author: Gabrielle O.

description: Great place to dine and Belly dance is always entertaining.
author: Shilpi S.

description:
This year is not a special birthday year but I am still going a bit overboard.  There should be birthday events, joint or solo, for the rest of the month, as far as I am concerned.  I may get too burnt out to follow through.  We'll see.

So, the friend planned this event with the help of BFF#2 and I have to admit, everything turned out great.  The restaurant is way more elaborately decorated than you would think from looking at the outside.  It was like walking into another world.  I got to hang out with great friends and eat good food in a fun environment.  What more could I want?

I got over the whole hatred of eating with my hands thing for the night. The eggplant, chicken in phyllo dough, lentil soup and fish tangine were so yummy.  I also tried some of the different chicken dishes, lamb and the moroccan seafood dish and they were all tasty.  

The service was great considering how busy the place was and how rowdy some of our people were.  The belly dancer was fun and gracious.  She gave me a plastic fish that you put on the palm of your hand and depending on how it moves, it determines something about you.  Apparently, all my friends are passionate lovers.  Well, except for one.  His fish didn't move.
author: Seong P.

description:
I'm so glad someone picked this place. I think it was Aaron right? Good job Aaron!! I think I can safely speak for everyone and say we all had a really good time. 

Eugy and I got there a little early and we see the first belly dancer come out. Eugy gets all excited and says something about needing to go get more dollar bills. I give him the "don't you even think about it" bitch stare and he quietly sits back down and waits patiently. :)

Finally Aaron and the birthday girl show up (HEY SEONG!!) and we all go inside and get situated. The place is pretty large with mostly open space. I like this. There are heavily cushioned benches against the wall, knee high tables and on the other side of the tables, big cushy stools. 

The service was really friendly. Spotty at times, but there were about 6 birthdays going on, all very large crowds, so it was totally understandable to be a little aloof. They weren't too bad though. Nothing to frown at, that's for sure. 

The food was excellent. Flavorful, moist, just delicious. Before we ate, Aaron was saying something about eating with our hands and I really thought he was kidding. So when the course after the soup came out, I was hesitant to eat. I just sat back watching everyone else to see who was going to put their hands in first. I just knew that as soon as I put my hands in to get some food, our server would come out with flatware. He didn't, so I finally gave in and ate with my hands. 

For the main course, I had the couscous with chicken. Do you know how hard it is to eat couscous with your fingers?! And just as I earlier predicted, as soon as I stuck my fingers in, trying to smoosh the couscous into edible balls, out comes the waiter with forks. YAY~!~!!

Later the belly dancer came out and one of our other outgoing, intoxicated friends decided that it would be a good idea to get up and start grinding with the dancer. She reacted well and danced on with our friend. I just kept looking at Eugy with those "don't you even think about it" bitchy eyes. haha... 

Overall, this was a fantastic experience. I would highly recommend this to anyone who needs to entertain their dinner guests in an completely different way. Or dinner for large groups. This place is sure to please.
author: Jen D.

description:
You can only really experience another country's culture by eating their food the way they eat their food.  El Mansour is like taking a  Moroccan trip without leaving San Francisco.

Their restaurant is really low key on the outside and inside, it is done as traditionally as I could have imagined it.  The service and the owner are really welcoming and funny, making it feel like you are dining at their home.  

Being Filipino, I don't mind leaving the utensils out when dining.  Here you are encouraged to grab with your hands, share and have a good time.  Don't be suprised to see powdered sugar on top of the appeitizer, it is good mix of sweet and savor with the minced chicken between the phylo crusts.  I really feel you can't go wrong with most of the dishes, I can personally vouch for the rabbit and the olive & onion chicken.  Topping off your meal is the dessert of fried bananas and creamed phylo dough and now you are officially full! 

El Mansour is a place to dine with friends and family both large or small because of the experience.  The belly dancing and the tea pouring makes the food secondary to the fact that you are just having a great time!
author: Jason A.

description: WOW!!! That was the dinner of the decade. I just cant believe how talented the belly dancer was and it was thrilling to be able to join in. The food was impeccable especially the couscous chicken with veggies and don't even get started on the dessert. Woo hoo them banana fritters were on point. The atmosphere felt mysterious. I was drawn by draping the ceiling and the comforting pillows were ravishing. They have a very fun birthday song which you just must sing along to. So get your booty over there and have the whole moroccan experience
author: Lili L.

description:
Went with friends last night and we were definitely in for a treat! 

Although  the menu is just two pages, it is plenty to chose from. May be a more limited choice for a vegetarian... I went for rabbit, my three friends had seafood, chicken kebob, and a chicken and lamb meal respectively. All of it was just fabulous; from the harira (lentil) soup that started us off, the veggies, the bastela, to our main courses. And our meal ended with desserts and mint tea. Fabulous! 

Warm and personal service. And added to this was a belly danseuse that was an addition that enchanted the kids - and the bachelor party - next to us.
author: Mats C.

description:
Great decor, but small place for Moroccan food. 

The good: Had a large party of 14 and were seated within our reservation time. Half of us ordered entrees while the other half went family style. The food was delicious and I couldn't get enough of that bread. Friendly service staff but had some issues. The prettiest and friendliest belly dancer I've ever met. 

The bad: Service was dicey. We ordered champagne which was promptly brought to us but we had to wait another 10 - 15 minutes for them to provide the champagne glasses. There were constant reminders to the service staff for beer re-orders and at one point, we waited 45 minutes for our main courses to arrive. We asked periodically but just kept getting the same answer that the food was on it's way. There were two other large parties and they seemed to be getting their items in a timely fashion. In fact, they were seated at the same time we were, yet we ended up staying an hour later than them.

Overall, good place but be willing to wait around for a bit for your food items if you're in a large party.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
If you can't get the sexual tension tuned up way, way, WAY past 11 at El Mansour, and your date isn't lugging around an extra X-Chromosome, then the gene pool is probably better off without you.
 
The environment is exotic yet comfortable, even sensual. You enter through a traditional Islamic arch done with the medieval Spanish influenced tiles that define Moroccan architecture. Every inch of the interior is covered in rich fabric and thick oriental carpet like some sultan's tent during a mythical time between Disney's Aladdin and Operation Desert Storm. You sit on soft cushions (good for cuddling and necking, activities at least two couples were actively engaged in) and enjoy finger lickin' as there isn't any silverware (unless requested). 

The food matches the dcor for exotic feel yet comfortable essence. After ceremonial hand washing at the table you are served b'steeya, essentially chicken pot pie topped with sugar and cinnamon. Good, and Homer Simpson would be down for it. Main courses are flesh-centric: hunks of lamb, chicken, fish. Closest the menu comes to challenging even the narrowest of palates is lentil soup. 

Surroundings and food set the stage, but Stasha is the star. The master belly dancer performs Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays. Displaying just slightly more flesh than your basic tenth grade female mall rat (though, she confided, wearing a G string for emergencies), Stasha raised every pulse in the room, male or female, with her sensual movements and some of the most incredible muscle control I've ever seen not involving ping-pong balls.  Important note to all Bay Area strippers: See this woman to learn what sensuality and audience interaction are all about. Don't worry - you can write it off as professional development. 

El Mansour offers set courses for $27.75. Food was something between very good and good enough not harm the total experience. Quantities are large, so if you are worried about overeating don't feel like you need to finish all of every course. 

Parking can be very tight but regulars assure me you can safely leave your car on the top story of the supermarket parking structure across the way. 

Stasha's web site is www.stashamania.com 

Some general info on Morocco http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morocco

Trivia: You won't find any Moroccan patterns containing people, animals, or plants, due to the tenet that only Allah can create life.
author: Bill S.

description:
As you walk into this place you feel like you have stepped into a set for the Arabian Nights. The decor is tastefully done without being over the top. I love the low tables and seats for the authentic feel. The whole place is done in vibrant colors which again adds to the "feel" of the place.

The service was absolutely great. We didn't have to wait forever for our order to be taken and our waters and bread was efficiently replinshed. We ordered the family platter (which you have to ask for) and the food was amazing. The hummus and falafel was absolutely yummy. The lamb and chicken skewers were delicious. And the bread was so soft, it melted in your mouth. For dessert, we had some Baklava which was pretty good. At the end of the meal they wash your hands with rose water (nice touch). 

Oh and boys...they have belly dancing! What am I saying...it's fun for all of us to watch someone shake their booty to middle eastern tunes!
author: Teesta K.

description:
Oh God I am so full...and I went here yesterday.

The Moroccan "dining experience" lends itself well to special occasions and large groups, so places like El Mansour are perfect for birthday parties.  Intimate romantic dinners...not so much.  Although, unlike many places which consist of a warren of themed rooms, private tents, and the like, El Mansour is just a single couch-lined room, which gives it a nice communal feel.

As Kate V's meticulous breakdown will show, the prices here are actually pretty good: $30 for a 5-course meal of soup, salad, meat pastry, entree, and dessert (oh yeah, and the best mint tea I've ever had).  And while I've certainly been to middle eastern places that combined lavish spectacle and high prices with mediocre food, I'm happy to say that everything at El Mansour was perfectly delicious.  Note that you can't order a la carte, so come hungry.  Real hungry.  

Also, at the risk of being shallow, big props for having a belly dancer that was young, attractive, and classy (not necessarily a given, I'll have you know).  Hint: If the belly dancer beckons you up and it seems cheesy or embarrassing, you're not drinking enough.

The only thing I could've asked for was that the place be more crowded (ordinarily I would never say that, but again, raucous is good at these places).  So I suggest making your reservations for Friday or Saturday for the maximum experience.
author: Wes M.

description:
I had my birthday party here. We had about 13 guests. We were seated immediately in these clean, yet plush cushion area at the corner.  Some of the guys 'backs' ached sitting to long in an ottoman type of cushioned stool.

First dish:
Lentil soup - tasty!
Bread - Loved the bread
Mix/Mash of vegetables (chilled) slightly tart (carrots, cucumbers, eggplants and some spread to eat with the bread)
Bastilla
My main entree
Dessert (fried banana if I remember correctly) and some phyllo dough flake/wonton wrapper thing. 



I LOVE THE BASTILLA (it's this fried pancake like dough but slightly crispy with chicken, almonds and some sprinkles of powdered sugar on top). (link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pastilla)

Wash your hands because you'll be eating with your hands.  They come around to wash your hands with warm water/rose water. 

The menu was a little intricate to understand at first.  It was $30/per entree.  The tab came to $40/per person (you do the math!)

I got the honey/prune chicken. It was pretty moist/soft and it was still pipping hot when it was being served to me.  The food came together at once for everyone.  

The belly dancing show started around 9pm and beware of shyness - they will make you go up to dance if you are the birthday girl/boy!

I had fun -- just wished this place was not in "outer richmond" but closer in.  The decor was exquisite and we parked on the street.

This restaurant is right across the street (if not close already) to the Legion of Honor.  

I called 2 weeks in advance to make reservations and the follow up phone calls were very good.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I would probably give this place 3 stars but I feel that it is way overrated. It is expensive for what it is. The service is friendly, but slow. The food is good, but nothing special. 

And... The bellydancer is terrifying. I was here with a date after being told it was a good date restaurant. So the dancer proceeds to attack us and say really 'awk' things like "Oh you can show him your moves later in the bedroom" while fondeling me with her veil-device. She kept coming back to us and being awk so we hurried out of there. It was funny to laugh about it with my date, but fucking traumatic. Consider yourself warned.
author: Sven S.

description:
Any place that has a  Happy Birthday! song planned out in a routine makes me feel like, kinda ghetto .  Really, all the other strangers in the restaurant couldn't care less how old you are. They had two birthdays there.  I was very put off.
The food was OK, although they pretty much only served lamb, which I don't eat.  They had one chicken dish and it was kinda blah.
Totally off the subject, but tonight I went to this party and they had this entire pig, head and all, buffet style in a metal pan.  I ventured back to the food area 3 glasses of wine later and the pig carcass was missing it's ears and the skin off it's face.
EEWW. Who the fuck would eat pig skin face??? So nasty.  And the missing ears?   I was really weirded out.
author: Starla D.

description: Save for the belly dancer, which is a decidely American concept of life in the Casbah, this is as authentic as any restaurant in which I dined in Morocco. A prix fixe dinner includes an entree from seven options (with choices such as prawns and scallops, sea bass with tomatoes, olives and lemons, lamb and chicken with almonds, and rabbit kabob) served with couscous and vegetables, harira - the national soup, a spicy lentil bean - a salad of tomatoes, eggplant, carrots, and cucumbers, bastela - a pastry filled with chicken, almonds, and an assortment of spices - two desserts, and mint tea. Dinners are served in the traditional style, but silverware is available upon request. An excellent choice for special events or a large group of friends looking for a fun night out.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
I've been bringing people here for at least ten years--birthdays, New Year's, big groups, dates, etc.  They recently did a re-model that has made it a bit more kitschy, but I still love El Mansour.  There is the requisite belly dance performance, which can get embarrassing when the dancer brings blushing patrons to the center of the restaurant to "dance" with her.

Truly, the owners are wonderful, and from Marrakesh, I believe.  The food is a multi-course feast starting (and ending) with rose water poured over everyone's hands.  The seating is on floor cushions and the decor is beautiful, with fabric draped everywhere (fans of Edward Said, you'll hate it :-)).

My favorite dish is the bastilla, a traditional chicken appetizer with cinnamon and powdered sugar that you eat with your hands.  All of the main courses I've had are great, from beef kabobs to chicken and even rabbit.  They do have vegetarian dishes, but you'd want to skip the bastilla.  We almost always get Moroccan red wine, which is worth trying.

It's a multi-hour experience and great for almost any occasion.  Parking is on the street; you may have to park several blocks away on weekends. Don't park even an inch into a driveway, as the SF parking people are militant about that, and ending your evening down at the tow-truck place to get your car back is not fun :-).

That said, who is up for a trip to Morocco?
author: Diana G.

description: I knew in advance that this place would be expensive and it was. It was about 47 bucks a person which included drinks, tax, and gratuity. The experience was wonderful with belly dancing, lively music, washing your hands at your table, unlimited bread, and much more. I had ordered the chicken with honey and plum sauce as my entree with the pre fix meal. he salad was incredible with a mixture of tomatoes, cucumbers, and a salsa type sauce along with lentil soup and my favorite of the night, the bastilla which was TO DIE FOR! Flaky on the outside, warm and tasty on the inside. Any pastry with meat inside, I am a big fan of. I would totally come back just for the bastilla alone. Our entree took awhile to come out and it was so disappointing. It tasted very odd and at 30 something bucks a person plus...I should have ordered lamb instead. The chicken was forgettable while my group, about 15, most had lamb and they all enjoyed their meals. One star knocked off for the chicken but everything and the experience was fun until the bill came out...Ouch. No more group parties for me for awhile especially when 47 bucks could have bought me pounds of pastries down the street on Clement. This place is much more for an intimate party because of the small place. My party and I did not get to converse that much. Everyone was far off away from each other while couples I noticed enjoyed everything. Gotta bring back my partner and I to experience El Mansour and actually pay 30 bucks rather than 47 bucks. Yes I am cheap but forking out an extra 17 bucks is ridiculous. Oh yeah, one last thing, if you are sharing your food, they have a 15 dollar minimum charge. EWWW!
author: Danster L.

description: Great restaurant! I went here with my family, who have gone here many times before without me, so they were able to show me how everything was. First off, the atmosphere of the restaurant is very welcoming and very well decorated. It was also very dark in there but it did not hinder the experience in any way. Instead of your typical tables, this restaurant has you sit on sofas and cushions with a very low table where the dishes are placed. The food is great, I had the chicken with lemons and was very happy with the taste. The entrees are quite expensive, but you do get a lot of food. The other thing to consider is that along with the meal, you are also getting the belly dancing show, which the makes the price more reasonable. An experience everyone should try once!
author: Michael R.

description:
One of the reasons why I love San Francisco is because it's so ethnically diverse. My cousin was visiting from Florida and she wanted some Moroccan food a la "Along Came Polly" (which was a really bad movie, btw). Thanks to Yelp, it was easy to find a restaurant that met her expectations. El Mansour came complete with a belly dancer and did not disappoint. 

ATMOSPHERE: You feel like ... you're eating in the desert (with camels roaming outside) in a very large tent with draperies and pillows of deep reds and gold. It's exotic and fun! The kind of setting that's perfect for a group that's not just looking for a fantastic dinner, but entertainment as well. The belly dancer was talented and charming and ... ohmygosh ... the rose water was definitely my favorite part of the evening. I want to bathe in it every night, it smells sooo good! 

FOOD: Everything was delicious. I loved every bit of my 4-course meal. The lentil soup was heartwarming. The appetizers included the Salade Mohammed V and the Bastela du Chef. The eggplant was my favorite - so good soaked up with the bread. The Bastela tasted like a churro to me - a churro with meat. For my entree, I ordered the chicken with honey and prunes and really wish that I could get that dish somewhere in the South Bay. 

Reasonably priced, we were stuffed! I can't wait to come back!
author: Christine N.

description: Fantastic experience, great food and very prompt service. The Chicken, Lamb, Tea, Dessert....all very good. I would def go back. The only tough part is trying to eat rice with your hands...but once you get rolling, your good to go.
author: Alamandine B.

description: The food, service and entertainment was all top notch and spectacular!  I'd recommend this place to everyone who wants a fun and different experience with delicious food!
author: Anne P.

description:
Belly dancing.....ground cushions.........eating with your hands........illusion of a proper tent.......cleansing your hands in rose water........and best of all MINT TEA.  I LOVE El Mansour.  I first came here in middle school when I was 13.  It was for a friends birthday.  After that I was hooked and I eventually celebrated my 21st b-day here with my grandma, bff, aunts, and mother.  

Needless to say seeing my 79-year old grandmother tuck a single into the shimmying waistband of a 50 something year old belly dancer was priceless.  Don't get it twisted.....that lady could dance! 

As for the food, that is another memorable thing.  There are like 5 courses and you share everything but the main dish family style.  They have, hands down, the best lentil soup I have ever tried and the best mint tea and chicken cilicia.  The lentil soup follows the vegetables and is only eaten with a piece of bread.  The chicken cilicia follows and is a rounded flat pie like pastry made with filo dough and in the middle is a mixture of chicken, raisins, cinnamon, and almond.  To top off this savory sweet dish is powdered sugar and cinnamon.  You break it apart with your hands, but be cautioned, it is hot when it first comes out but its GREAT. 

Then your hands are given a shower of rose scented warm water accompanied by a hot towel. The service is amazing.  Then you move on to the main course which will be anything from a fowl to rabbit.  Each entree is accompanied by cous cous and a sauce.  

The dessert is fried banana and some other component that i forgot but it is also amazing of course, then finally the grand finale..............mint tea is poured by a server about three feet above the cup.  The tea is one of the main reasons to come here....seriously.  Not to mention the awesome belly dancing show.  

So my night was eventful.....I was forced to dance in front of a 'tent" full of strangers with the 50 something belly dancer as the matriarchs of my family stashed ones in her brassier and skirt......very eventful indeed.  

I recommend coming here for a special occasion or a nice date, but trust me that coming with a group is more fun!!

You would think that this place would hurt your wallet something fierce but you will end up paying about $35-$40 a person including tip.  That is very reasonable since you could leave an regular place like the Cheesecake Factory and drop way more without half the fun or memorable cuisine.  

You will need reservations and I recommend planning it a week or so in advance.. It really depends on the night, but this place is usually booked so give them a call.  I hope you all have as much fun as I did!
author: Crista Y.

description: Great place to try new food, experience a new culture and have a great time. From the way you eat your food, to the decor, to the flavors of each dish, the whole experience is something different and new to try. Came here for my bday with a party of about 13, they were very accommodating and very understanding when some of our party was late. I wanted to try something very different, so i ordered the rabbit. I love rabbit after trying it there, it was done great, nice and tender with some good flavor. Highlight of the night was the very, very pretty belly dancer.
author: Candice B.

description:
Don't be fooled by the imposing blue door that has absolutely no markings of the name of the restaurant or the fact that it even is a restaurant. Just barge in.

El Mansour starts off with a great ambience. Low lighting and low tables. Fancy drapery and sofas. You then proceed to enjoy your fixed price dinner, which comes with a whole bunch of Moroccan goodies that I wish I knew more about. The whole thing is tasty. Then when you least expect it (or maybe you do because you actually read the Yelp reviews beforehand), a belly dancer comes out! All told, this place offers a great dining *experience* rather than just a plain meal. The main downsides that take off the 5th star are the remote location and the price.

Handy tip for poor students: Go with a friend who is interviewing with a Silicon Valley company. This way he can subsidize the meal on the company's behalf.
author: Stephen L.

description:
I first visited El Monsour about ten years ago with a friend who loves this place.  She grew up in the Richmond and often visited with her family.  She even knows the owner... should I say the owner's husband? Anyway, I've not seen this friend in many years until we recently met again for dinner at El Monsour.

I'm not real familiar with Moroccan cuisine, but I do know this, it tasted a lot like my grandma's baked dishes.  The olive and onion chicken was tender a moist but a little too salty.  The lamb with honey almonds was very good.  It pulled from the bone nicely and had a sweet flavor from the honey.  The Casa beer (Moroccan) was nice.  I think it was a lager.  Overall, the entrees went down like comfort food that I will not appreciate until later when I'm looking back on the whole experience. 

The dinning room was comfortable and well dressed making it a great place for conversation until the entertainment started.  Although I appreciate the art of belly dancing, it did disrupt our chat as the small room was consumed with music and movement.  It felt like we were forced to watch and participate.  I guess that's not a bad thing, but we were more concerned with catching up each other.
author: Charlie S.

description:
A parent's review of this place

brought my 17 month old her. She loved the food and the people watching..  Good place for birthday or big groups. might even be great for little kid's birthday party!  Just move those candles...

The portions were HUGE and this was my first time eating moroccan. delicious!  drooling just thinking about it.

who doesn't love phyllo and sugar and cinnamon?  with chicken and as a dessert? They were able to hurry up and accommodate our "eat fast, before daughter blows"

and our daughter had her first exposure to dance.  =)
author: Sophia Y.

description:
This is my first review Yay!!

I was inspired to write it because I recently ate at El Mansour and had the best time.

The atmosphere was so wonderful.  My first time having Morrocan food and I loved it!  It felt like I really stepped into Morroco...or into a scene in Along Came Polly :)

The woman who does the belly dancing was so fun, she engaged someone from every section, I loved the hand washing, and the tapestries everywhere.

I had the Chicken and Couscous, and it was really full of taste.  

I wanted to go back tonight to take my mom who is visiting, but, they are closed on mondays, so make sure you tell your family and friends to visit tues through Sun, so that you can take them somewhere that will stand out in their memories. 
 I think tourists like to see the less "touristy" things, the things that we locals love, so they can feel like they are sharing a secret with us...
and why not share our secrets? and support our local businesses who are putting out great food, and fun times for everyone. 

I enjoy that this restaurant is kid friendly.  The kids get to get up and dance if they want with the beautiful belly dancer,

Oh yeah, about that, we didn't put money in her belt originally, because we thought it might be an insult, but come to find out, YOU'RE SUPPOSED TO PUT MONEY IN THERE!!!  So, don't feel rude if you want to tip her, she's great!  

So go, you should go now!

If it's not a monday..
author: Aurora R.

description:
what a great place for a fun get together with friends! the place is dim with walls and ceilings covered in different fabrics and tapestries. a belly dancer comes around for a little performance and even grab some volunteers from each table to teach a few simple moves. when you sit down, they give you a towel, place a large metal fancy bowl int he center of the table, then ask you put your hands above it. then they pour warm water over your hands to wash them! you eat everything with your hands here, but will give you utensils if you can't stand to eat with your hands. 

for the meal, you can choose a specialty plate and that comes with soup, appetizers, and dessert:

the harira soup (spicy lentil bean soup) was so full of flavor! loved this!

the bastela du chef (pastry filled w/ chicken almonds and spices) seemed odd at first because of the powdered sugar on top, but  turned out to be really good! the outside was crispy and sweet while the inside was soft and savory... perfect combo!

i ordered the lamb and chicken. and for the record, i do not care for lamb, but wanted to try their "best" dish. the lamb had NO gamey taste! it was delicious and tender! 

for dessert, they served us king hassan (banana fritter) which was sweet and soft with kaneffa (sweet bastela w/ cream and almonds) which was crispy. they really know how to please the palate with tastes and texture!

the a la mentha (mint tea) was last and a perfect ending for our meal. they begin to pour the tea normally, then raise the pot as they're pouring so the tea is coming out the spout like a waterfall. this is to cool the tea so it's drinkable. brilliant! the waiter was fun and gave us another full pot so we could test our tea-pouting skills. 

such a fun experience and would definitely recommend this place!
author: Tea Lyves ..

description:
I came here tonight with a group for a friend's birthday.. It was my first time coming here but a few of them's second time.. I knew this place was going to be good based on the personal reviews but nothing does it justice.
The food, ambiance, service and entertainment exceeds my expectations by far. We got the full meal thing family style so we were all sharing but it was more than enough food. 
You get there and it is a very small and intimate restaurant with very comfy seating.. (you're basically sitting on a couch). The service is amazing and they start you off by washing your hands for you.. Then slowly the meals come.. the appetizer, I don't remember what it was called but was seriously one of the most amazing things I've ever eaten.. EVER! It was like meat wrapped in phyllo dough topped with powdered sugar.. And everything else was just SO good and flavorful and tasty! They served lentil soup and it was the best lentil soup I've ever eaten.
The belly dancing was great entertainment and you can go up and dance with the girl, she is very nice and beautiful. 
Overall, I had an amazing experience and it definitely won't be the last time I come here. 
Also, there are no utensils to use but that's what makes it so much fun! And they have a lot of vegetarian options..
author: T L.

description:
Atmosphere was fun - the carpets and pillows and tapestried walls definitely gave a kitchy Arabian Nights feel (I mean that in a good way). There were authentic Moroccan touches with the real Moroccan lamps, mosaic fountains, cushions and waiter costumes - although the Thai waiters didn't contribute to an authentic feeling (although they were nice and apparently knew the Thai husband of the Moroccan owner). 

Food was ok, but worse than expected. I went here after just returning from Morocco and wanted to show some friends some of the fine cuisine. Compared to the food in Marrakech (perhaps an unfair comparison), the food didn't stand up at all. I chose this place over the higher-rated Aziza because the online menu showed dishes that were actually common in Marrakech - tajines in particular- that Aziza didn't appear to have. 

Expecting authentic delicious food, I was disappointed that none of the dishes had very much flavor, especially the tajines that were so delicious in Morocco I practically had to be rolled out of the restaurants.  If I was judging all Moroccan cuisine on El Mansour, I wouldn't seek it out. We ordered the fixed menu which included salad that was so generic that now, 3 days later, I can't even remember what it was except that it was generic (it wasn't like real Moroccan salad, which is a smattering of 6-15 tiny plates of things like pickled beats, sweet pickled tomatoes etc.). Then came the "bastela" or, as they call it in Marrakech the "pastilla" which was the best dish at the restaurant, but again, not remotely comparable to any of the versions I tasted of this common dish in Marrakech. It is a crispy filo-wrapped crumbled chicken pastry with cinnamon and sugar on top - which is pretty hard to do badly. This wasn't bad, just wasn't good. The chicken had an odd savory seasoning that didn't go with the sweet flavors, and wasn't present in my Moroccan frame of reference. 

Next came the mains - rabbit tajine, fish tajine, "chicken with lemon and olives" (which is a tajine in Morocco but not at this restaurant) and lamb with almonds and honey. The lamb was gamey, the chicken was bland and oily and the tajines didn't have much flavor- they were clearly not cooked in the tajines as is the Moroccan custom, but were scooped into the tajine pot for presentation. One reason tajines are so good in Morocco is that the long cooking in the clay pot leaves especially yummy and spicey flavors on the sides of the stew, which was notably absent in these dishes.

Overall, the experience was fun, they had a few Moroccan wines (the guerrouane red is fine of the choices on the menu), but don't judge all Moroccan food on this place. Mostly, it would be awesome if the restaurant used more of their traditional techniques to make really flavorful food so that in addition to the atmosphere, the food would leave an accurate impression of how delicious the food of Morocco is.
author: Ashley R.

description:
This is currently my favorite restaurant, though lately I'm having a serious "thing" with Indian food....but this is still my fav.

I could make a meal out of the soup and appetizer platter alone. There is no beef on the menu but you can get lamb, chicken and rabbit. The meals include: Couscous and Vegetables, Harira Soup(Spicy Lentil Bean Soup), Salade Mohammed V (Combination of Tomatoes, eggplant, carrots & cucumbers) the salad is served hummus style with bread to eat it with...yum. Bastela du Chef (Pastry filled with chicken, almonds, and assortment of spices), this pastry is a puff pastry filled with shredded chicken w almonds and topped with powdered sugar it's got the whole sweet and savory thing going on. Desserts are; King Hassan (Banana Fritter)
Keneffa (Sweet Bastela with Cream and Almonds)
The A La Menthe (Mint Tea
The finishing mint tea is hot yet refreshing. 

The Belly dancing is top notch. Stasha is a beautiful dancer and if you're lucky she'll be working the night you go.. http://www.stashamania.com/
I preferred the old decor at the old location, next door. You can see some of it on Stasha's website
Get away for an exotic evening and go to El Mansour.
author: Tammy B.

description: This place was awesome, the lentil soup in the begining of the 5 course dinner was amazing.  Make sure you have a strong back as you will be leaning over to grab your food from the shared plates a lot.  The belly dancer theme was cool, the environment is well decorated.  I got the chicken and lamb specialty and it was pretty good.  Will go again.
author: Kamal R.

description:
This place is definitely worth the trek to the edge of the city.  It has it all.  

The food is amazing -- it's hard not to fill up on the appetizers and save space for the main course.  I think most people get the prix fixe that starts you out with soup, a shared salad, then this amazing chicken-stuffed phyllo shell covered with icing sugar (tastes so much better than it sounds), followed by the main course of which you can pick from several items, finishing with dessert.

All the while you're served by really friendly and helpful staff, with unique touches: washing your hands at the table, having your tea poured from 1 metre above the table, and of course, the belly dancer.
