(who will eventually drag you up to dance with her)  Sure, it verges on cheesey, but stays well clear of crossing the line.

All around, a great experience for under $30 (without drinks)!
author: Sri A.

description:
This place is: 
SUPER
DUPER 
FUN
!
The food is yummy, not necessarily 5 star quality, but still quite good. The ambiance is awesome (genie in a bottle style). That night the belly dancer wasn't the 50 something year old woman that previous yelp reviewers had mentioned, (not that I would have had a problem with that) but rather a young, exotic, SMOKIN' hot mamita that knew how to shake and shimmy her body like nobody's damn business! 
Ooooohhhh weeeeeee!
I might also mention that the prices are quite reasonable. I nearly drown myself in Pinot Grigio yet still left without doing too much damage to the wallet.
I will surely go back!
author: Miss T.

description:
- Service: Mostly attentive albeit a bit gimmicky at time (waterfall-like mint tea pouring, rose water hand washing)

- Food: ~ $34 consisted of soup, appetizer, main meal, dessert, and then tea.  While my vegetarian dish tasted good, I haven't had other Moroccan food before, so I don't have a basis for comparison yet

- Drinks: When ordering wine by the glass, they may limit your selections because they don't want to uncork new bottles unnecessarily for cost reasons.  It wasn't what I wanted to hear, but I do appreciate their honesty in explaining it

- Group size: If you make a reservation for a large group, make sure your number doesn't expand at the last minute.  Ours did, and the seating and portions was divided unevenly.  One table of 7 ended up with the same amount of food with one table of 4

- Ambience: Entertainment's there, with a belly dancer, music, and interacting with the patrons.  The interior is small, but my guess is that it can probably sit up to 100 people (e.g. 4 groups of 25 people)
author: Lloyd C.

description:
Went here for a birthday party. The consensus:
Any place that washes your hands in rose water between courses is pretty much amazing.

Definitely a great place for large groups, El Mansour has a fixed menu that includes appetizers, 1st and 2nd courses, dessert and tea. All of the dishes we ordered were cooked to perfection. The meat was marinated beautifully and literally was so tender, it just fell off the bone. The appetizers are served on communal plates, so you have to dig in and get your hands dirty. Our friendly and slightly whimsical waiter was happy to provide us all with towels :) 

Besides the fantastic food, there was entertainment too! Oh my! The belly dancer took the floor and visited all of the tables, her undulating hips throwing shadows on the decadent platters. Romance novel writing aside, we had a hilarious experience when a little 5 year old girl decided she could outdo the dancer. Needless to say, she (the girl) collected enough dollar bills to seriously outdo her weekly allowance.
author: verna b.

description: I haven't been to many "dinner and a show" places, I rarely go to the Outer Richmond and I probably eat Moroccan food every other year.  With all that said, I had a good time. I would recommend the later show so you can avoid any families that may show up with kids. The later crowd that was coming in looked like they were ready to have some fun.  Good food, great atmosphere and an excellent show.  The belly dancers are HOT!
author: Corey V.

description:
Very fun spot and clearly a favorite for birthdays--I could sing happy birthday in arabic by the end of the night.

First two courses were delicious, wasn't too impressed with the entrees, dessert was eh, but the tea was nice.  

Service was good, but the belly dancer needed to do a few more sit-ups. The setting was awesome and the seating is really comfortable (unless, your party gets too large and then u get squished and not everyone gets the cushy couch).

Worth the experience, but I think once was enough.
author: Sara S.

description: The ambiance was cool, definitely a place to go with a lover or a group of people. The belly dancer was super into our group, which I always get uncomfortable with. I hate being the center of attention so that part I could have gone without. Ha! Now on to the more important things! The service was great. The food was good. I had it once for a friend's birthday. I can't say I would ever go back or crave the food again. I ordered a lamb dish that was kinda bland. But the sides and the other dishes I tried were pretty good. Like I said... good but nothing to brag about.
author: Natasha S.

description: awesome place will come here again!!!!! highly recommend it and the belly dancing along with the food was great.
author: Tina B.

description: I have had the pleasure of eating at El Mansour for at least 30 years. I began in college, took my kids later on and now they go on their own. The ambiance is very nice, I feel transported to a far off place. The entertainment is a special treat. The meal is an event in and of itself; every course is delicious. My marriage didn't last but thankfully El Mansour is still there. Looking forward to experiencing it with my fella.
author: Debbie L.

description:
El Mansour became one of my top three all time restaurants last night.  
My in-laws surprised me and my wife by taking us here for our anniversary dinner. For someone who loves quote unquote ethnic food, it was a perfect choice. 
First off the atmosphere is amazing. The walls are lined with comfortable plush sofas and cushions with low, round tables about knee height. The waiters are extremely friendly and attentive. 
The food is incredible!!! Some balk at the price, but $35 gets you a 5 course meal. Warm water and a clean towel allow you to wash up and prepare for your feast.  The first course was harira soup we sopped up with some fresh and amazing bread and our fingers. Same with the salad of cucumbers, carrots, eggplant, and tomatoes. Main course I had the lamb w/ eggplant and it was perfection. I've had meat that falls off the bone, but when I picked up my lamb, the bone fell out! Best lamb I've ever had, and the eggplant was the ideal consistency. My wife got the lamb and chicken with almonds which was equally phenomenal! Next up is a bastela, which is a chicken and almond filo pastry that is out of this world.  Finished our meal with hot mint tea and a King Hassan (banana fritter)! They have an excellent selection of wine and beer as well. 
The entertainment, i.e. belly dancers were quite amazing as well. I can see why Herod offered half his kingdom if her performance was anywhere near that good. And while it as exotic, i never felt uncomfortable watching the show next to my wife. Very tastefully done.
The family who owns the restaurant sat and shared their story of how it has been passed down for 40 years. They take a lot of pride in what they do. 
In the opinion of this reviewer, anyone who gives El Mansour less than a 4 star rating is an uncultured philistine who should go back to eating at Applebees.
author: David A.

description: The food here is ok, and I have been a few times since I live down the street.  However, it doesn't feel clean.  They do make families feel welcome, and they do have a dancer, so you get the exotic feel, but the pillows smell a bit, and while you continue to rinse your hands during the meal, I can't ever get rid of the "unclean" concern here.  You pretty much have to sign up for the whole meal, which is a bummer if you want to try an appetizer or lighter meal.  Finally, the waiters do a poor job of explaining the differences between the food options so you never quite know what you are going to get.  Pictures would be more helpful than they are.
author: Rita G.

description: Waste of time and money!!!! The waiter doesn't know how to serve for crap!! I give it two stars for the belly dancer and ambiance.
author: Tai N.

description:
I went here with a big party. Although the restaurant may seem tiny, it's actually good for a big parties. The only thing is to be sure to make reservations. I saw a little girl with a party next to us, so I guess it's an ok place for children too. 

The menu is simple but expensive. It's basically prixe fix and you choose the main course. Every menu comes with soup, "salad", appetizer, main course, and dessert. I believe the cheapest menu is $30/person. I don't know if ppl know this about Moroccan food but you eat with your hands. There are no utensils, just bread for you to "scoop" your food with. I had the Chicken Kabob, which was really good! My boyfriend had the Lamb, which was surprisingly good and that's saying a lot because I usually hate lamb. 

They also give you water to wash your hands before, and after dinner. The seating is a little cramped and the seats make you bend over when you eat. All in all, I guess it's ok as long as the company is great.

The belly dancer came half way between our menu. It was kinda, awkward. hahah.... I think it's because the belly dancer was middle aged.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
The food isn't great nor is the service, but the atmosphere is delicious.  Everytime i'm here, it's always fun due to great company.

If you don't wanna eat w/ your hands, ask for forks.  And if you're disgusted when people eat with there hands, GTFO.
author: Sam K.

description:
We stopped by El Mansour because Oyaji was too crowded. To be fair, I'm not a Morrocan cuisine enthusiast. In fact, I think if there's a chance to select anything to eat on any given day, Morrocan would not be on my top 20 or even 30 list. And I'm not a big fan of eating with my hands.

But I'll give the positives first: great service, wonderful rose water, neat atmosphere, mint tea.

The belly dancer tonight was like the decor of the place: Americanized and unrefined. Her performance felt like we were at a circus, waiting for a clown to tweek our noses. I was trying not to watch her, so that she wouldn't pull me or my sweetie up there for some impromptu belly dancing. I might sound like a grouch tonight but mainly it's because I had a sprained ankle... 

P.S. I had to stop writing for a few minutes here because I had to run to the bathroom and take care of the runs. So... eat here at your peril. The food was carefully cooked and very hot (my preference) but when not eating with utensils, I definitely felt a few burns on my fingertips that I would rather not have experienced. Two stars is all I can give them.
author: Pretty P.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by this place.  First of all, it's right next door to one of my fave Japanese restaurants, Oaji.  Yeah, the outer Richmond sucks but it's worth the trek if you're going with a big group.  One thing that surprised me was that there was no waiting area, you just walk right in and there's your seat.  I guess they don't expect alot of people to go there.  

The best part of this place is definitely the food.  Granted you have to eat with your hands (not really, we asked for forks like a bunch of annoying Americans), but it's really good food.  They start you out by washing your hands.  Then we got this lentil soup that was so flavorful and cooked to the right tenderness.  I had 2 bowls.  Then we got this filo-pastry filled with chicken and nuts and topped with powdered sugar.  I know...it sounds weird, but actually quite good.  For our entree we were presented with a plate full of various meats and seafood and vegetables and cous cous.  The lamb was probably the best thing, kinda sweet and very tender.  The dessert was fried banana and this other doughy thing I can't really remember (too much wine at that point).  The finishing touch was mint tea.  Yum.  

My only reservations about this place were: 1 - I don't like eating with my hands.  2 - The seating was kinda uncomfortable, it's like eating a whole meal served at your coffee table.  3 - The bread they brought us wasn't flat bread like we expected, but still good.
author: Ming L.

description:
Other yelpers that gave 5 stars have already mentioned the good stuff thats made here. Love the lamb with honey and almonds the most. I also like that the tee-off bar is about 40 feet away. 

I bet you a million dollars the owner has every color imaginable "Polo" and "Izod/Lacoste" collared shirt available to mankind.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
An Oasis in the Richmond.

The food is super yum.  Great flavors! Plate after plate after plate of food till you are bursting. And then there's more.  Lamb, chicken, pastry, salad, soup, all the dishes were just as good as I could wish for. Enjoyed every bite of it. Prix fixe menu keeps it from being a place to just grab a bite. It's a BIG 5 course meal so bring your appetite that night. 

Now, lets talk about why you must go here. Visiting El Mansour, is an opportunity for one to imagine themselves transported off to a distant and exotic land, without all the hassle of luggage, travel and insects!

Even before entering you notice the design and decor. Feel the weight of the heavily gilded doors with its inlaid geometric designs. It feels like a door to the Sultans palace should feel. 

Once past the threshold you will not be disappointed. A tiled entry with a fountain, leads to a room full of casual and comfortable seating areas. Many soft cushioned, corner booths to relax in. Small puffy stools are also at the tables for bigger groups. Seating is low to the ground, Almost to the point of laying down. Very casual.

The elegant hexagonal geometric pattern is repeated throughout. The large round inlayed wood tables, the carved woodwork, it's all there.

How can I forget to mention the thing that you will instantly notice, the tented ceiling. Its fabric draped from high above, to the walls surrounding. Our 5 year old said "it's like a big tent!" We told him that's why we brought him there.

You will have your hands washed at your table twice! Each person has their own towel, no puny napkins here! Your delicious sweet mint tea is poured from 3 feet above the table for the full effect. Impressive as it is delicious. 

Please don't be shy, take the free on-the-spot  belly-dancing lessons. Don't forget your cameras that night for sure!

This place would be great for large groups, birthday parties, wedding dinners, graduation, and above all, is kid friendly, reminding you this is a wonderful spot. Like I said to start, an Oasis.
author: Matthew C.

description:
I'm a picky eater and I don't like trying new things. More importantly I refuse to eat anything without knowing what it is first. 

Well, El Monsour has changed me. First things first, I hate eggplant and I will not eat it but their pickled plate of cucumbers, tomatoes, raisins and eggplant mush is delicious. It tastes even better with the house bread. Next we had the lentil soup which unsuprisingly I hate beans and lentil but I drank the whole thing. 

The most delicious part of the meal is their crispy chicken pastry. Yum- sooo good. Its sweet and salty and just right. I could eat the whole thing by myself. 

The combination of good food and their amazing hand poured high mint tea, belly dancers, and comfy couch seating areas, and handwashing at the tables was such an amazing feat. I love it.
author: Victoria Y.

description: This place was absolutely phenomenal! We came here on a Tue night. We were the only customers here so it felt like we had a private dinner even all to ourselves! The waiter one of the best waiters I have ever had! Even though the owner is Asian, the waiter is Moroccan. So he knew his stuff when we had questions regarding the food. We opted for the 5 course and chose the honey lamb and the chicken with lemon and olives. My favorite was the chicken with lemon and olives however the lamb was phenomenal as well! By the time the meat came out, I was so stuffed I could barely eat half of what was on my place. This is probably one of the best Moroccan restaurants I've ever been to. I loved the rose water at the end. I couldn't stop smelling my hands. The belly dancer was amazing! Apparently the night we went, this particular belly dancer is an award winning belly dancer and has won numerous competitions. She only performs Tue and Sun nights. She is amazing! We even got private lessons for free! All in all, we would definitely come back here. My friend and I absolutely fell in love with this place. It's definitely one of my favorite restaurants in SF and definitely the #1 most memorable dinner experience I ever had.
author: Nari L.

description: The food here is absolutely amazing. It doesn't matter what you order, everything is delicious. The service is quick and exceedingly friendly even when they are busy. Belly dancing provides excellent entertainment, good spot for a second or third date.
author: Burch G.

description:
Group of 12 for went there for my husbands birthday.  We had the fix menu. The owner said this was the best way to go. I expressed to the owner the importance of having enough food for everyone. I was embaressed in front of our guest cause everyone left hungary. We ordered an extra plate of food besides the fix menu and was charged $80 for one plate of food.
Ugly old stinky towels was handed to everyone to dry their hands with after they came around with warm water for hand washing. 
I paid over $750 for 12 people and everyone left hungary. I was embaressed in from of my guest and would not recommend this place.
author: Ani O.

description:
How fun! This place was definitely an experience. I was a Morroccan Food Virgin before this place, so I can't really compare. But, what I did have was good. The 5-Course precursor sounded a little intimidating, but they gave a lot of time between each course, so it was easier to eat. 

Walking in, I just knew it was going to be a good night. The place looks like a supped-up tent. And it was crackin'. A lot of people there. Looks like you need a reservation to eat here. I was impressed with how they clean your hands, which was a cool surprise. At the end they garnish your hands with this Rose-Water which smells crazy good. The belly dancer was a nice addition. Dinner and a show for $30, not bad. 

I have to take away one star, cause some of the courses was awkward to eat with your hands. I mean you could ask for a fork, but you kind of want to stay authentic.
author: Jon C.

description:
So ten guys roll up to a Moroccan restaurant in a mini-van


 This sounds like the start of a bad joke, but it's actually the story of my cousin's stag party. See, I was charged with organizing this shindig, but was explicitly told by the bride-to-be, No strip clubs!


 I slyly smiled and said, I promise, no strip clubs.


 Yeah, well I remember the last time you did a bachelor party. No strippers coming over, either.


 Damn! What the hell happened to never talking about what happens at bachelor parties? I'd been ratted out from my usual loophole Fine, no strippers.


 The gears started turning in my head. There had to be some way to get my cousin to perform a final misogynistic act of shoving fistfuls of dollar bills into a waistband I know! A place with belly dancing!


 And El Mansour delivered. We all sat down amongst the plush decor, washed our hands, ate heartily, and watched the entertainment. We warned management ahead of time that this was a bachelor party - we'd be on our best behavior, but we wanted to make sure my cousin was properly embarrassed. Sure enough, they came through, and next thing you know, my cuzz was center stage - he unleashed his inner Middle Eastern man and actually raised his arms and swayed his hips like a pro. Afterward, the lovely dancer came and sat down with us for a while and was absolutely interesting to talk to. I found my loophole, and all of us had a memorable, enjoyable night without having to go anywhere sleazy.


 The food itself is pretty average for Moroccan. Granted, we don't have much of a basis for comparison around here, but trust me I'm brown and I live in Paris. I know Moroccan, m'kay?


 Service is overall excellent, and the staff were always courteous, and never showed any inclination of being worried about a bachelor party. My only niggle with El Mansour is that when they come around to wash your hands, the warm water is scented with rosewater. I freakin'... hate rosewater!!!
author: Omid T.

description:
This is a restaurant great for groups celebrating a special event.  We did so for my sister's birthday, but our reservation got pushed back a whopping 40+ minutes!  Half of us managed to crowd into the tiny waiting area, while the rest had to brave the chill outside.  We resorted to downing some shots at the next door bar to warm us up.  Birthday girl needed to get the party started anyhows!

The seating turned out rather awkward.  We did have a big group, but we ended up semi-segregated from others.  Those that sat on the outer side of the table had to sit on cushioned stools... no back support, seats kinda sunk down, and had poor access to the even lower tables.  It didn't feel very communal in the end.

The menu is set up mainly like a prix fixe.  You get a choice of entrees, and everyone gets the same soup, salad, and savory dessert.  The lentil soup was outstanding!  I always worry about lentil as it usually comes out gritty, but they slow cooked it long enough where the tiny beans just smooshed in between each sip.  The salad was a trio of cold vegetables mixed with a unique spiced dressing.  It wasn't very delectable for me.  Came off as bland and texturially confusing.  Most of it was raw and too chunky.  Oh and all of this is served with Morrocon bread, which I found a bit bland.  Good for sopping up sauce though.

I ordered the sea bass entree.  It was very flavorful, but a fellow diner who knows his seafood noted that it wasn't the usual rich, fatty Chilean sea bass.  So I kinda missed that oily silkiness of the fish.  But the tomato salsa and the lemony sauce was a good meld over the sea bass.

Dessert was pretty intersting.  They serve what is called a Bastela du Chef, a flat pastry filled with chicken!, almonds, and sugar.  Very good, but difficult to eat as everything kinda spills out in crumbles.  Their mint tea was like sugar water.

The belly dancer was a little awkward for me.  It's fun and interactive, sure, but she looked like an older version of that "I Dream of Jeannie" lady.  Not for me, sorry ma'am!  But it was great for my sis who got up and shook her milkshake.  

Then later on the belly dancer danced around looking for tips like a stripper!  Huh?  These people aren't getting any titty massages, and you even get offended when they try to slide it into your belt.  Save it for the pole workers.  And what do you expect the guys to do?  Put it in your little coin purse?

Visit once for birthdays or bachelor/ette parties.  Their atmosphere is better than their food.
author: Chris T.

description:
I've been here numerous times and have enjoyed myself each time.  
Once you are seated, you order from a small but very tasty menu.  The Bastela (pastry with chicken, almonds and spices) is divine.  They come by with a beautiful silver cauldron and you wash your hands while they pour over warm rose scented water.  They also provide you with a warm moist towel as you eat with your hands, not utensils. Friday and Saturday they have Belly Dancing.  Been there done that, I prefer to go when the dancers are not there, unless of course I am bringing someone for the first time.   Good solid place to take people with open minds without expectations.
author: Robyn C.

description: We made reservations last night for a nice night out, and when we arrived the hostess asked us to have a seat since they were packed. We did, ordered drinks to hasten the wait, and watched other people come in. Our reservation was for 8pm, and as we sat another couple came in and said they had an 8:30pm and a group followed them with an 8:45pm. We spoke to the hostess several times and she kept assuring us we were next. Then she seated the 8:30pm. She then seated the 8:45pm. When she FINALLY reappeared we , asked her why we were still waiting and she said she was sorry, but would get us refills on our drinks for free. We asked why she seated the other people first and she assured us they had earlier reservations. Since we were standing right there when they announced their reservation times, we disagreed and the hostess began to argue with us. Recommendation: don't bother.
author: Daniel D.

description:
Food: Delish, even if a bit messy (you eat with your hands)
Service: Short but prompt
Price: Good prix fix price - although the explanation of the difference between the two didn't make sense ($32.95 vs the $29.95), supposedly was the couscous, but I saw couscous with some of the $29 meals?

Went for my gf's 30th b-day party and it was lively and memorable. From the minute I entered the restaurant's very moroccan door I could tell it was going to be a hit. The belly dancer looked great and was extremely entertaining, especially with our rowdy group! She does a great job engaging all the parties in the restaurant.

Food had its memorable moments, including:
1. The lentil soup: well flavored, a little kick
2. The appetizer: puff pastry filled with chicken. Delish combonation of sweet and savory!
3. The rabbit - tender and perfectly cooked!
4. The mint tea: may be too sweet for some, but lovely for me!
5. The french white wine - can't remember the name, but the sweet one!

Pretty good but could use some improvements:
1. My sea bass stew. The stew was delish, but the sea bass portion was literally only enough for 4-5 bites. And that's my bites, not hubby bites.
2. The salad: good tasting of cucumbers, eggplant, carrots, but they only bring by the bread basket for you take one piece at a time. There's no way one slice of bread was going to cut it, so I had to use my hands to pick up the rest of the salad (which I'm sure was the reason why the salad plate was never cleaned)
3.  Lamb: The slices I tasted were just ok. Still had the gamey flavors.

Overall, a great experience and I would def recommend for any party!
author: Pachi C.

description:
Warmth! Friendliness! Flavors! Dancing! 

The first time I entered El Mansour a few weeks ago, I stepped inside what seemed to be a big family event. Lots of laughter, music, and happy conversations rang through the air. I decided not to stay as I was alone --but vowed that I would have to come back with a friend. 

My friend and I were seated at the table furthest from the door (near the entrance to the bathrooms and kitchen) and at first he took his seat against the wall while I sat across from him on the ottoman. In just a few minutes I realized that the ottoman was not going to be very comfortable and was invited to join my friend against the wall by our neighboring diners who were sweet enough to offer to move their table closer to ours if it would help us be more comfortable! 

When I first looked at the menu, I was a little intimidated by the prices -- $25 seemed like a lot for an entree -- but after reading further and realizing that the appetizer, salad, tea, bread, and dessert were all included, I relaxed. 

The food was incredible. Very tasty - flavorful spices without the heat of "spicy" food. Like others, I was a little put off by the appearance of the eggplant and other veggies which I was expected to eat with my hands -- I saw a few other diners with forks, but I was determined to try it! Delicious! Using the bread made some of the smaller, looser things easier to eat and added some variety of texture. 

The belly-dancing was a surprise. The music became louder and we weren't sure what was happening (maybe someone's favorite song? A birthday?) - but were very quickly put at ease by Stasha the belly dancer. She is charming, she is beautiful, and she's a very warm soul! After only a few minutes, she had warmed up the room. Separate parties of two and three diners became part of the same family -- we were all sharing a meal and experience together. 

There were some kids - but all were well-behaved. Someone's precocious little boy was the first to tip the dancer (as she playfully backed away from him while he was trying to place the bill into her costume -- and then he ran from her as she attempted to give him a kiss!) to the amusement and delight of all! 

If you've never tried Moroccan food, be brave and give it a try here at El Mansour. If you like Greek or other Mediterranean food styles, you will find the flavors familiar (although the combinations are quite unique!). You will not be disappointed. The staff was very friendly and helpful and made the experience very comfortable. Don't be put off by the idea of belly-dancing during dinner -- Stasha goes out of her way to make the experience a delightful one that's fun and family-friendly. 

A+ for atmosphere (a wedding tent with room for all) 
A+ for entertainment (music varies from quiet background noise permitting conversation to louder during the belly-dancing) 
A- for food (great tasting, excellent combinations, maybe a little more variety) 
A- for value (the portion was a little small on the mixed seafood, but the other choices seemed larger -- plus you won't leave hungry with the soup, salad, appetizer, and dessert!) 

Try something new and have fun at dinner!
author: Josh S.

description:
I had a blast here for my cousin's 30th birthday!  The service was great here!  They really cater to you and your party.  The decor really set the mood and ambiance for the night, casual, fun, and entertaining.  

The food was very good.  I enjoyed the lentil soup, the appetizer plate, and my lamb and eggplant.  If you like lamb, get this dish.  You will not regret it.  The belly dancer had a good performance and she was great at getting the guests to come out and perform with her!  It really made the night that much more lively.  I would definitely come back here for more belliful fun!
author: Han N.

description:
This place is an awesome dining experience. I had family in town for graduation and needed a restaurant to be both the place to eat and provide the entertainment for the night. Obviously the belly dancer was entertaining, but so was the dining experience itself! First they wash your hands over a silver apparatus, then you get soup, then an appetizer, then some "salad" thing, then your entree, then you wash your hands again in rose water (smelled so pretty!), then the best mint tea ever and two deserts. And all of it tastes fabulous!!! Just awesome! 
This places specializes in large groups, and you need to make a reservation. I HIGHLY recommend it for special occasions or if you just want to do something different.  Everyone in my group gushed about how much they love this place. The decor is pretty sweet too.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Moroccan version of dinner theatre.  Love it!!  I really have no idea how authentic any of the food or belly dancing is, but it's all great!  The food is all tasty, and you'll definitely be full after you've eaten the lentil soup with bread (make sure you ask for seconds on the bread), the "salad," the phyllo dough thing, your main course, then the delicious dessert with the pastry and banana thing.  Also gotta love the hand washing with the rose water they come around with.  The belly dancers are very skilled, and you're certain to be grabbed to dance with one of them if you are the birthday girl or boy.

Make sure you make reservations, especially for the weekend, or you'll be left out wandering around on Clement Street with not much else to do.  Overall, a great group/celebratory place.
author: Danielle B.

description:
The decor and ambiance transports you to another place entirely! And the food was sensational!
We had a large group of about 13 people for dinner and ordered a "family style" meal for everyone to enjoy.  This is definitely more than a meal, but an overall experience.  We enjoyed a number of different dishes, and had plenty of time between courses to enjoy conversation and beautiful dancing.  The entire staff was incredibly warm, the food was absolutely fantastic and the mint tea was some of the best I've ever had!
This is a great place for special celebrations.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Steven w.

description:
i really enjoy the rare outings here. i've been twice and the first is probably alway going to be the best. i have to say that the menu can be somewhat confusing. if you don't know that you can do family style, where you can share all the specialties instead of only choosing one, then you are missing out! 

this is really quality food, but if you don't enjoy eating with your hands, then this is NOT the place for you. you start with a rose water hand wash, which is divine and given a towel as your napkin...it's more absorbent. then the most delicious lentil soup is served with bread (which will also serve as a spoon). it is definitely all-you-can-eat bread, which will be needed for their version of a salad, or basically two dips (tomato and eggplant) and carrots and cucumber. then, the best savory pastry, called bastela, it's filled with chicken and has powdered sugar sprinkled on top. then comes the main entree, which is always cooked perfectly. you get one last rose water hand wash and get served the sweetest mint tea, ever.

this is a really special place...beware of the belly dancer, she will find the most reluctant guests and ask that you dance with her.
author: Marjie T.

description:
We went to El Mansour tonight as our Christmas eve celebration my husband and I. We are big fan of trying new foods and had never been to a Moroccan place before, and it's in our neighborhood!

We had impeccable service. We felt at home the moment we walked in, the staff were very nice and helpful, always close to answer questions, take orders, refill water glass, everything. They had a big smile, were very friendly but not overbearing, totally perfect!

The food was, to our taste, delicious. Neither of us are knowledgeable about Moroccan food, so we can't really give a comparison, but we both enjoyed the food, and how the courses were spaced, very much.

The atmosphere in there is very nice and friendly. The lay out of the place makes it easy for the different groups to interact, but you aren't sitting all over each others. It was a slow-ish night though, I don't know what it's like when the place is packed. 

Only complain is that there were no dancers. They had a problem with the sound system today, so they could not play the music for the performance. That in itself is forgivable, though one would think they would get somebody in there to repair since it's their trademark really. What is less forgivable, is that we were never notified of the fact. We waited for a while, until we finally asked (after we paid and everything) and the waiter finally admitted the problem. For the price you ask my friend, that should have been said at the beginning, and a discount offered or something to make up for the fact.

The service and the food was too good for that to ruin the night, but that was really unfortunate.
author: Willow K.

description:
I went here a couple years ago for a friend's birthday, and we had a pretty good time. It is usually pretty hard to find parking in this area (c'mon, its clement!), so you should probably give yourself enough time to find a good parking spot if you've got reservations. 

When I walked up to the place, I didn't know what to think because I could hear the clacking of finger cymbals,  & ululating and the big blue door was closed so I didn't want to disturb whatever was going on behind it. haha...  Of course, there was a belly dancer behind that  big blue door. Yepp, dinner AND a show!

We had a party of over 13 people and they accomodated us comfortably.  
Everyone ordered different entrees, but with the entree, you get 4 other courses and warm bread. The best part of the meal had to be the banana fritters and the pouring of the best tea I had in my life. No, I take that back, the best part of the meal was when they poured rose water on our hands and my friend got scared because he thought it was gonna be piping hot. 

If you want to try something new for a date or special occasions, this place is perfect. You get a good meal, good entertainment, and a memorable experience, especially if you get chosen to dance with the belly dancer.
author: Mary C.

description:
El Mansour has such a great atmostphere and is really one of those unique restaurants that you have to try. There is belly dancing involved too!! We got the older lady but she was very fit and loved getting the crowd involved. She will pick on the guys in the group if you do end up going with some guys. The whole experience was just wonderful. The chicken, lamb, lentil soup, salad, and the sweet but salty pancake filled with meat thing called bastela du chef.  The bastela du Chef is absolutely delicious! Sounds weird since it's sweet and salty but it's so good that it's the one thing that I remember about eating here. I came here like a few months ago so yea. 

The main meat dish was good because the meat wasn't dry. I am actually just speaking for the chicken with onions and olives. I think I should have been more adventurous and tried the one with raisins instead. I just thought this whole experience was different with the nice flavors and all. It's a good thing and I would like to try more restaurants like this one.
author: Shu L.

description:
I had a party of 31 and the staff was very helpful to us all. The bummer was it had to be family style food as oppose to each person ordering something for themselves. It made sense though why they needed to do that. The atmosphere was great, super friendly staff, great food (love the rabbit) and the mint tea is soo yummy!! 
A friend and I even got a tour of the kitchen and it's very neat and clean. 

I really recommend the restaurant for small or large parties. The belly dancer rocks as well! Very personable and entertaining!
author: Ang P.

description:
My husband and I have been to this Reastaurant for many times. We did try other Moroccan reastaurant in the bay area, but El Mansour Reastaurant easily the finest Moroccan reastaurant in San Francisco and bay area. It's worth for us to travel from San Jose to San Francisco.
The food was very good and the atmosphere was homey. we really enjoyed our food, it seemed very fresh and testy, In addition we loved the service. Houda the owner was very charming and very nice.
author: Ruqaya R.

description: Once you enter through the beautifully decorated doors of El Mansour, you are whisked away into a fantasy land of fine food, good service, and fun belly dancing all in the backdrop of what feels like a old fashioned harem's quarters.  The food is good, authentic, I hear (which is good for never-tried-morrocan-food-before me).  I loved the decor and seating.  The rose-water pre-meal rinse was touching...and also where I found out I am allergic to rose water.
author: Shinny L.

description:
One of the greatest dining destinations in the City! It may look kind of shady from the outside, considering it has no windows...but when you step inside, you'll feel like you're just in Morroco. They even wash your hands with rose water when you're finished with your meal!

The place is decorated in traditional Morrocan style, with plush seats and textiles galore. They have a prix fix menu that includes a meat/vegetarian dish with soup, salad, dessert and really, really sweet mint tea. I split the chicken with raisins and onions with a friend and it was very tender and tasty! I would recommend sharing if you can't handle that much food. 

But of course, the highlight of this place is the belly-dancer. She definitely interacts with the audience so be prepared to dance if you are within her vision and reach! Great place to go if you're in a big group.

If only they had hookah...
author: Natalie T.

description:
great for large parties, you get to eat a ton of delicious moroccan food with your hands while gawking, i mean, appreciating the art of belly dancing. i always look forward to the sweet mint tea at the end of the meal. also, the service is always very friendly and accommodating.

i am all about the bastela du chef! it's a sweet and savory phyllo pastry dish filled with chicken, almonds, and hella spices. it's so good, i wish i could marry it!
author: krys s.

description: This place is great for a group of friends or a date. When I first entered this place I was quickly transformed another country. The decor was awesome and full of color, I felt like I was in Morocco.  The food is very pricey but good.  I would only visit this place for a special occasion. Make sure you do not eat beforehand because you will be stuffed.
author: Matthew L.

description: This place was recommended to me by a friend while I was visiting in the San Francisco area.  It was a great experience, good food, fun atmosphere.  They bring you different courses before the entree and you get to enjoy each course.  The Bastela du Chef is my favorite and while it seems like a dessert it is not, very tasty.  The lentil soup was also delicious.  I had the lamb and chicken and it was very tasty.  I normally don't like lamb in America but this place knew how to prepare it. The couscous was the only thing that was not as good as I've had at other Moroccan restaurants.  The waiter was fun and attentive, in spite of the place being crowded. We went a little early and that seemed to be the thing to do because by the time we left there was quite a wait. They have a belly dancer come out and entertain.  It is a great place to go and enjoy some great food and entertainment!
author: Kathy M.

description:
I've never been to Morocco -- but this place makes me think I'd like it and that I'd gain 20 pounds on my trip.

The food is great.  Order from the "Specialty" side of the menu, and you'll begin a 5 course journey into food bliss.  The lentil soup, cold veggie salad platter, and homemade bread hunks (to be used as your utensil) will fill you up if you don't watch out... but it's hard to stop; the bread is soft, oh so fresh, and addicting.  Your entree will follow (I suggest the honey lamb), and then perhaps the best part of all: BANANA FRITTERS!  I generally avoid this friendly fruit but anything fried tastes like something else entirely, and these are divine.

And don't forget the belly-dancing!  Entertainment whilst you dine, but be warned!  Don't make eye contact with the dancer or you'll be pulled up as part of the show (I learned my lesson the hard way... and it wasn't pretty).
author: Chelsee H.

description:
This is my first time at the place and yes i can see how a restaurant like this could be fun and I was almost ready to do that until I asked the waiter or manager (he seemed kinda important but might of been just a host or door man?) but me and my girlfriend asked if you can order a la Cart (or by it's self!?) whatever he gave me attitude and tried to detour me from ordering just a small plate of something like a kabob by it's self (mind you we ordered a bottle of wine!)saying that what is on the menu is supposed to be an experience..............what??? I can care less about a belly dancer and sitting on a chair that makes my knee hit my chin and that's not the point what trying to say is why cant we order small plates and please don't give people a hard time because we don't want an experience..........we just want to eat and try new food!!!!!! 


I might go back....if I wanted the experience!!
author: Matt B.

description:
I'm a big fan of cuisine from middle-east/mediterranean.  When I saw the menu and pictures I couldn't wait for this visit.  It was a let down for multiple reasons.  

Firstly, food was okay.  The appetizer, Bastela du Chef, was little sweet.  I normally don't associate sweet with my appetizer.  I had their lamb and chicken specialty entree.  The lamb was good.  The meat came off the bone effortlessly and was tender.  Flavor has acceptable.  Chicken had flavor on the skin but once you get past the skin it was just bland white meat.  I've had better Moroccan food in south bay. 

Secondly, ambiance was a big disappointment.  They played the music for belly dancing so loud we couldn't hear ourselves two feet away.  I guess they didn't want us to talk but focus on the dance!  The seating arrangement was also strange.  For a table of four they had two seats facing the wall.  The ones sitting there had their backs to the dancer who was dancing on the middle of the floor.  The only way to watch without having a neck sprain is to turn and sit, which means we not only can't talk but can't eat either.  On the positive note, the dancer was hot!

I wouldn't recommend this place especially for this $$$.
author: Yes G.

description:
Moroccan food, mmm yum. 

We went here for one of our friend's birthdays, it's definitely a cool experience and you can't tell that it's a restaurant from the outside because it's so unnoticable. Inside is a different story, the atmosphere is really cozy and they even had a belly dancer!  Some of my friends *ahem* birthday boy *ahem* was too chicken shit to dance with the belly dancer though. All good.

I really loved their appetizer and the honey almond lamb shanks, sooooo goooood! *drools*  Service was pretty good and they even gave us forks because some of us were uncomfortable using our hands =X. That mint tea they served us in the end was pretty damn good (considering my obsession with mint)!

Ohh they even had rabbit!! I never had rabbit before lol, it was good though.

Overall experience was pretty good, but unless I make more money and have more money to spend, I won't be coming back here for a while because it's pretty expensive. You get a great dinner and a show for your experience lol.
author: Natalie G.

description:
This is my favorite place to eat!  I have been going here every year for my birthday for about the past 11 years.

It's a five course meal and you eat everything with your hands except the dessert (however, back in the day they didn't bring out forks with the dessert).  You can ask for silverware at any point throughout the meal but why when it's so much fun to eat with your hands. 

I think it's better to make a reservation because if you're planning to go there on a weekend, the place is normally packed.

The belly dancing is really cool.  One reviewer said that she avoids the belly dancer because they turn the music up but why wouldn't they?  They are providing a show with your dinner and them turning the music up a)notifies you that the belly dancer is coming out and b)makes you pay attention to the cool show that's being provided.  You can continue talking with your friends or date in 10 minutes when she's done.

This place is perfect for a date (my fiance and I came here for our first valentine's day together) and it's perfect for a large group (we had 15 people there for my birthday a couple years back).  Just make sure you go there hungry because five courses is a lot of food and it's all good!
author: Chiara M.

description: Great for birthday parties and belly dancing.  The best dish is the bastilla, a powdered sugar pastry with a vegetarian or meat filling.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I'm been here. The people who brought me here looooove it. Well, as soon as I walked in, I regretted it. Not for the great, attentive service. Not for the sugar-dusted pigeon pie (sweetbreads, yes. sweet meat, no.). Not because I wanted to eat with utensils and sit at an actual table. 

It's because as soon as you walk in, it's so obvious this is a place to go with an object of desire. Couples were cooing to each other, and feeding each other and getting turned on with each subsciquent handful. It took 'love bites' to a new level. I was pissed. Surrounded by love. Me? Sitting with two old-ass gay men who aren't even turned on by each other. You can't even get a Dickels and a pony here to chase the blues away.
author: Rene D.

description: Great Food, Great Dance, no rush and superb recommendation!
author: Christian H.

description: One time experience only. Went there for part of BF's bday celebration mainly due to the belly dance performance. They prob. only has two belly dance performances per night at 7:30 & 9:30pm. However the dance was short only abut 15 minutes. Food and service (depends on which waiter you get)  was just average.
author: Stef L.

description: Pretty decent middle eastern food. Quite a few courses leading to the main entree followed by Morrocon mint tea and dessert. Nice ambience after the remodelling last year and good for dates or groups up to 10 ppl. Love the Honey and prunes chicken main entree!
author: Yan M.

description:
I was surprised to see 3 different families celebrating birthdays of babies. What parent thinks that a 2 year old prefers Moroccan food and a pretty belly dancer? 

I was there for a Sunday dinner for the first time with 4 friends and one proclaimed, "It's like we're on vacation!" The atmosphere was really nice but the food was okay. The appetizer and dessert were pretty good, the tea was FABULOUS but the main entree was just okay/good and those in my company felt the same way. You pay $27 and it commits you to a full meal (appetizer, salad, one main entree, dessert and tea). Everything but the main entree is served on one plate and to be shared among everyone at the table. This is not your place if you're not comfortable with eating off the same plate as others and with your hands. You can request forks or attempt to scoop up mushy eggplant salad item with a piece of bread. We got forks even though 4/5 of us were Filipino -- people who are accustomed to not using utensils, shoving morsels of food into our mouths with our fingers. 

It was fun to watch the non-rhythmic white men trying to impress their dates by accepting the challenge of the belly dancer under the flashes of digital cameras and camera phones. It was gross to know that the older man in the corner was clearly aroused by the dancer, as he sat with his wife and college-aged daughter. I thought it was obscene to see people tuck dollar bills into her outfit. SHE'S NOT A STRIPPER! Geez! That is seriously disrespectful. Do you tuck money onto the bodies of minimally dressed African or Brazilian dancers? NO. You're suppose to appreciate the beauty of the dance, not objectify it's sensual characteristics. People can be pigs!

Although it was entertaining to see people wince with embarrassment when chosen by the dancer, it was also terrifying. I didn't want to be dragged into the center of the room to display my inability to move my hips! People will assume that I suck in bed (which I don't, thankyouverymuch! I won't claim to be a stud but I can show you a little sumthin' sumthin'). Okay, I'm straying off topic... but overall, it was a fun experience. I don't necessarily like to pay one price and commit to an entire meal. I like to have the option to get a salad or not get one, etc. For me, it wouldn't bother me terribly if I never went again but I would definitely consider it as a place to bring my out-of-town visitors.
author: Elsie M.

description:
The food and the atmosphere were quite good and somewhat exotic.
The belly dancer was...a good dancer but had a face that only Fellini would have loved.
author: Peter O.

description:
Pretty good food, average prices for San Francisco. Nice staff. The decor is a little tacky once you get inside (kind of like Moroccan Disneyland), but it's fun. Good place for a date or a group, but not really for kids.

The bellydancer was very professional and enthusiastic about the dance (we talked with her a bit). They have a dancer every night, which is rare and a great opportunity for us to experience a unique art. If you really want to honor the dancer, shower her with the bills instead of jamming them in her waistband.
author: buttercup r.

description:
The atmosphere, decor, and service at El Mansour are awesome. All the furniture and decorations are imported from Morocco, so you feel like you're in another world. What's also great is that they have free entertainment (belly dancing) every night. The belly dancer will try to get people to dance with her, so join in on the fun!

The food is good, but not as good as I remember it (I went to El Mansour 4 years ago, then went back last week). The portions seemed smaller, for one thing. Also, they now provide forks and knives to customers. I was kind of disappointed, because I think eating with your hands was what made El Mansour so unique. It's as if they lost a part of their character. 

Overall, I'd still recommend this place.
author: Cee J.

description:
We loved this place. It is a bit pricey, but it really isn't for the amount of food that you get.

You are seated, then the waiter comes with a dish where you wash your hands. The towels to dry your hands become also your napkin. Then there is soup, salad, appetizer, entree (which you order from the menu) and then dessert. Oh yeah and it is finished off with green mint tea. By the time you leave you are ready to be rolled out.

We took our then 3 year old daughter with us. She was fascinated by the belly dancer and though she seemed like she didn't watch the dancer, but she came home and repeated the repertoire exactly like the dancer did :))

I highly recommend this place.
author: Mona O.

description:
Are you ok with eating with  your fingers?  If not, this isn't the place for you.   

Try to get here a little early because you'll have to drive around for parking.  I

This is fun place if you have a group of people.  The food was good, but I was suppose to get sea bass and they used another fish... tricky dicky... 

The belly dancer started around 7:45pm and they only do one show, about 20 minutes long.  So if you get there about 8:30pm... you missed her.  

The mint tea was ok.  I've had better.   

Minus two star for switching out the fish!!
Minus one star because over all... it was meh
author: Ling K.

description:
I put 4-stars because it was fun to have dinner and a ~20-minute belly dancer show though the friends we went with say the proportions and show are not as good as years past but service was still great. This night we tried a bunch of different items. Everything comes with soup, salad mix and chicken backed cinnamon pastry type appetizer as well as desert tea/sweets. The lamb entrees were definitely the best, cooked to perfection and good cuts, the honey/almond was sweet as expected and the eggplant was mild but delicious. Chicken kabob was breast and a little dry as expected (came with couscous which is hard to eat with no silverware!), the split whole lemon chicken was much juicer. Seafood mix dish was good but not proportions were small.

Everything you eat with your hands and most dishes are shared so don't be shy and don't bring any friends that are fighting off a cold! This was fun to go to once but I don't usually fork out $35+/person for a meal (not counting drinks) so I probably won't repeat as it wasn't extraordinary enough for my frugal self (i'd give it 3-stars for value :P).

Also not sure why some were complaining about a charge on the split, obviously the $30 a meal charge is for the show, salad, appetizers, etc and it would be unreasonable to think there would be no sur-charge.
author: noah a.

description:
This is probably my FAVORITE restaurant. I've been here for birthdays, Valentine's, and I take my visitors here. The food is just delicious. They always have the same belly dancer who's really fun (she makes you dance with her and one time gave me a super cool gift for my birthday. It was this fortune telling fish that told you what kind of lover you are!) and I love the atmosphere and everyone's super friendly. Best of all, you can eat with your hands!
My favorite is the lamb with honey and almond. I'm not usually a fan of lamb, but this is soo tender and not at all gamey. It's like a sweet and savory dish. And I love the bastia. It's so good! That's all I ever order. I've also tried the seafood entree and I think the chicken with lemon and prunes. Everything is good, you can't go wrong. It always feels like a special occasion when you eat here. =)
author: Mina T.

description:
I ate here four months ago and I still think about their Bastela du Chef, which forever (positively) changed my mind about chicken and powdered sugar together in one dish. Yeah it sounds nasty and I thought it was kinda sketch BUT IT IS DELICIOUS. In fact, each course was a pleasant surprise. 

Add in the friendly people who work there and BAM...you get a great meal ($30ish) in a fun atmosphere. This is a place for groups/families/couples/anyone!
author: Kristine B.

description:
0 star.
that's what this restaurant deserves.

My mom's visiting from Japan. She is fighting with multiple cancers. She loves to try different types of food. Obviously I have eaten in this restaurant many times before, every time I visited, I had to wait at least one hour, well, I used to think the wait was worth it cuz the food's good. 

 I wanted my mom to try their food. I called in to make a reservation. this guy told me if I could make it within 30 mins, I could have a table. Great. I told him I was at Costco, I was going there RIGHT THEN. I drove fast, I'd known the earlier we got there, the better the chance there was for no-waiting. So, I got there, at 6:20, The place was EMPTY, but some ppl were starting showing up. My mom, my son, who is 2 years old, and I were taken to the table. We got a table and got seated.

After a few minutes past, we got water and menu. At the same time, I started noticing this obviously -owner looking guy circling around our seats, looking at us like we were pests or something lower than him, then, the waiter came back,saying "...bla bla bla, these ppl were not supposed to show up, but they came...bla bla bla"

So they over-booked. Because the guy who I talked on the phone was new.  although there were so many seats sill empty and ppl hasn't shown up yet, we, who have already got seated, were told, 
"Can you come back one hour and a half later?"

What pissed me off the most was, the owner didn't even apologize. It's true this mistake was caused by this "new" guy, but, hey, that's your restaurant, your source of income, right? 

 He told me, "I can show you the reservation book!!!" and... most of all, he said to my face, 

"If you come back one and a half hour later, I will give all of you FREE FOOD."
author: Yuri K.

description:
oh el mansour.

i had never been until last night and from the moment i was guided in out of the rain all i could breathe out was "wow". i've been feeling less than stellar lately with living in the pacific northwest and dealing with the grey world it has to offer in the winter. el mansour transported me out of my funk and right into a plush womb-like world, where the seating is low and comfortable especially for girls who are 4'10". a decadent place in which more and more incredible finger food comes to you and a very beautiful woman belly dances in an exciting and shimmery costume that looks like metal waves of an ocean. she even got me to dance! bless her, watching her clear joy and elegance totally shoved my world weary facade aside and reminded me that i could find wonder in the dim lighting of a magical restaurant. 

i keep trying to think of clever and funny things to report here but honestly, the place is so beautiful and intimate that i just want to offer the truths of it. 

the servers are adept and very sweet. the food is perfectly seasoned, copious for the $32 price and well presented. I had a lovely two hours with my handsome date, who was recognized immediately by the staff and fawned on (much to both of our delights). we smiled indulgently like lucky things the whole time and from what I could see, everyone else in the place did too.
author: Alysia A.

description: Good food and great service! Was hoping for the dancers, but probably had to stay later! Overall good experience!! Will definitely come back again!!
author: Michael L.

description:
I went to this place with Blake H (see his review), my husband and a group of friends when we visited San Fran.  Amazing!  I have never had anything like it.  Great for groups.  You get food and entertainment all for a very reasonable price.

FYI- they are vegetarian friendly and all the food is so flavorful.
author: Paige R.

description:
Mmmmmmmmm...(ahem), oh, sorry, I was thinkin' of the collective taste of the food, the entertainment and the atmosphere that this place has to offer.  Mind you, I'm writing this review about 6 months after the fact and I'm still reminiscing about it.  Overall it was a fun, relaxing and fulfilling experience to eat here.

Best enjoyed if you're with a group of friends on a special outing...or a not so special outing, it really doesn't matter.  Just be sure to get your food "family style" or whatever they call it so everyone can enjoy the experience together.  And if you're feeling brave, try the rabbit, I've never had so tasty.

And let's not forget the great entertainment, a bellydancer who I believe is in her 50's, but you would never know it.  If you're lucky she just might invite you to get up and dance with her :)
author: Jonathan B.

description:
They're awfully sweet and nice there, and the service was good. The belly dancer was fun and personable, even if she comes across a little "whatever happened to  Jeannie the Genie?"  (Think spectacularly well preserved middle aged white lady straight out some sort of late-era Heinlein sex-positive fantasyland.)  The food was really good in spots - the fish tangine especially. 

However, I found the seating arrangement akward (everyone's against the wall facing the middle of the room, so you're all staring at each other), the bread too fluffy to serve as an eating utensil (a wedge of cakey bread doesn't turn a saucy meal into fingerfood),  the mint tea oversweetened, and the bastilla much too much like eating a turnover with chicken in it. 

My friend and I agreed it was like the Benihana's of middle eastern food.  This is a slightly expensive yet  rather middle of the road theme restaurant. (Dinner for two and a bottle of wine came to $105 plus tip.) 

In other words, if you've been to Aziza or even La Med, you're not going to be that  impressed by the food or the atmosphere.   Go to Aziza, instead. It's even more expensive but worth every penny. (Although,  the tables are uncomfortably close to each other at Aziza. You won't care though, because the food is that exquisite, but that's another review.)
author: jette s.

description:
From the outside, you'd think you were at a local dive bar. It really looks NOTHING like you would expect. You open the door, and it's magically teleported you to an African destination. This place really helps make your night, not only blessed with great food, but an experience you might only get overseas. 

Just thinking about the lamb, with honey and almonds, makes my mouth water! The food here is pretty authentic. It's rich in flavor, and easily covers both savory and sweet. 

When the dancers come out, it gets loud and fun. If you're not shy, get up and dance. Sometimes they dancer might even pull you up. Have fun if she does =).

The tea they bring out is a great way to close the meal too. They pour it in their unique authentic manner. They raise the teapot high,  to get it bubbly. It makes everyone watch, and want to drink some a.s.a.p.

Please don't be afraid to try something new. This place is a memory, you shall never forget. It's  definitely a hidden SF treasure.
author: Charles K.

description:
I went here for the second time right before New Year's, and it was every bit as good as the first. This place is great, and a lot of fun (especially in a group setting). The ambiance is definitely there from the setting, which is designed to look like you are inside a Moroccan tent. The belly dancing is also an added bonus, which is especially fun if you can manage to egg one of your group members to join in the dancing.

As for the food? Simply amazing. The lentil soup that the meal starts out with is delicious (and I don't even like lentils!), and it is followed up by a delicious salad platter of carrots, tomatoes, eggplant, and cucumber. Since everything is to be eaten with your hands, the servers provide a lot of soft white bread that goes well with these starters. The next course is the Chicken Bastela, which is a chicken and almond dish that is wrapped in a phyllo pastry skin and covered in... powdered sugar? I don't know how it works, but my entire group loved it and we practically wiped that plate clean.

All the entree courses are great, but my favorite by far is the Lamb Brochette. I will never understand how they get that much flavor into such a tiny piece of lamb, but I want more.

The meal is finished off with a delicious mint tea, banana fritters, and a puff pastry dessert. Again, zero complaints.

The service staff was really friendly, they were very accommodating for our vegetarian company, and the owner was incredibly nice when we happened to finish up after the restaurant closed. He was also understanding and very helpful when we needed to split parts of our bill (our party was 25 people) onto separate cards.

Visit this place!
author: Brandon T.

description:
My friend Mina took me here for my birthday.  It was the first time i had moroccan food and i thought it was delicious :o)

I don't remember what i ordered because i kind of had a sample of a few different dishes.  They were all very tasty though.  The atmosphere is very cozy and good for groups.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Ive gone here twice with my bro.  I usually dont tend to try places like these (even tho I wish I did) but Im very glad I did and hope to go more in the future.

My first time here I thought maybe it doubled as a huka tobacco smoking joint...haha.  Everybody here was on couches and ottomans (surprised nobody lying on the floor) just relaxing and enjoying each others  company.

The atmosphere and decor, along with the music and belly dancing are nice crowd pleasers even tho you'll NEVER find me up there dancing with her.

I LOVE the moroccan tea here.  I saw on tv that the higher they pour the tea from is a sign of respect or something like that.  I'm not big on tea in general...but DAM this was good tea!

I like the 2 or 3 appetizers included with the meal:  the nice salad, that chicken filled flaky pastry with the powdered sugar on top (see pictures) and how you wash your hands at the table.

Food here is very good.  I liked the lamb a lot.  I also remember good chicken.  I tried one of the desserts here that was good...forgot the name.

So yeah, if you wanna try something different and dont mind sitting in an open type area with couches along the wall and ottomans twds the inside, then definitely try this place out.
author: Gilbert C.

description: This place was awesome. The food was delicious (go for their specialities menu...it costs a few dollars more but EVERYTHING we had was amazing...I had the lamb and chicken). Our male dining partners loved the belly dancer and the service was spot on. I would highly recommend this place and I would go back again in a heart beat.
author: Jessica P.

description:
our party of 6 had an amazing dinner here.  the food is authentic and quite tasty.  do come here on an empty stomach as it's a 5 course meal. you get your money worth, and quite more, with their ample portions.  you eat with your hands, and they bring over an ornate pitcher and basin to wash your hands in before and after dinner.  our server was great.  the belly dancer was fun and had the crowd participating in her routines.  

i would highly recommend this place for a date, group dinner, and anything in between!
author: Sheri N.

description: We went there tonight for my birthday dinner and had a great time! The food was excellent and so was the entertainment. We loved the belly dancer and actually got up and danced with her. We had such a good time that we will definitely go back again and bring our family and friends!
author: Kimberly B.

description: I reserved El Mansour for my husband's birthday. From the moment I called to arrange my reservations for 20 people, I received exceptional customer service. They worked with all my demands. We had excellent service & food and they even held the place open for my party to continue after hours. The food is awesome, service orientated staff and management! We will be back!
author: Yasmin Z.

description:
spent 10 days in morocco this year for vacation, and this place is prob as close to authentic as anywhere i've seen.  the interior is AMAZING, and truly feels like morocco.

great, attentive service from men dressed in moroccan clothing

delicious tasty well-prepared food (we lasted with our hands all the way until the chicken came --- we asked for forks then, and got them without any hassle) standard tagines, cous cous, and kebabs. lentil soup, salad, pastilla, and mint tea.

bellydancer was a surprise and she was very good. i thought it got tacky when she started getting dollar bills stuffed in her bra and she started picking diners to dance with her tho....
author: Dora F.

description:
I had so much fun eating at this restaurant! I went with my husband and 6 other friends. No waiting since we had reservations. Beautiful interior with a great atmosphere. We got to watch a belly dancer during the dinner. Hey, live entertainment with dinner! AND she pulled people up to dance with her! So fun. The food was fantastic! We had the 5 course dinner and no complaints whatsoever! The amazing thing was that we spent almost 3 hours in the restaurant, but the time flew by because it was soooo fun in there!! Would definitely go back there again!

4 stars: we sat on cushions on the floor which was fine by me. But my friend had a back problem and there was nowhere else for him to sit at. So just know that the dinner will last a while and find a position so you don't injure yourself!
author: Felicia S.

description:
Ive been here twice, the first time, I found it so refreshing to find a great new place, that was outside the bubble that is SF restaraunts. The food is awesome, the venue is cozy and so much fun. The belly dance show is hillarious, and so great. 

The only con I had was our 8:00 Reservation, was moved to 930, by the time they could finally seat us, I had forgotten this, however by the time i finished my wonderful meal. (great Dive bar next door ;)
author: Kathy M.

description: I came here to celebrate my sister's birthday and although the location is not even close to where I live...it didn't matter because I had a great time...we all did! You come inside and it is inviting and exotic.  It's a great place to come to when you want something different, something out of your comfort zone. The host was friendly and the staff were attentive...the food was great, too! A great variety of choices to choose from especially if you are vegetarian...I had the chicken and vegetables...you may think how simple but the flavors are enticing and make you crave for for...the whole experience of coming here is a a treat...they don't just treat you like a customer but make you feel like you are being invited home. Plus, you get a show...there's a belly dance after her performance...you may join in the fun! What a great place to be especially with great food and company!
author: Mel P.

description: I love this Moroccan restaurant.  I never liked lamb until I tried eating the lamb dish with prunes at "El Mansour."  I really love how Moroccan-style lamb is prepared and cooked.  The lamb meat was so flavorful and had just the right amount of sweetness from the prunes.  The meat was cooked to perfection and was so succulent, it practically fell off of the bone.  So, if you are not a big fan of lamb and have never tried any Moroccan-style lamb dishes, I highly recommend ordering the lamb with prunes dish at "El Mansour," it will blow your taste buds away!  Nom, nom, nom.  I live in NYC now and I still remember how delicious the food was here.  I will definitely try to eat here again whenever I am back in San Francisco for a trip.
author: Victoria G.

description: my bf and i decided to check this restaurant out to try something different. we enjoyed the food as well as the entertainment, but the service needs improvement. our reservations were for 9 pm , but we weren't seated til about 9:30. crammed in a small space, hearing sounds echoing of other guests stating they had reservations....people we all have reservations. once seated we went through this 5 course meal, we received our entree at 11 pm , who eats at 11pm, not i! the place is run by an asian man, who obviously is more concerned with how much money he can make in a night oppose to quality of the entire dining experience.  i'm sure there are better places with the same concept
author: Pia Z.

description:
Went here for my birthday last year, and loved it!

We had to wait a bit, but there's music playing and the decor was beautiful.  You feel almost like you're in a tent as opposed to a building.

The food was really good, the dancer pretty good, and end presentation of tea was fun.

I will definately go back!
author: Miriam G.

description:
Before I get to the 1 star part of this review, the food was good, but there are many other better ways to spend $50/person in the city. The menu is the least flexible I've ever heard of, where you HAVE to get a gigantic dinner whether you want one or not. There are only two price levels, and no sharing allowed, so everyone who walks in the door will be spending $40 before they even start thinking about drinks. Because every entree comes with a soup, a salad, bread, an appetizer, and a dessert, with ample time in between, that also means you are spending AT LEAST 2hrs here. The ambiance was fun, and the belly dancer was good, but I've seen better on both counts... actually, the Turkish girl in our group danced with the belly dancer for a bit, and I think demonstrated there's no number of classes you can take that can replace actually having grown up in a belly dancing culture.

Fine whatever, I'd probably give them 3 stars if that summed up the experience, and 4 if the service was good.

The singular star is because for the very first time in my life I've actually had a bad experience with the wait staff at a restaurant. I eat with a total disregard for price, eat everything and anything, tip well, am rarely in a hurry (when I eat), generally rate places based on just the food, and am the kind of guy who gets more entertainment than genuine rage from the inconsiderate jerks who cut me off in traffic. I am a VERY easy customer. A waitress would basically have to pick a fight with me to get me upset... which is exactly what happened.

I showed up after a late lunch, and asked to share a meal with my girlfriend. The waitress explained why that doesn't work and they would "go bankrupt if they did", and without any back talk I ordered a second meal. Then we ordered drinks, and I asked if we could split a bottle of wine. The response I was going for was, "yes, how many glasses would you like?" Instead, I got an eye roll and an exasperated "yes of course, we just can't split the food because blah blah blah bankrupt." Exactly the same thing I had just heard, but with the attitude cranked up to 11.

Now, in a normal restaurant, "may we split a bottle of the house red?" would be a simple, mostly rhetorical question. But here - where they have to explain why you can't split a dish, have to explain why you just got a bathroom hand towel instead of a napkin, have to explain what each dish is, have to explain that you don't get utensils, have to explain the perfume stuff they just splashed on your hands (and incidentally in your water glass) - you would think they would be used to questions of all sorts, and ready to handle them without becoming irate. But no, let the misunderstanding continue...

I admittedly did a poor job of explaining my intent with the question because my friends and I were busy defending ourselves, and somehow - for the THIRD time - we drew out her whole "no splitting food blah blah bankrupt" spiel. With much effort, I dropped it, and said, "ok, thank you, 4 glasses and the bottle of wine, please." But by then such a scene had been made that, not only did the other half of our table look confused and horrified by the exchange, all the other tables in the area were now staring at us. Then one of the girls made the mistake of asking what happened, so I quietly explained to her, and the waitress barks at us, "do you want me to take the order or not." As in, "you can get out if you don't like it." Of course the music was low at the time, and this was all absolutely humiliating. Had I not been in a group of 8, I would have certainly taken her up on the offer and left.

The other waiters weren't much better. Somehow they could pour tea into a glass from about 5ft up, but had a hell of a time getting ice water into the glass from an inch or two away. Another waiter clumsily spilled soup on my leg and didn't even apologize. I can only hope the mean lady told them to give us terrible service, because that is pathetic if they independently came to those performances.

When we paid the bill it occurred to me that each person in the group had come with hundreds of dollars in cash. In the 2hrs we spent there, I'm certain the eight of us could have easily taken out 4 to 6 bottles. But we stopped at one, because none of us wanted to give another dime to this establishment. 

This place is a joke. It actually pains me to see this place have such a high rating on Yelp.
author: James Y.

description:
El Mansour is contrived to be as "authentically" Moroccan as possible.  When you walk in the door, you're meant to feel like you're inside a tent (the ceilings have cloth hanging from them to give this effect) and you sit on the floor with embroidered cushions and low tables.

The food is delicious.  There's a set menu where you choose from a list of entrees and then it comes with soup, bastela (phyllo dough stuffed with chicken an almonds with cinnamon and powdered sugar), mint tea and dessert.  You eat with your fingers (please don't be a jerk and insist on silverware, just wash your damn hands and eat!) and they provide you with a towel and put a basin of water on the table between courses so that you can rinse off.

Finally, they have bellydancing, which is entertaining, but honestly when I went there I was concentrating more on the bastela than on the dancing ... it was that good.  

It's a little bit pricey for me, so really this is a good place to go for a date or for someone's birthday or anniversary or something.
author: Matthew M.

description:
This is my favorite place to go for my birthday. It can easily accommodate large parties and the food is amazing. The menu is slightly unusual. You choose your entree and the rest of the meal is fixed. Lentil soup, vegetable plate, Bastela du Chef (yummy shredded spiced chicken topped with a pastry dough and sprinkled with powdered sugar), entree, small dessert and mint tea. Also, you need to ask for silverware if you want to use them. Otherwise you eat with your fingers and bread. I reccommend the lamb with honey and almonds.
They used to be located next door but moved to their new location a few years ago.
author: Amy W.

description:
