The best: the warm water poured over your hands before and after you eat, (rosewater after as well!) the tea poured from on high, the many small courses to give you a good taste of everything, the very tender lamb.  

The not so great: a moderate time before plates are removed once empty (I am kinda picky about that.)  Water glasses not always full, but never empty.

Definitely gives you an experience to remember.  I didn's see the belly dancers but I'd love to go back!
author: crystala t.

description:
Food was PHENOMENAL!

Yelpers did not lie.

You really have to be in the mood for the belly dancer and morrocan experience, but if you are ~ DO IT!

Everything was yum yum yum.

I had the sea bass and was blown away!  My bf had the lamb.  I don't normally like lamb.  WOW!  And our friend had the chicken.  So good!

I wouldn't recommend going the vegetarian route though because they really just take the same dishes and take out the wonderful meats.  Not the same.
author: Liz B.

description: The food is really good but the joint is done up like any American's Moroccan wet dream:  pillows on the floor, drapey stuff on the walls and cielings.  A belly dancer that balances a sword on her belly.  Ehhh.  But the food was good: the bastila rocks.  So did the fish tagine.  I'd go back but I am not a big fan of watching the annoying clientele pretend they are in "Arabia" while they eat.
author: Free P.

description:
Popular for birthday parties. There were five while we were there, including the one we were there for. Seating is on low divans and leather poufs in a Moroccan-style draped room, with big low tables set in front- cozy and casual. Very much a younger Marina/straight crowd.

The belly dancer was great. She's in terrific shape, beautiful, and a pleasure to watch.

The service was enthusiastic and welcoming.

The food is vile. Seriously, food so bad the 2 stars are for the room, the belly dancer and the service, and I like Moroccan food, especially the combination of sweet/sour/salt in so many dishes. The prix-fixe menu is $35, and while I don't want to begrudge anyone their profits, it's a total rip-off in terms of food cost. There's no excuse for serving unidentifiable vegetables in San Francisco. It's possible the kebabs are a better deal, but I ordered the lamb with prunes- an overly sweet concoction overloaded with cinnamon that was half-meat, half-spine. Cartilage included. The bistaya that preceded it was very sweet and made with chicken thigh and neck, which is fine, but I got a piece of neck bone in my first bite. On the plus side, our vegetarian friend got a bistaya made with a carrot/sweet potato filling that was actually outstanding. On the minus side, none of us finished anything we were served.

So go for the show and ambiance... and order the kebabs. The servers are great, and don't begrudge them a decent tip just because the food is poor.
author: Rocco P.

description: We were there with a large group of friends for a birthday party on 1/5/13. We had traveled from San Jose, and it was raining and we thought we must be crazy to make this uneasy drive, and knowing parking would be a hassle (it was). But all that was quickly forgotten when we got inside. What ambiance! What attentive service! What delicious food! It was an excellent choice, and we are all the better for the experience. This restaurant should be on everyone's bucket list!
author: Linda B.

description: I have eaten there several times over the years but this past w/end was definitely my best experience tasting authentic Moroccan cuisines so much that I am making my own home-brew mint tea !!!   Merci beaucoup pour l'organize, Imane!!!
author: Linda L.

description: Are you ready for some fun?  El Mansour is full of great food and great belly dancing.
author: Dave And Teenz Q.

description:
I came here for a birthday dinner with 10 people. Our reservation was at 6:15 and most of us showed up on time (Tip. have an early reservation and get there on time)  While we were waiting for the rest of the party, the staff advised us to order anyways and will take the orders for the rest of the people.

The menu selection is small, but quite interesting.  I chose the Chicken with raisins and onions.  The meal included Moroccan salad, lentil soup, lots of bread, pastry filled with chicken and almond and mint tea at the end.

Perks: Belly Dancing!!!! I wish the people that night were a little more enthusiastic. The only people clapping were my table.  I also liked the idea of eating with our hands.  It makes the whole eating experience a bit more intimate.  The rose oil they gave us after they rinsed our hands after our meal. 

Cons: I wish they would offer us more bread to eat the salad with.  Not cool when crush eggplants get under my nails.  

Overall, great experience.
author: A L.

description: Consistently a nice time, with good food, friendly, warm service, and a pleasant atmosphere.  A little bit of Marrakesh in San Francisco,
author: Josh R.

description: This place is amazing! The food was absolutely delicious! It is very rare to find a restaurant that can achieve culinary perfection with EVERY dish. Some of the best food I have ever had!  This place has it all....excellent food, attentive service, and great entertainment. I will defintely be making this place one of my usually restaurants. I live about 20 minutes from El Mansour....but let me tell you...it is worth the drive. I would recommend this place to anyone who wants to enjoy a delicious night out! :)
author: Catherine M.

description:
Great place for a weeknight bachelor party. It offers dancing flesh, comfortable seating, good wine and food and without skeezy lapdances. 

But, the serving options were a little limited for vegetarians. The ambiance was a little too well-lit. The waiters were good but a little off-kilter. Everything was solid and I'd recommend going here, but the place felt like it was missing soemthing which is why I give it 4 out 5.
author: Scott K.

description: Came here last night for my birthday and had a wonderful time.  The food was amazing I had the Lamb and Chicken entree which came with soup, salad a delicous chicken pastry the entree and a dessert Yum. All for $32.95 the service was great and friendly there was a belly dancer too.  Highly recommend this place for a fun evening.
author: julie c.

description:
This was one of the best dining "experiences" ever, second only the the Napa Valley WIne Train for me.  Like the Wine Train, the food was very good.  We spent a lot of time in France and know our Moroccan food, and this was comparable to some of the best Moroccan places we'd been too.  My kids ate it all.  Also, we are a Tunsian/American family so we would normally be quick to critique what is not "real".  It was all good though.  

The experience was a lot of fun.  The decor, the wonderful dancer, the other people in the restaurant.  It was like a huge party.  I laughed until I ached when the dancer teased hip swirls out of some of the patrons.  She was really sweet with my kids too.  It kind of reminded me of the old "Pasha" restaurant, but it felt more "real" and cozy.  

We ate very well, and the price was pretty reasonable.  All courses for like $30 each person.

They did a really nice job with some of the birthdays.  

A fun place with good food, we will be back!
author: Christine B.

description:
Read the yelp reviews and thought we'd give it a try.  We were craving Moroccan food and picked this restaurant based on reviews.  We were NOT dissapointed!  Food was great!  In fact we ate too much of it!  We ordered the Lamb with almonds, good, but the real star was the Rabbit!  Divine!

The atmosphere is as I expected, a fun Moroccan tent-feel, where you eat with your hands and sit on couches and pillow seats.  

Had a blast with the belly dancer too!  So fun!  The staff was wonderful as well.  We will definitely be back and this time with friends!
author: Debbie M.

description:
Eating with your hands while sitting on plush cushions?  Sounds like my kinda place!  They have everything you could want here--fabulous couscous, a chicken with cinnamon and sugar appetizer disk (comes with all meals) that is to die for, and great lamb (that's saying something, considering i dont like lamb).  The seafood dish was really good too.

The atmosphere is great.  After having been to Morocco, I doubted I would find somewhere i felt was REALLY authentic in the city.  Great to be proven wrong!    I loved the belly dancer too...nice touch.  Although the old men trying to dance with her was slightly disturbing, and  hilarious.

The staff was very friendly and explained all the dishes...as well as taught us a bit about traditional Moroccan culture.  Service was a little slow at times, but I think it was appropriate for the meal and atmosphere.

Im dinging one star because it is a bit expensive, but Ill certainly go back!
author: Kelly S.

description: I've been to El Mansour before with my family and decided to take my boyfriend for his birthday on August 28, 2010.  He'd never had Moroccan food and was blown out of the water at the wonderful food and amazing dining experience.  The owners, waiters and belly dancer, truly transport you to a foreign land.  They make the entire dining experience relaxing, fun and wonderfully delicious.  The set prices and 5 course meal make an exotic dining experience very affordable.  I love this place and would recommend you try it for sure!!
author: Christine Z.

description:
I came here a few years ago with my high school's French club; I think we were all a bit apprehensive at first because, coming from the Central Valley, few of us had experienced a restaurant much more exotic than Elephant Bar.  Boy were we surprised!  Between washing our hands in the luxurious warm rose water and sharing the delicious bastela du chef, all 15 of us quickly fell in love with Moroccan food.  After this wonderful experience, I even found a Middle Eastern cook book and learned how to make my favorite dish--the bastela.

It has been about five years since that first trip to El Mansour.  This weekend, for Valentine's Day, I am taking my fiancé to the Moroccan restaurant.  We are both so excited!
author: Annie A.

description:
to my surprise i throughly enjoyed my visit last night.

wheni heard el monsour, i was like ooooo belly dancer. great.  woohoo. dolla dolla bills yo. 

whoa, the foods actually pretty decent. 

the staff was very good to us, the food, well it was unorganized for a bit, entrees were missing, coming out late.... but looking at the big picture, if you can keep several large groups entertained and feed and happy throughout the night, you did you job as a restaurant. 

the funny staff, the good food, the belly dancer that seemed to float on water.... all in all a great time.

oh yeah, and good company seems to help a bit too. 

happy birthday seong.
author: Euge L.

description:
Ok, first off, the food was really really good. If you've read my other reviews you know I'm not too picky about food. Also, it was pricey, but fortunately we were treated.
Now, this place really sells you on an experience. You sit on pillows, eat with your hands, there's a live belly dancer who will invite you to dance with her so you can post the pictures on Facebook, they pour the tea from really high up, all of which makes me the opposite of happy. The servers and owners are super nice, but you can kind of get the feeling they're saying, so you think this is what it's like in Morocco, hm? 
It seems like the kind of place Andy Sandberg would take Joanna Newsom out on a date thinking she's going to be all into the cultural fluff they have, and really she's politely appalled by the corniness of it. Man, it irritates me so much that she dates him. I mean if you're a young and unusually skilled and attractive musician making your way up, you'd think you'd choose someone who has some sort of talent in whatever he does. What about Galifinakis? Zooey Deschanel married Ben Gibbard. But I guess he did get in better shape.
author: Sterling C.

description: I was there on a night that belly dancing didn't happen, and it still was a pleasant dining experience, with excellent food and ambience. You sit clustered around tables against the wall so that there's room for the dancer(s) since this is supposed to a performance dinner. Would make an awesome quirky date place with unsual but tasty food! One warning, I noticed some other tables with more people given the same portions of the courses to split, so do not be shy to ask for more since the meal is designed around two people and would be thin split four ways.
author: John G.

description:
Esa Y....I thought this place was familiar!!!! After 11 years, I forgot I had been here! That was an awesome birthday party, by the way!
I revisited El Mansour this past weekend for a friend's 28th birthday and had a wonderful time. I love eating with my hands...and, consequently, enjoy a nice hand-washing. The servers were awesome - attentive to our insatiable need for Moroccan beer, kind enough to chill the birthday girl's bottle of bubbly, and able to put up with the party's lively shenanigans. We are big on shenanigans. 
While the belly dancer was entertaining, I think that our group could just as easily gone without. 
The food was amazing.
We pretty much ate like Kings.
With the exception of having to watch the couple across the room basically dry-hump on on of the couches (when the woman managed to detach herself from the clinging paws of her date to use the restroom, he promptly enticed the belly dancer his way by waiving a few bucks...in the middle of some hip-jutting freakiness, enter girlfriend...who then joined in the hip-thrusting!!! Did her date have a great night? I am willing to bet $500 he did!) it was thoroughly enjoyable and I can't wait for the next birthday bash there!
Oh, ladies...this is not the best place to wear low-rise jeans....tie the sweater around your waist or beware the whale tail!
author: Jessa B.

description:
You have to go here if you like to be entertained while you eat! The food was great. I really enjoyed the Harira soup (lentil soup) and the bastela du chef...oh my...so delicious! I chose chicken with almonds as my entree and it was also good. The idea is your supposed to eat with your hands. For me, this was a bit tricky because whenever I get something delicious on my fingers, I forget my manners and I'm tempted to lick it off. (haha) However, you are sharing some of the appetizers with your friends (without silverware) and you don't want to gross them out by licking your fingers and then taking another share of the appetizers. If you can't stand getting your fingers sticky, silverware is optional! But, I believe the idea is to eat with your hands and use the bread in place of silverware. They do come around with a silver watering vase to sprinkle on your hands and a warm fresh towel to dry them with. 

I loved the mint tea. You have to catch the fragrance as the waiter pours it. Delightful! The flavor will make you say YUM!

The belly dancing that evening was wonderful. My friends got up to dance and she gave them a belly dancing lesson.
author: Liz K.

description: Excellent place.  Having recently returned from Morocco, I was interested in tasting more of their great traditional dishes.  And El Mansour does not disappoint.  With very good traditionally inspired Moroccan cooking, well done Islamic/Berber tent-inspired decor, excellent, friendly service, and talented Belly Dancing, an El Mansour dining experience is a feast for all the senses.  I look forward to returning ... next time bringing several friends along.
author: Chris A.

description: The service was good, belly dancing was good, eating with your hand  was fun, nice ambience.  Had the chicken with honey and prune and it was good, especially if you are a fan of honey.  The fish tajine can be messy and nothing really special about the flavor.  It's a different dining experience and is worth coming at least once just to try it out.
author: Heidi F.

description:
I have an unforgetable nite at El Mansour.  Its so entertaining.  
I love the atmosphere, environment, decoration, performance and food.
They are all very impressed.
author: Joyce J.

description: It's a great place to go for something different and relaxing with comfortable seating on cushioned bench or stools.  I tried El Mansour for the first time last week and I enjoyed the ambiance and the exotic food.  It's something out of the typical dining experience.  Food was prepared competently, nothing truly outstanding but nothing to complaint of either. We enjoyed the atmosphere and allowed us to conduct a quiet conversation until the belly dancer showed up.   The belly dancer was entertaining, but the audiences were as well as some of them were asked to belly dance along side.  Overall, I say if you are looking for doing something different, El Mansour is a good choice.
author: Robert H.

description: The chicken was so tender that it melted off the fork. The service was great and the belly dancer was amazing. She did this trick of dancing while having a lit candelabra on top of her head. Go figure?! Anyway, in the end they washed our hands with rose water. Very cool.
author: Samira S.

description: Fabulous food, great service.  Love the atmosphere and the polite staff.  Good entertaining belly dancer.
author: Tara S.

description:
Yelpers, this is the first time I am going to strongly disagree with you. Just recovered from eating at El Mansour. What started out as a promising night (appetizers and soup were great), came to a scheeching halt with my fish course. The sea bass tasted and smelled so strong of iodine that I was sick for the rest of the night. Still wondering about the white fluffy bread served with with every course, it was such a disappointment (would have loved traditionnel flat bread). And the "thè a la menthe" tasted like burnt tea leaves. 

Hubbie has spent some time in Morocco and said, "Most moroccan restaurants use forks and knives" so he thought the eating-with-your-hands thing a bit cheesy. He said the lamb was good. Told me afterwards (too late), "moroccan's aren't too strong on cooking fish" Belly dancer was beautiful, though, and it was charming when a little girl went up to dance with her. Laughing help me to forget the iodine overwhelming my senses.

Staff was super nice and maybe I just got the one random off meal but once is enough. Will definitely not be going back.
author: Cecilia V.

description:
Let me start by saying I have never seen my parents so excited to shove money into a woman's bra. Way to ring in fifteen years of marriage, Mom!
I went here with my parents and relatives to celebrate their anniversary. Our server was very laid-back and personable. We asked him for his recommendations for dinner and drinks, and all of his suggestions worked out perfectly. Our entree consisted of small portions of several items so I won't bother listing them, but everything was scrumptious. The belly dancer was...fun. If I could I would give 3.5 stars, since the bread they gave us seemed a little stale, and they didn't give us the standard-issue flat bread which is easier to eat with. Picking up couscous with just our fingers was trying, to say the least.
Overall, it was a lot of fun. I'll go back someday, if only to hear that server's seductive accent again.
author: Alani F.

description: Awesome food and service! Dining is an experience complete with waiters pouring rose infused water on your hands before dining. You gotta try the bastela du chef. Excellent overall. Great for b-days. Oh and I can't forget the belly dancer. She's mostly there on Fridays and I must say, she's very entertaining...
author: joan l.

description:
I haven't been back to El Mansour in the past two years, but the impression it has left on me still sticks. I have fabulous memories from dining here. I always make sure to make a reservation ahead of time because on the weekends it can be booked and they might not be able to accomodate you without a resevation. 

Walking through the entrance door leads you into an entirely different world. It's a definite escape from reality. I haven't had a problem finding convenient street parking yet.

I love the belly dancer they have perform. She is always very interactive with the crowd.

If you enjoy a dining experience, this is a place to put on your list. The meat falls right of the bone and is absolutely delicious. You experience the whole hand washing ceremony, tea ceremony, and eating without forks...that is, unless you request it. ;) It's a great place for a romantic date or for an intimate birthday celebration with friends.
author: nightlife i.

description:
good atmosphere.  good food.

love the bastilla!  it's chicken, almonds, and spices wrapped in phylo dough, baked (?), and dusted with spices and powdered sugar.  yum :)  that's like perfect breakfast food!
author: Sally T.

description:
this is a great place for a bday party.  it's evident, b/c it seemed like every table in the restaurant was celebrating a bday!!  we came here to celebrate seong's bday last night, and we had a large party.  the decor of the place is really nice w/ lots of tapestry and embellished pillows and seats.  the tables are low, so don't make the mistake of wearing a short dress like i did.

the servers start you off by pouring water on you rhands so you can clean them.  be advised that you eat w/ your hands here!!  at least they give you bread to scoop up the food!  you start off w/ the lentil soup, which very good.  then there are shared apps of various salads and a sugary pastry filled w/ minced chicken and other stuff wrapped in phyllo.  for entrees, you each have your own, and i had the fish tagine, which was yummy.  to finish, we had banana fritters and some more phyllo dough w/ sugar and then mint tea.  

this place is a lot of fun and loud and rowdy!  when the belly dancer comes out, the place really heats up.  i would definitely come back for another party!
author: Helen T.

description:
The dining room is colorful and decorated with traditional Moroccan design. A skillful and elegant belly dancer performs occasionally. She will invite you to dance with her. Ladies and gentlemen, don't be shy like us. Dance with her! You will need a workout after the food anyway. And quit giving an excuse of not suppose to exercise right after a meal! Get lots of dollar bills when you go there. You will need it ;-). Delicious food, especially the pastry filled with grounded chicken and almond is FANTASTIC! Two thumbs up. Just the mint tea alone will get me to come back again. Oh, they do have utensils only if you ask for them. But, people, blend in and experience the culture by eating with your fingers.

Last but not least, A + + to the owner for her friendliness and generosity.
author: William B.

description:
Rabbit was chewy and medium rare. (Stinking Rose's roasted rabbit was better.) The lamb tangine and kebab were both tender and fab and well seasoned. The mint tea was the shiz. I knocked that sucker back like it was Patron. The bread was dense and super yum, but you should know better than to fill up on bread before the meal. Belly dancer was cute and entertaining. It's awesome when she brings up your rhythmically challenged friend to dance with her. I busted a rib from laughin ... So bring your camera phone so you can blackmail his ass.

Don't do the Moroccan wine -- medium bodied but flat. Do a local full bodied wine -- St. George's Cabernet was a good pairing. Plus you get more bang for the buck. But if you're a veggie, do a white or rose since most of your meal will be couscous and veggies. 

Now some folks don't know how to eat with their hands (or prefer not to). But if you're Filipino, Indian, Ethiopian, Eritrian or can't afford Ikea utensils for home, eating with hands is second nature. The restaurant does offer utensils for the uncoordinated. But y'know ... when in Rome ...  So eat with your hands. It's part of the experience.

The place got cushioney stools and cushioney benches and cushioney cushions. Since it's interactive but loungey, it's awesome for big parties. I don't recommend bringing a date here because when the belly dancer comes out, music's loud and guests can get loud. Plus your man friend might get hypnotized by her Shakira shakin and ignore you.

You'll get full. You'll get tired. You'll be relaxed. Don't go out afterward. You'll wanna sleep. Don't expect a hookah. Definitely worth the price.
author: Nelson T.

description:
I have never heard so many birthday songs in one evening...  it was funny!
Unfortunately, we had to wait 35 minutes before we could be seated.
A few of us did not feel like eating a whole meal, however we were told that everyone had to order the $30 meal, no option for smaller portion... This was disappointing. 

Did I mention we had to wait an hour long to get our main course.

We loved the music, the dancer, and the food when it came ... but I am not sure we would come back, it was pricey and the service was not up to expectation.
author: peggy D.

description: We had such a great time here. The food was excellent. The laamb was juicy and even easy to eat with your hands. The restaurant did a really great job of transforming the inside and outside into a very comfortable and outgoing scene. It's a fun night out for a date or in a group.
author: Aly L.

description:
El Mansour is such a fun, unique dining experience and the service is so pleasant and efficient that it just adds to the whole experience.  I always feel like I enter into the world of a sultan as soon as I walk through the opulent front door and met w/ the colorful decor. It's the kind of place for either large parties or a cozy romantic dinner for two b/c the seating lets you get really close to your honey but wear comfy clothes b/c you'll be either leaning over the table if sitting on the low banquettes or sinking into a really low cushion on the floor.  

I love the food, starting with the flavorful lentil soup followed by the egglant & tomato salads which are all served with some of the best all-you-can-eat bread that the server brings around in a large wicker basket for you to take from.  Then comes the bastilla which is a phyllo pastry filled w/ minced chicken and almonds dusted w/ powdered sugar -- so good I always want it all to myself.  The main courses are super tasty -- their chicken is a whole game hen which is so tender you barely have to tug at the bones and it comes apart.  I haven't had any of the brochettes but they look amazing -- as long as swords.  And finally for dessert you get a phyllo drizzled w/ cream along with fried bananas and a delicious mildly sweetened mint tea.  Your napkin at El Mansour is a large hand towel which you totally need when eating with your hands.  You can ask for utensils but part of the fun of moroccan food is eating sans knife & fork.

There's only one thing about this whole thing that I'm not a huge fan of, and I'm sure I'm the exception here -- the belly dancing.  I just don't like having to play along w/ the whole cheesy thing (again, only MHO).  And I always feel trapped into staying when I'm actually ready to leave if the dancing's in full swing b/c it seems so rude.  One way to get around it is to confirm what time the show starts (usually 7:30pm) and time your res. around it.

Return Visit = Definitely
author: Jeannie C.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants.  The ambiance is wonderful.  They serve a 5 course dinner with the best Chicken Bastilla that I have ever had.  The dinner ends with Morroccan Mint tea poured elegantly.  My favorite dish is the rabbit kabob.
author: Kathryn F.

description:
cool restaurant in the outer richmond.  they are probably a bit more authentic than aziza a few blocks away.  i actually like it here more than aziza.  not sure why though since they are both really good restaurants.

some things i like - sitting on the cushons/floor,  eating with your hands (if you want to), price fixed menu.
author: Patrick L.

description: My favorite Morroccan Restaurant in the Bay area.  The food is good, eaten on the floor and with the fingers.  The belly dancers are fun, and provide great entertainment for visitors to Bagdad on the Bay.
author: Jim D.

description:
so, someone said this place is just "okay" for moroccan food.  since i have nothing to compare it to, that leaves me forced to assume all other moroccan places - wherever they may be - must be off the hook, cos this place has impressed me and my friends three times and counting.

i hear the restaurant itself has been redecorated (renovated?) in the last few years, and i don''t know what it looked like before, but it is rich and gorgeous now.  everything feels lush.  the tiles, the carved wood, low seating and tables with lots of pillows are all awesome.

i'm not on fire about bellydancing, but this place has a more-than-decent  dancer, who always seems to distract all my friends.

for me, the food is great.  everything seems expertly spiced and seasoned - not over- or underwhelming.  i'd be curious to know what other moroccan places do better in sf, cos i will surely check them out.  the meats are all impressively cooked: way tender and falling off the bone, full of flavor.  the salads are nice and sublte, yet memorably tasty.  bread is fresh and served warm every time.  dessert and mint tea at the end is always a crowd-pleaser, too.

i honestly have to wonder where else the reviewers who don't like this place are dining to be so apathetic about it.  i have yet to be equally impressed with another middle eastern place in sf, let alone another moroccan restaurant.  until i find those, this one gets all my gold stars.
author: Eleanore T.

description: The great service, cozy interior, excellent food and belly dancing makes this place a reasonably priced cultural experience.  I went on a Tuesday night with a group of friends for a birthday.  If you like lamb and tender, moist thighs (chicken that is), this is the place for you.
author: ellyk E.

description: A very cool experience.  As soon as we walked in we noticed the comfortable couches everywhere that made for a very relaxed atmosphere.  What I didn't expect was the exotic belly dancer that started dancing as soon as we sat down.  She was pretty good.  I ordered a moroccan beer which was very good and then an entree to lamb stew and kabob.  The entree we ordered also came with a lentil soup (which was excellent) and a salad.  I had to get used to eating without utencils which made for an interesting experience.  Overall the food was very good.  The wait staff is very nice and courteous, the atmosphere is relaxed and fun and most importantly, the food is very good.  I will definitely be coming back here.
author: V C.

description: One of my all-time favorites! The ambiance is fantastic. Dinner + wine + tip is probably $40 - $50 per person, for a fixed menu of about a zillion courses. Served traditional moroccan style -- you eat with your fingers.
author: Ellen B.

description:
the moroccan food is genuine and authentic, though i would have preferred access to modern-day utensils and napkins [tearing apart a rabbit with your hands isn't easy], as well as more bread [which they take away after a few minutes, for some odd reason]

the location itself is spacious and undoubtedly moroccan, but sitting on the floor isn't something i like to do
author: Charles C.

description: El Mansour is my favorite restaurant in SF.  The last time I went here was with my family for my sister's birthday.  The inside of the restauant has a very beautiful Moroccan feel to it.  The seating is very comfortable and the ceiling is eye catching with colorful fabrics drapped on the wall.   The waitors were very friendly and talked to us a bit.  I ordered  a sugar pasty fill with meat called bastilla for my appetizer and it was delicious!   Then I had the almond and honey duck which was tender and sweet.  The belly dancer came out around 9ish and she was hot!  She wore this glittery colorful outfit and danced around the room for a while.  Then she had everyone come up in groups to dance with her- which was highly entertaining to watch.  She even talked to my sister and gave her braceletes for her birthday.  This place is perfect for amazing food and an amusing evening.
author: Sara L.

description: Great experience!  Friendly staff, great ambiance, awesome food!
author: Carrie G.

description: Took my daughter and her group of friends for her 20th bday! great place to celebrate a bday....any age! plan on using your hands to eat! the food was delicious and it's a feast. Service is very slow, but it's quality. Plan to be there long, but they are on top of their game. Great Experience.
author: Lisa R.

description: I'm still looking for the ultimate middle eastern experience in the city and I was hopeful about this place. Alas, El Mansour proved to be good, but just good and no more. The appetizers hold far more promise than the mains, and the location demands a pilgrimage that doesn't bear repeating.
author: Stellah D.

description:
I went here recently for a friend's birthday party. I had a good time - they've got their routine down as far as making it a fun experience for large groups and I'm glad I got to try it once but it's really expensive (though you do get a ton of food). Based on the food alone I wouldn't really come back. 

They have a set menu for $30-32 which includes lots of stuff: bread, soup, salad, basteeya (delicious chicken filo dough pastry), entree (lots of different options), dessert (banana fritters and keneffa) and mint tea. We shared two entrees: couscous with 2 kinds of lamb (stew and brochettes), and chicken with onions and raisins. My favorite parts of the meal were the salad and the basteeya (if I could come here and just order those two things for around $10 I would be much more likely to come back). The entrees were pretty good (the brochettes had great flavor / spice, though they were overcooked) but it was very difficult to eat the rest of the entree food without silverware (I know it's supposed to be all authentic and romantic to eat with yours hands but it doesn't really do anything for me, except maybe get couscous down my shirt - don't ask...). Dessert was good too (the banana fritters were great - the keneffa strangely had almost no filling unlike versions i've had at other middle eastern restaurants which were much better than El Mansour's version).

The decor is beautiful, especially if you enjoy Moroccan tilework (which I love)... but you don't need to eat here to see it since the nicest parts are on the outside walls of the restaurant. The belly dancing was fun to watch (especially when the birthday boy was encouraged to get up and shake his booty).

In summary: if you want a memorable party for a large group and don't mind it being kind of spendy this is a decent choice. If you're looking for straight up delicious upscale Moroccan food without all the hoopla go to Aziza instead.
author: Lila T.

description:
I found this place on YELP! I love YELP! Ok...(get it together) I loved the decor on this place. I really enjoyed the audience participation and the girl was hot! Who knew!!! I really wasn't expecting her to be as HOT as she was. My finance really enjoyed it! =) He even got to go up there and get his hips swung by her. LOL HOT! The food was great! If you are a eater and can eat a lot this is great place for food. THE FOOD JUST KEEPS COMING...its a whole Entree. Comes with Soup, Salad, Appetizer, dinner, desert and to end your meal HOT TEA! My fiance ordered the Lamb! WOW...it melted in my mouth. I ordered the chicken with vegetables. I mean the food was really amazing. You can eat with your hands or ask for a fork.  The staff was friendly. I really had a great time! 
I took a star away because it was difficult to get a cab. We walked 5 blocks to be able to get a cab. Other than that! GREAT TIME!
author: Irma E.

description:
my girl says to me "girl this place looks like a brothel from the outstide."
when i got inside i told her "girl this place reminds me of a circus with the tent decor and all" haha ... i love the ambiance of this place. ooh especially the bellydancing. as i watched the bellydancer i was convinced that i too wanted to be a bellydancer. pssha yeah right. well i just want to learn the art of bellydancing. 3 stars because the main dish (lamb) was a little bland but other than that it was an awesome experience although the bellydancer reminded me of the ice lady in the movie chronicles of narnia
author: bella h.

description:
i recently had a birthday gathering at el mansour and was extremely concerned with my friends' (who schlepped from as far as union city) satisfaction with the food and, more importantly, the entertainment.  The food was yummy - not too exotic for the typical palatte, but not too mundane for those who are more adventurous with their food tastes.  The rabbit was my favorite, followed closely by the lamb with lemon and olives. The decor was kitschy,  the staff was very accomodating, and luckily for me, the entertainment was worth the schlepp from the outer regions of the bay area that all of my friends made to get there. The belly dancer was a great performer.  She made it interactive by having almost all of us come up and attempt "working it" like she did.  hilarious for all involved.
But to top it off, because we're not so swift with math, our group ended up paying an extra hundred bucks.  The head waiter found us at the bar next door (also recommended by the way), and gave us our cash back.  Can you friggin believe that?  I still can't.  
If you are looking to get together with friends with some decent food, fun entertainment, in a comfortable atmosphere and in an HONEST establishment, hit up el mansour.  you will not be disappointed!
author: annie c.

description:
The food is good, but I didn't think it was quite as cool inside as the Moroccan places I'd been to down in San Jose (esp Morocco's!!), and the food wasn't quite as tasty either, and it is a bit pricey for what you get.  The belly dancer was good though, and the service was very good.  

I had the seafood plate, my date had couscous with lamb, hers was better I think, I probably should've gone with lamb or chicken tagine!
author: bill r.

description:
I heart El Monsour...

  This was one of the first local restaurants I tried back in the day when I was new to SF. Back then there wasn't as much seating. When you walked through the door you were instantly thrust into the view of the diners and sometimes directly into the way of the belly dancer! It was crazy but always fun to instantly be apart of the communal vibe. Now after a remodel, there is much more seating and a bit of an entryway into the restaurant. 
  My most recent visit was for a birthday bash with 15 or so people. We had the front, right corner to ourselves and let me tell you... It was awesome. We were able to transform the area into our own space. We were lounging, mingling, eating, and being lively. The wait staff didn't miss a beat and they were even able to keep track of the people who moved spots before the food was served. We opened many bottles of wine without corkage I believe. What I liked most about this venue for a party was that the home-y atmosphere puts everyone at ease. You get the intimacy of a party at home with an international vibe and no dishes! 
  I've always liked the food here as well. It's cooked like your Moroccan mom made it. It's hearty, flavorful, and cooked well, but not perfectly. If you want fanciness, go to Aziza. If you want a completely unique experience that transports you out of SF and into a fun and exciting realm, visit El Monsour.
author: chelsea b.

description: this place is awesome. my friend took me here for dinner, it was my first belly dancing experience. it was pretty sexy, I have to admit. this place is a totally different experience. this restaurant is one big room with tables and stump seats all along the wall. the seating was some what comfortable because it was like sitting on a couch, but umcomfortable because people have to hunch over to eat since the tables are low. the décor here is beautiful, it was almost like being in someones home. oh the food, the food was great. reminded me a little like mediterranean food without all the hummus. the staff comes around before to wash your hands. our meal included a salad, some type of sweet meat pie, the entree and dessert tea, it was a great meal. the belly dancer came out and people went a little crazy. she was great, she got people to dance with her, and she accumulated a good amount of dollar bills. great experience, highly recommended.
author: Serena L.

description: our first night in san fran we had dinner here...we didn't know it wasn't in the city...we got dropped off in front of a blue door! when we walked in i was impressed with the decor! i loved all the colors! my hubby didn't like sitting on pillows, but it was fun! the prix fixed menu was great, good amount of food for the buck! the staff was great! ahhh...it was like we were transported somewhere else...very romantic!
author: Rita L.

description: This is a fun place to have a group dinner. The seating style is very relaxing, you sit on cushions near the ground level, kinda like being in someone's home on their living room carpet near the sofa. The decor gave the impression of being in a tent. The food itself is good, but my fond memories are those of the belly dancer...
author: vinh t.

description: This place is a blast.  Maybe not the best food, but the experience is awesome.  I came here with my girlfriend and parents.  We all ordered different dishes and picked off of each others plates.  The rabbit was the best.  The belly dancing was fun, all in all a great dinner with great entertainment.
author: B. K.

description: Atmosphere is like Arabian nights and the sofas create a really comfortable atmosphere. Food is really good and cleaning your hands is pretty elaborate. The belly dancers make give a fun and entertaining show pulling guests to the floor to dance with them.
author: Lily K.

description: I came here years ago for a birthday party.  This place is a lot fun to go with a group.  I was starving by the time we were seated...around 9:00 (no reservations).  I kept eating the delicious warm bread they brought around in baskets, drinking the moroccan beer, and enjoying the belly dance show.  You sit on the floor on cushions and the inside of the restaurant looks like a tent!  It's pretty cool.  I like how they bring the lemon to wash your hands (I'm neurotic about hand-washing). The food came out around 10:00-10:30 but by this time I was no longer hungry.  I ordered the couscous with veggies.  I wasn't impressed with the food and I didn't realize they don't use utensils with moroccan food. Don't do what I did and fill up on bread as you are supposed to use it as a "utensil."  I give El Monsour 3 stars for the ambience and the overall experience.
author: anne m.

description:
Fun times out in the Outer Richmond!
I'm always a sucker for food with built-in entertainment and this place did not disappoint. Its definitely a no frills space with a simple design to set the mood for a taste of Morocco. The lady who run's the place is great and very attentive. Apparently its been a family business for years and you definitely get that vibe. 

The food. was great. And there's a lot of it. It's pricey though which took me by surprise (almost $30 an entree) but the whole meal involved several dishes after you choose your main dish. The choices range from seafood, chicken, lamb and rabbit. After first ordering the chicken (and then getting berated by both my brother and the Owner about how chicken is so boring and that I really should try something original) I opted for the seafood dish. Pre-main dish, they served a great starter salad and a sort of pancake dish with chicken and powdered sugar (weird but good. dessert or appetizer... still deciding). The seafood and couscous were awesome. It wasn't very much though so order a meat dish for more bang to your buck. The lamb was ridiculous. The rabbit, surprisingly good too. (man, I love eating other people's food). The Moroccan beer was also a great compliment to the meal. To top it all off, there was the predictably interactive belly dancing show which I obviously participated in. After a meal like that, my belly was definitely up for some action. 

Overall? This place was fun and the food was great. All said and done, for over $40 a pop, I'd rank this more a special occasion kind of place. I'd also say the bigger the group, the more fun this place can be. It's fun and festive and the food can put everyone into a coma.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
This is my favourite restaurant in the city hands down. 
The ambiance along with the food and the waiters costumes makes it one of the thousand and one nights :) 
My husband and I go there every once in a while for our celebrations.The food comes in few courses.....It's usually more than filling to me so I always end up packing half of my entree. 
If you love lamb like my husband then,this is your place....if you like the Arabian nights feel this is also your place. 
It is an experience that I think locals and tourists should have :)
author: yarah b.

description: You'll feel like you are dining in someone's living room.  Comfortable seating, bellydancing and tasty tidbits served family style.  It's a great experience.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
came in a few years ago for a girlfriend's birthday dinner... i think it was on a weekday so there were hardly any people which was ok with me since we got more attentive service... it's all family style share food... we had the several course dinner and it was all very flavorful and enjoyable... even though there were only a couple other diners, they still had a belly dancer perform which was a nice touch to the experience...
the decor is as if you're in a moroccan tent with plush cushions and fabric in rich colors everywhere...
author: charlotte s.

description: Good food, good service, great deco, and belly dancing. What more can you ask for :-)
author: Mayank R.

description: Wow. I have been to many moroccan restaurants in the city and this is by far the best! Although the entertainment is not as good as Pasha or Amira, the food is so much better. Honey almond lamb and chicken with lemon is the best. And the bastela du chef- yum yum - the best thing you will ever eat. The service is really good too and I usually spend about 2 hours eating here - no rushing you out the door.
author: Katherine B.

description:
For me, this place was just okay, though my friends enjoyed it very much. We went with a large group and ordered family style. First came a lentil soup - that was the best thing of the night. Creamy, earthy, hearty, served with bread. Next came a chicken filo dough appetizer with powdered sugar and cinnamon sprinkled on top. Thought it was a weird combination, but it wasn't bad at all. Then came an assortment platter with salsa (that's the best I can describe it), pickled cucumbers and carrots, and a spread of some sort. I don't remember what kind of spread but it was good. This came with the same bread served with the soup. It was french bread. I think the main entree came next which was a plate full of meat, served with bread. It had an assortment of chicken, rabbit, lamb, shrimp/scallop. The best thing on the platter was the lamb kebabs but they only gave us three pieces when there were six of us sharing a plate. Other stuff was alright. I don't know if I missed anything because I can't remember. Dessert was a friend banana - very small piece, one bite worth. It was alright. The tea was superb! I thought I wouldn't like it because it had a lot of mint in it but it was good. Really good. Don't leave without it. Overall, I was expecting so much more - more flavor, more excitement, just more, but my experience was just mediocre. It seemed very generic.

Service was good. The staff was nice. Belly dancer was fun, but it wasn't mesmerizing like I've read in the review. I liked the decor and lighting of the place. Very chill. They pour water over your hands before and after you eat - at the last wash they sprinkle some rose essence on your hands. Smells good.
author: Carmen L.

description: My experience at this place was so-so. I was bummed, I had really been looking forward to coming here and my birthday was the perfect excuse. Unfortunately, the experience wasn't quite what I hoped for. The service was slow, we literally had to glare the waiter down to get his attention. Honestly, i was a little creeped out by the belly dancing show. The dancing itself was fine, but people sticking dollar bills into her costume make it seem more like a strip club then a cultural experience. The food was good, but it was priced at "great"- which it was not.
author: Megan C.

description: It was really fun dining experience. How many times do you get to sit around like sultans and eat fine food with your bare hands? :-) Per my wife who has been to Morocco, food was very authentic and fancy. Very delicious. Belly dancing was bit weird at first, but was fun when everyone got into it. I'd love to go back with a bigger group.
author: Min L.

description: How can I not remember to write a review for this place.  I had an absolutely great time here.  We came here for my girlfriend's birthday. The food was good.  Omg...I loved the bread....it was so good dipped in the lentil soup.  I got a chicken dish it was also very yummy.  I can't wait to come back.
author: Allison T.

description:
Hands down, best place to have a birthday party, or just a nice evening out.

I was here just the other night with a group of girls for a pre-bachlorette party DINNER. I truely had a great time!! From the outside, the door is not so huge, you can easily miss the place! Once you walk in, you truely feel like you're in Morroco. It is so beautifully decorated from the ceiling to the walls to the floors to the chairs.. even to the tables. I would type our night out, moment to moment, but I wouldn't want to ruin the fun for you. Definitely visit this place for dinner. Go on an empty stomach.. YOU WILL BE STUFFFEDDD AFTER! Forget 5 stars.... 6 stars sounds better =]
author: C M.

description:
We had our first experience at El Mansour for my cousin's Birthday and I was highly impressed. We weren't sure what to expect but we were greeted by a small room that accommodated what seemed to be every group celebrating a Birthday in SF. 
We felt as though we were Barbara Eden in her Jeannie bottle. The room was decorated with bright elaborate pillows and flowing drapes that made you feel like you had stepped into Morocco. 
The food was very flavorful and just the right amount. Each course brought new flavors that combined spices like cinnamon and sugar with chicken and cilantro. 
We recommend going in a group and not making it a date night spot. The price was very reasonable, the food was excellent and the entertainment was wonderful. We would most definitely go back to celebrate another Birthday!
author: Melissa P.

description:
HAHAHHA--the belly dancer is awesome.  Not sure if they rotate people, but the woman who danced on the night we dined was so friendly and entertaining.  I was a little concerned with the guests who brought their daughters dressed like belly dancers and tried to make them dance...but still fun nonetheless.  This is a great place to go to if you're with a group of friends or on a date since you'll stay to eat for at least 1 1/2 hours.  The food takes a bit longer than you'd like to come out, but when it does it's worth the wait..plus you're relaxing on these cushion couches and munching on bread.  You can also order wine (we had the Moroccan special wine which was pretty cheap for the bottle and had a good taste to it too) while you wait.

You can read from the rest of the reviews that you eat with your fingers and share plates with your table--I think this is a great and fun new way to eat dinner and the experience, food, and wine were all worth the $40 we each ended up paying.  Great if you're celebrating an occasion.
author: Trisha H.

description: This place is so much fun with a group of your fabulous friends (lame, boring, tightwads need not apply).  The place is SO cute and a fantastic place to celebrate birthdays.  I had the Moroccan seafood special and it was DELICIOUS.  More couscous wound up in my lap then in my mouth, but it was so worth it.  The prawns & scallops were moist and juicy...so succulent!  They bring out course after course (included in your meal price): my faves were the harira soup (lentil) and the eggplant/carrot salad.  The mint tea served at the end (served R. Kelly style by pouring it from the sky!) is a great way to end the meal.  WARNING: It's a little awkward to watch a gyrating belly while licking your fingers, but I guess that's the fun in it!
author: Courtney B.

description: AWESOME! This place is authentic and delicious. Great decor and good service. Fun belly dancing. The Moroccan Seafood is my favorite! The lentil soup is outstanding as is the phylo dough pie. Mmmm. Come hungry!!!
author: Anita K.

description:
I must admit, I haven't been since the remodel but I can say that is place is truly a SF gem for Moraccan food.  I have been to Aziza up the street they are close but in a fight, I would have to choose EL Mansour.  I have been dining at this place for well over twenty years.  I like the atmosphere of the old place so I hope it has kept some of the intimate charm.  Now the food

The food here has been spot on for years and judging by the recent reviews nothing has changed.  I am looking forward to trying the Tagines, they look really good.  My favorites on the Couscous dishes, either seafood or chicken. I also like to Phyllo dish, that is savory and great.  The simple desserts are great too like deep fried banannas with just a drizzle of honey.
This is a great place for groups as well, very informal and inviting.  This is restaurant is one of San Fran's places that remains high on the list of must dine restaurants.
author: Kelvin M.

description: If you want to dine at Love Boat meets strip club, have at it. We went to Valentine's Day dinner here last night. Waited almost an hour to be seated despite having reservations. Food was eh. Brought me the wrong order, didn't serve my partner his beer until well after he asked for it. Not really feeling the weird white belly dancer. Superb disappointment.
author: Anisha D.

description: My husband and I have been coming here for years.  My entire family (30 total) came here for a graduation celebration dinner last night, and everyone had a fabulous time. Most of my relatives had not tried Moroccan food before, and everyone loved it.  The manager and his staff didn't make us feel rushed. Great food and a whole lot of fun!
author: Mac S.

description: So fantastic!  This is a great place to celebrate a birthday.  The food is DELISH and the all experience is so different and fun!  looove the belly dancing :)
author: Caroline B.

description: This is such a fun experience. Yes, it's more about the experience than anything else. It's great for a large group who need a bit of entertainment to spice up the conversation. Bellydancing is certainly the feature of the restaurant. The food is fine too but be prepared to open up your wallet a bit. The place is comfortable, if a bit cramped with a lot of people but is well worth the experience.
author: R K.

description: Everything we ate here was super delish.  The service was really attentive, and super friendly.  This is a great place to bring out of town guests and you want to do something interesting that everyone will probably enjoy.  The belly dancer was giving me the eye all night which I found weird . . . until I realized she was planning all along to make me get up and dance with her.  Bitch!  Needless to say, we had a great time and if I could eat that food everyday, I think I would.  Just beware of the bastela . . . it comes really hot and will burn your fingers, but it's so delish you'll just keep burning yourself over and over.
author: Danielle P.

description: OMG!!! Every time I go it just gets better and better.  I love the atmosphere of the place, the food is excellent from the first taste of their lentil soup to the last sip of the mint tea!  There's a lot of food so just pace yourself, but its delicious.  And the entertainment is very fun, especially as my husband was made to get up and dance with the belly dancer!! haha.  Two thumbs up!!!
author: Serena S.

description:
came here for the first time last saturday and i didn't know what to expect from the decor of the entrance. when i first walked in, all i saw was a huge living room type of restaurant with nice comfortable couches all around with small round tables

i've never been to a restaurant which involved finger foods and no utensils but this place had to be good for a $40 meal right?

the service was 5 stars and the food was great too, the juicy chicken and all the juicy lamb that didnt have the after taste of lamb was great. the spices they used were great as well

i was suprised about all the food and how good it was and the service was well. we had a big group and they were really nice about it too. it was a nice first experience overall because their customerservice was just so good 

the only thing that bothered me was the freaky belly dancer, she freaked me out O_O
author: Kenny L.

description: yum yum yum!  Food is delish and the belly dancer is fun (despite kinda of looking like an old stripper)... Everyone is wonderfully nice and it's a great place to kind of "escape" from the city restaurant vibe for a while.
author: Jennifer H.

description: This place definitely has a comfy exotic feel to it...I felt like I was eating inside a genie bottle! The food was delish but I did get a bit turned off by the prices and service- the waiters seemed like they were in a rush to get us out (they took one of our appetizers away when we weren't even done with it!), and since we wanted to share plates we had to shell out an extra $17 on top of the price of the meal (which was about $29). The food was good but not worth the price in my opinion.
author: Monica D.

description: El Mansour is a treat. Food is delicious and it offers a taste of something unique and other-worldly.
author: Jonathan F.

description: I went here with a group of four people.  Briefly, we loved the food!  The sweet, chicken, pie thing was amazing!  I also had the Fish Tagine which was wonderfu.  They had entertainment and it was fun to get our hands washed at the table.  My only complaint, the prix fixe menu.  We really didn't want all that food but felt forced to order it and eat it.  They should let you order at least an entree ala carte.
author: a e.

description:
I have been to many Morroccan restaurants, both in California and on the east coast, and El Mansour rates as one of the best. To start with, the menu is very limited, which may sound like a minus, but in fact is a big plus, in that the kitchen is free to concentrate on making the food the best it can be. And it is.

The lentil soup was rich, savory, hot and perfectly balanced in texture and flavor.

The Basteeya, often a dish that lacks character, or is soggy, or is oversugared, or is too eggy, was absolutely perfect. The crust was impossibly crunchy, the aroma was complex and savory, and the sugaring was in delicate proportion to the eggs and nuts that were found inside.

The Chicken with olives and preserved lemon was a revelation. Often, preserved lemon dishes are made with inferior lemons, and/or the olives are run of the mill. Both condiments were excellent, and the long-cooked chicken was hot, the skin was perfectly rendered and the meat remained succulent.

The belly dancing was well done, and sometimes very funny, as the accomplished and lovely lady made a point to embarrass and entice each man in the room. Her balance, elegance and skill was noteworthy.

Decor is lovely, and though the room was filled to capacity, each of us felt we had our own private space.

You have to go.
author: Charles L.

description:
I cannot begin to share how fantastic El Mansour, Jack, Houda, and all the staff are at El Mansour. I also cannot fully express in words what a great experience we had. My fianc and I decided to do something different and fun for our engagement party--not an easy task. I could not be happier that we thought of our local neighborhood gem for such a setting. We had been to the restaurant before a number of times (we love the food and authentic decor) but neither of us had ever planned such an event. Jack and Houda have so much experience and helped us with everything. They thought of things we would have missed that really made the event, like two fantastic belly dancers that the family just loved (I will never forget the look of delight on my Father's face as he danced with one of them). The menu gave just enough choice to make everyone happy and not too much to confuse them, the wines were delicious and of course the mint tea always fantastic. 

Jack and Houda were so accommodating; we took up the entire restaurant and yet our guests said they had never been to a more intimate and enjoyable party. The food was fantastic and the staff was so attentive!  For the Moroccans who were there, they felt transported back to another time & place and were inspired to share many stories of days gone by. Thank you El Mansour for a beautiful, unforgettable experience. Thank you Jack and Houda for your planning help and making such an incredible event possible. We'll be back soon!
author: JM R.

description: GREAT DATE PLACE! you get tasty food along side with entertainment!! goo!!
author: Isaiah W.

description: love the food, love the service, and love the belly dancer.  it is really worth the $ spending your evening there.  I have been going there fore many many years. the food and the service remain the same great quality.  The only thing is I hope the belly dancer can be a bit younger. that will be more enjoyable.   Yet, still highly recommended this place.
author: Kristie C.

description: Why in the world is everyone giving this place good reviews!?  I'm flabbergasted!  It's over-priced and the food ain't even all dat, nah mean?!  I ordered the chicken and it was COVERED in cilantro!  Who does that shieieie!?  So I basically paid 30 bucks for cilantro! The only good thing was the fresh bread, but I could get fresh bread at Outback Steakhouse for freezy, or 1/16 of the price here!  You're just paying for the atmosphere and to watch girls dance with their muffin tops hangin out!  muwahahaha.....
author: K T.

description: The atmosphere in this place is really cozy and fun, however the bellydancer is a bit too old for her job and i have seen much better. The food is good, the appetizers are much better than the actual entree. Its kinda pricy for what it is, probably wouldn't go here again.
author: Lena F.

description: I had a great birthday dinner here with friends recently. The food was wonderful - especially the chicken basteya, and we loved the pouring of the mint tea at the end of the meal. The belly dancing was great - the dancer was gorgeous! - and the service was very friendly and attentive. Great place for groups and festive occasions - really fun.
author: Irene B.

description: Great place for big groups.  Everything about the place makes it great - the food and drinks (shredded chicken wrapped in filo and sprinkled with powdered sugar and aromatic mint tea); the interior (feels like you're in a palace); service (very friendly); entertainment (the belly dancer pulls people in to join her!).
author: John c.

description: great place to bring friends for food and a little entertainment.  Came here  for my friend's birthday.  We had a blast.
author: Yen T.

description:
I love this place... the food is excellent and there's so much of it. I want to get the recipe for the lentil soup which was fantastic. I read another posting that mentioned the bastela. I have to agree that chicken and powdered sugar is an odd combo but it works! I love bastela! And last but not least... Stasha. She is so entertaining. A great dancer that really engages the crowd.

El Mansour is a fantastic restaurant.
author: Olivia G.

description: Fun and intimate setting.  The food was flavorful and pretty good.  The prices are decent.  The belly dancer wasn't what it expected, but it was still a fun vibe.
author: Jen L.

description:
I have been a fan of El Mansour for over 20 years. Great food, reasonably priced (not the California/Moroccan infused pricey snobby stuff like Aziza or the touristy places downtown or on Pacific heights), wonderful atmosphere and nice people who own it. Friday and Saturday nights you need a reservation, but other nights are less crowded. A not to be missed San Francisco tradition.

This has nothing to do with El Mansour, it is about the restaurant's patrons. If you have kids and want to go to El Mansour go early, enjoy and leave early so that adults can enjoy the experience. Parents often keep kids there way past their bedtime and then they become cranky and spoil the experience for the adults. Therefore, I have decided to only go there during the week when the food, atmosphere and entertainment can be fully enjoyed.
author: jack w.

description: different dining experience....community plates shared by hand....washing of hands to begin....thick face towel passing...more of heavy duty napkin to guard lap from drip of saucing.....wet of palate with lentil soup simple and pleasant....plain bread dip and soak...spiced and seasoned vegetable platter refreshing tastes....third, dastela du chef, a unique chicken pot pie sweetened by dusted powder sugar appetizer.....entrees following....overly sweetened almond lamb....kabob presented speared through eggplant...favorite un-messy item to eat.....standard kabob and taste....rest a slop mixture of pungent to sweet chicken...sweetness of warm prunes or raisins...olive tangy also play in mixture of food...finishing fried banana dessert....dull in thick batter texture bad....atleast this time a belly dancing belle...stuff of $dollar bills to encourage....$fifty-five per person with wine moderation....el mansour, first time a treat....second time a fading novelty....
author: Hen A.

description: We had a great time in this restaurant.  The food is surprisingly good and their service is superb for a Friday night. I also love their decor and the ambiance.  It is a bit pricey but considering that includes entertainment (belly dancing), it is worth it. I highly recommed this place to anyone who haven't been to a Morroccan restaurant.  I will suggest you go with a group of friends to make it more fun!
author: rosemarie l.

description: My friends and I had dinner here last Friday after reading great reviews and receiving suggestions from others.  The ambience was amazing, as if we stepped into a Moroccan paradise, and the house belly dancer was very entertaining.  However, the service was slightly off.  Our waiter was a bit confusing and seemed to hate the fact that we wanted to share the meals since they were $30 a pop.  What made things worse was when a waiter took away our salad, which was far from being done, and piled it under other dirty dishes.  We asked for it back but he just brought the next course instead.  In the end, we received our bill and noticed an extra $50+ for an unknown item.  We asked our waiter what it was, and he hurriedly explained that he charged extra to share meals, meaning $17 per couple for an extra soup and tea.  Although the food was tasty, it wasn't spectacular.  The dinner definitely put a damper on the rest of our evening.  I don't think we'll ever go back again.
author: Aggie R.

description: Yes A very good choice and well priced.  We stayed for nearly 3 hours and I don't consider 32$ for a full course meal along with your nightly entertainment unreasonable at all(we don't drink).  The service was very pleasant, friendly, and hospitable.  There was a certain outgoing attitude that came with the service that I felt rather good about but I can see it maybee rubbing some personalities the wrong way.  I believe their  motives to be pure.  It was a great night. We will se how things go next time I visit.
author: John D.

description: great restaurant. great service. loved the soup and the salad. the chicken with honey was great but the rabbit kabob failed my expectations. entertainment and the waiters are great, fun and welcoming people. I would definitely go back again. great idea for an adventures date.
author: Sam S.

description: If you like eating with your hands, sitting on the floor at a low table, and belly dancers, then this is the place for you. I had my 17th birthday party here. Can you imagine how happy the teenage boys were? I have always secretly wanted  to be a belly dancer since that night, but I have never set aside enough time to stick with a class. I also had one of the first dates with my husband here. He said that the fact that he was willing to  eat with his hands in front of me so early in our relationship was a sign that we were meant to be. I must say I am a fan of eating with my fingers. This fascination started young. My mom called me E.T. fingers at the dinner table because I was always picking off the platter. My favorite part of the meal is the bastilla, a spiced chicken pie that is dusted with powdered sugar. This may sound weird to some but in the annoying words of Rachelle Ray, "It's de-lish." I also love the fact that at the end of the meal the waiter washes your hands with warm water then slashes them with rose water. You literally leave there smelling better than when you got there. I think that this is a fun place, although a bit pricey for a Tues. night. The sweetened mint tea that the waiters pour from a foot above the table both refreshes you and relaxes you at the end of the meal. This is a good place for a fun evening.
author: Esa Y.

description: I went to El Mansour on a Friday night with my sis. The decor in and out is authentic and exotic as all get out. We arrived earlier than our reservation, but the owner hostess lady was gracious and seated us right away.  The wine list was so-so but drinkable. The meal is well timed and was very good.  Traditionally , they begin by washing your hands at the table and giving you a towel to dry them which is also your napkin for the meal.  Well technically you wash your own hands, and they pour the warm water for you.  They brought by yummy bread. I wasn't sure where I was supposed to set my bread while there were no other dishes on the table so I just held onto it.  Then came a plate of dips, very tasty and refreshing pickled carrots and cucumbers and a  tomato dip that was a bit like salsa. I could have used more of the eggplant dip which was both of our favorite.  Then comes a chicken in phyllo dish with powdered sugar on top. Hot as hades but really good once cooled down. Next our chicken and seafood dishes which were equally good.  Oh yes, and you eat with your hands,  I almost forgot about that. At this point the belly dancer comes out and the music gets louder, ok loud. Now I love Moroccan food, and know to expect the dancer who was really pretty and really nice and really limber and really really sparkly. For some reason this made me want to hurry up and leave. The mint tea was served as well as a plantain and honey apple phyllo something for desert. At this point I was satiated and feeling hot. No I really don't want to dance with you lady. Overall we had a great time. The food is better than good, the ambiance is lovely and yes I will go back. Perhaps I will remember to ask the hostess/owner to tell the dancing lady not to keep asking me to join her to dance, because I just don't want to.  I just learned that the dancers are on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays. Good tip.
author: Amanda L.

description: wow...this place has to be one of the best dining experiences i've ever had. another diner who's visited Marrakech mentioned it's about as authentic as it's going to get. i agree with the other reviews about the chicken almond pastry dish..it's unbelievably good. my entree included that, a tasty tomato lentil soup, bread, a salad & the seafood...all delicious. another highlight was the bellydancer.  she'll pull random diners and mesmerize them with her Shakira-esque type hip-grinding if they don't keep up with her groove. fortunately for me, i wasn't mesmerized enough and i had to show her a few moves of my own.
author: Chris C.

description: K and I decided to go to a belly dancing place, and randomly chose this restaurant. Our reservation was for 8pm on a Saturday nite. We were a few minutes late because it was so hard to find parking, but it was still fine. The inside wasn't how I thought it would be. It was pretty tiny. I did like it, sitting on little couches and things, but there were a lot of kids. There was a whole pack of kids wrestling on the ground in the middle when we arrived. I dunno, that kind of lent it a living room type feel. I'm not used to seeing a bunch of kids playing in a restaurant (or kids very often at all) so it may not have been the best place for our date. But I guess it's an excellent place for a family to go. They bring out this large samovar type thing to wash your hands before and after dinner (with rose water the last time), which was cool. We both got the regular entrée, which came with a tasty lentil soup, then a salad with cooked cucumbers and carrotts, and a very yummy babaganoush. The whole time, the waiter walks around trying to get you to eat more and more bread. You don't get the bread at the table, you take one piece at a time as he walks around. The bread was just bread, average, but he really wanted us to eat it for some reason. Lol. The water wasn't refilled as often.  After salad, they served us a yummy chicken pastry covered in confectioners sugar. Sweet and meaty at the same time, I liked it.  I had the lamb couscous for the main dish. The meat was just ok, but the couscous was good. By this time, I was kind of full... I have to say my main dish was the worst part of the meal. K had lamb with almonds and honey which was super super sweet. She liked it all right, but thought it was a little fatty, and also too just meat. Which was why I was glad to have gotten couscous. Desert was very good again. Fried bananas and some other thing. All that came in one package for $30ish or $28, so so much food, and a good deal. The belly dancer was on late because we were waiting for a group of lost people. They arrived, and she did a wonderful job, although I was picturing someone a little younger. She wasn't old old... She had everyone dance up with her, but I didn't go cuz I got kind of shy, since I knew I wouldn't be good at it. The waiters were in love with us, staring at us the whole meal, and told her to make sure to get us up on the dance floor. They were even watching me as I went to the bathroom (which was clean).  The whole meal and show lasted till after closing and we left very full at 10 something pm, with the waiter wanting us to go home with the dancer, or go to the next door bar with him to hear a band LOL. (no, we didn't do either). So, not a romantic place, but very entertaining.  The worst part was the kids, and also the actual entrees. We had fun though!
author: Merredith L.

description: great cozy place to eat with friends.. there a belly dancer for your entertainment.. unqiue food.. great for sharing.. my dinner lasted for alomost two hours... my first time trying rabbit meat~~ tastes very delicious.. I never image myself trying any other meat~~ their green tea is minty and sweet and their dessert~~
author: Lily T.

description:
great food, friendly service! went there for my first time on friday, saw the belly dancer and had an amazing meal! the ambiance was also really nice, good for dates or groups. had never eaten moroccan food before  and the waiter was kind enough to explain everything to us. my favorite dish was the chicken bastilla with powdered sugar. doesn't seem like it goes well together but was perfect! my boyfriend was a bit shy to eat with his hands but that was the funnest part for me :)

the only down side, a bit on the pricier end if you buy drinks but well worth it if you can afford it. on average it's about $32 per person, not including drinks. beer is about $5.50.
author: nellie a.

description: we went to have a morrocan dinner at the el mansour in san francisco and eat coucous but we were very disappointed .the quality and the quantity were much below average.unfortunately the coucous was over cooked and not at all the morrocan way . the atmosphere is nice and the staff were courteous ,the morrocan decor was outstanding but the food was extremely disappointing .
author: Azmi M.

description:
El Mansour is one of my favorite restaurants. Get their prix fixe dinner (about $30-35), it's to die for and very satisfying, especially the Lamb with Honey and Almonds! The prix fixe includes lentil soup with piping hot bread in thick triangular slices, a shared salad plate with marinated vegetables, eggplant salad similar to babbah ghannoush and another salad similar to Tabouleh. This is followed by a crazy hot Bastille pastry crisscrossed with powdered sugar and cinnamon, filled with eggs and chicken. You'll want to eat it so fast you'll burn yourself. After the main course dessert is served, normally fried bananas with honey and strawberries served with mint tea ceremoniously poured from three feet above each ornate glass. This place has been in business forever and the family that runs it is wonderful and very hospitable. 
Make sure to make a reservation as you may be SOL to get in otherwise on a busy weekend night. This is a great place to enjoy a slow dinner and entertainment. The Restaurant is beautiful itself with traditional Moroccan bench/cushion seating and low tables. The walls are lined with ornate design and the ceiling covered with hanging colored cloths. The belly dancer, Stasha is really amazing. Her show is clean and she is truely a talented dancer unlike many similar restaurants with nobodies that remind you more of a strip joint than traditional dance. She is graceful and has been dancing and teaching dance professionally for decades. She makes all her own costumes and although she's a few years older than she looks at first glance, is never shy to flirt with the crowd and coax unsuspecting guests to join her on the floor in dance. Definately worth the money and the drive. Great for couples, parties, and families - as long as you're cool with the belly dancer. :) Not a quiet restaurant, especially after 9pm.
author: J B.

description: came here for a work-related function and had the full dinner. what an awesome experience. from the rose water hand washing to morrocan mint tea at the end, every moment was enjoyable. the seating was super comfortable and the decor posh but unassuming. while i liked the lamb, chicken and couscous very much, for some reason the simple lentil soup impressed me the most. yum!
author: Jane C.

description: I've been here many times over the years both with large groups and small and always have a wonderful experience!
